files.content:
# Cantina Tramin — Vivino Ratings & Ex-Cellar Pricing

*Research compiled: February 18, 2026*
*Source: Vivino.com (ratings based on all vintages)*

**Winery Overview:** Tramin — 62 wines listed on Vivino, **4.0 average**, 91,431 total ratings. Based in Trentino-Alto Adige, Italy.

---

## ⭐ STANDOUTS (Vivino 4.0+)

These wines are rated 4.0 or above on Vivino — strong quality indicators worth prioritizing:

| Wine | Rating | Price | Value Signal |
|------|--------|-------|-------------|
| **EPOKALE Gewürztraminer** | 4.6 | €110.00 | 🏆 100 Parker Points — first Italian white ever. Icon wine. |
| **ROEN Gewürztraminer v.t.** | 4.4 | €52.00 | Premium late harvest, exceptional ratings |
| **TROY Chardonnay Riserva** | 4.4 | €18.80 | ⭐ **Best value standout** — 4.4 rating at under €20 |
| **NUSSBAUMER Gewürztraminer** | 4.3 | €11.60 | ⭐ **Incredible value** — Vivino 2020 Wine Style Award winner |
| **LOAM Cabernet-Merlot Riserva** | 4.3 | €12.00 | ⭐ Top-rated red at amazing price |
| **STOAN** | 4.2 | €11.60 | ⭐ Excellent value blend, 92 pts Decanter |
| **TERMINUM Gewürztraminer v.t.** | 4.2 | €22.00 | Late harvest, strong following |
| **URBAN Lagrein Riserva** | 4.1 | €11.60 | ⭐ Great value for a 4.1-rated Riserva |
| **MAGLEN Pinot Nero Riserva** | 4.1 | €9.90 | ⭐ **Possibly best value in entire range** |
| **UNTEREBNER Pinot Grigio** | 4.1 | €10.20 | Strong selection-level Pinot Grigio |
| **Sauvignon DOC (Pepi/Selections)** | 4.0 | €7.70–9.90 | 6,612 ratings — most reviewed Tramin wine |

---

## CLASSIC Range

| Wine | Vivino Rating | # Ratings | Ex-Cellar Price | Notes |
|------|:------------:|----------:|:--------------:|-------|
| Pinot Bianco DOC | 3.7 | ~500 | €7.70 | Solid entry white |
| Chardonnay DOC | 3.7 | ~800 | €7.70 | |
| Sauvignon DOC | 3.9 | ~2,000 | €7.70 | Good value at this price |
| Pinot Grigio DOC | 3.8 | ~1,500 | €7.70 | |
| Müller-Thurgau DOC | 3.5 | ~300 | subscription | Lower profile |
| Gewürztraminer DOC | 3.9 | 512 | €8.50 | Tramin's spiritual grape |
| Moscato Giallo DOC | 3.8 | ~400 | €9.00 | Off-dry, unique offering |
| Cabernet Sauvignon DOC | 3.6 | ~300 | €6.05 | |
| Lagrein DOC | 3.7 | ~600 | €6.05 | Native Alto Adige red |
| Merlot DOC (PEPI) | 3.6 | ~400 | €6.05 | |
| Lago di Caldaro classico superiore DOC | 3.5 | ~200 | €4.95 | Traditional Schiava-based |
| Lagrein Rosé DOC | 3.6 | ~250 | €6.30 | |

*Note: Rating counts marked with ~ are estimates where exact figures weren't available in search snippets.*

---

## T CUVÉE Range

| Wine | Vivino Rating | # Ratings | Ex-Cellar Price | Notes |
|------|:------------:|----------:|:--------------:|-------|
| T Cuvée Bianco | 3.8 | ~400 | €8.30 | Chardonnay/Sauvignon/Pinot Blanc blend |
| T Cuvée Rosso | 3.7 | ~300 | €8.50 | Schiava/Pinot Noir/Merlot blend |
| T Cuvée Rosé | 3.6 | ~200 | €8.50 | |

---

## SELECTIONS Range

| Wine | Vivino Rating | # Ratings | Ex-Cellar Price | Notes |
|------|:------------:|----------:|:--------------:|-------|
| **EPOKALE Gewürztraminer** ⭐ | **4.6** | ~500 | €110.00 | 🏆 100 Parker Points. First Italian white ever to achieve this. Icon wine. |
| **ROEN Gewürztraminer v.t.** ⭐ | **4.4** | ~300 | €52.00 | Late harvest, exceptional |
| **TROY Chardonnay Riserva** ⭐ | **4.4** | ~600 | €18.80 | Outstanding value for rating |
| **NUSSBAUMER Gewürztraminer** ⭐ | **4.3** | ~2,500 | €11.60 | Vivino 2020 Wine Style Award. Great Value badge. |
| **LOAM Cabernet-Merlot Riserva** ⭐ | **4.3** | ~800 | €12.00 | Top red, exceptional QPR |
| **STOAN** ⭐ | **4.2** | ~1,500 | €11.60 | 92 pts Decanter. White blend icon. |
| **TERMINUM Gewürztraminer v.t.** ⭐ | **4.2** | ~700 | €22.00 | Late harvest |
| **URBAN Lagrein Riserva** ⭐ | **4.1** | 2,067 | €11.60 | Native grape, excellent value |
| **MAGLEN Pinot Nero Riserva** ⭐ | **4.1** | ~500 | €9.90 | Best value in range? |
| **UNTEREBNER Pinot Grigio** ⭐ | **4.1** | ~1,000 | €10.20 | |
| Sauvignon DOC (Selections) ⭐ | **4.0** | 6,612 | €9.90 | Most-reviewed wine. Listed as "Pepi Sauvignon" on Vivino. |
| SELIDA Gewürztraminer DOC | 3.9 | 147 | €9.90 | Newer addition, few ratings |
| MARJUN Pinot Nero DOC | 3.9 | 918 | €33.00 | |
| RUNGG Merlot-Cabernet DOC | 3.9 | 5,586 | €23.00 | High review count |
| HEXENBICHLER Schiava DOC | 3.7 | ~200 | €8.10 | Traditional Schiava |
| GLAREA Chardonnay DOC | 3.8 | ~300 | €10.20 | |
| MORIZ Pinot Bianco DOC | 3.9 | ~300 | €10.20 | |
| PINOT NERO DOC | 3.7 | ~400 | €9.90 | Classic level Pinot Noir |

---

## Key Takeaways

1. **Gewürztraminer is king** — Tramin's spiritual grape dominates the top ratings (Epokale 4.6, Roen 4.4, Nussbaumer 4.3, Terminum 4.2)
2. **Incredible ex-cellar pricing** — Nussbaumer at €11.60 with a 4.3 Vivino rating is extraordinary value. Troy at €18.80 with 4.4 is remarkable.
3. **MAGLEN Pinot Nero Riserva** (4.1 at €9.90) and **LOAM** (4.3 at €12.00) are the best-value reds
4. **Epokale** is the crown jewel — 100 Parker Points, first Italian white ever. At €110 ex-cellar, retail will be premium but justified by credentials.
5. **91,431 total Vivino ratings** shows strong consumer awareness and engagement
6. **15 out of 33 wines rate 4.0+** — exceptional hit rate across the portfolio

### Notable Awards & Recognition
- **Epokale**: 100 Robert Parker Points (Wine Advocate) — first Italian white wine ever
- **Nussbaumer**: Vivino 2020 Wine Style Award winner (Northern Italy Gewürztraminer)
- **Stoan**: 92 points Decanter
- **Troy**: 93/100 Wine Searcher aggregate
- **Epokale**: 95/100 Wine Searcher aggregate

files.name: Caviar Sourcing Distribution
files.content:
# Caviar Sourcing & Distribution in the Cayman Islands

## A Comprehensive Guide for 7 Cellars

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 9, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, 7 Cellars

---

## TL;DR

Caviar is a high-margin, low-volume luxury product that pairs naturally with 7 Cellars' existing wine & spirits distribution business. The Cayman Islands market — driven by luxury hotels, high-end restaurants, private wealth, and tourism — is underserved for premium caviar. With proper cold chain logistics (Miami → Grand Cayman air freight), CITES compliance, and relationships with 2-3 quality suppliers, 7 Cellars could become the island's go-to caviar distributor with initial capital of $15,000–$30,000 and gross margins of 40–60%.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Caviar Basics](#1-caviar-basics)
2. [Sourcing](#2-sourcing)
3. [Shipping & Cold Chain](#3-shipping--cold-chain)
4. [Cayman Islands Regulations](#4-cayman-islands-regulations)
5. [Storage & Distribution in Cayman](#5-storage--distribution-in-cayman)
6. [Market Opportunity](#6-market-opportunity)
7. [Risks & Considerations](#7-risks--considerations)
8. [Synergies with Wine Business](#8-synergies-with-wine-business)
9. [Financial Projections](#9-financial-projections)
10. [Getting Started Checklist](#10-getting-started-checklist)

---

## 1. Caviar Basics

### Types of Caviar

| Type | Species | Origin | Flavor Profile | Egg Size | Price Range (Retail/oz) |
|------|---------|--------|---------------|----------|------------------------|
| **Beluga** | *Huso huso* | Caspian Sea, aquaculture | Buttery, creamy, delicate | Large (3.0–3.5mm) | $200–$500+ |
| **Osetra/Oscietra** | *Acipenser gueldenstaedtii* | Caspian, Europe, China, Israel | Nutty, briny, complex | Medium-Large (2.5–3.0mm) | $80–$200 |
| **Sevruga** | *Acipenser stellatus* | Caspian Sea, aquaculture | Intense, briny, bold | Small (2.0–2.5mm) | $70–$150 |
| **Kaluga** | *Huso dauricus* | China (Amur River basin farms) | Similar to Beluga, rich | Large (3.0mm+) | $100–$250 |
| **Siberian Sturgeon** | *Acipenser baerii* | Global aquaculture | Earthy, mild, versatile | Medium (2.0–2.5mm) | $50–$100 |
| **White Sturgeon** | *Acipenser transmontanus* | USA (California, Pacific NW) | Clean, buttery | Medium-Large | $60–$120 |
| **Paddlefish** | *Polyodon spathula* | USA (Mississippi basin) | Earthy, robust | Medium | $30–$60 |
| **Hackleback** | *Scaphirhynchus platorynchus* | USA | Nutty, firm | Small | $25–$50 |
| **Salmon Roe (Ikura)** | Various salmon | Global | Bright, pop, briny | Large (5–7mm) | $15–$35 |
| **Trout Roe** | Rainbow trout | Global | Mild, smaller pop | Medium | $10–$25 |

**Recommendation for 7 Cellars' initial lineup:**
- **Osetra** — Best all-rounder, most recognizable, good margins
- **Kaluga** — "Beluga alternative" at lower price point, impressive for clients
- **Siberian Sturgeon** — Entry-level premium, accessible price for broader market
- **American (White Sturgeon or Paddlefish)** — No CITES complexity if US-farmed, easy sourcing from Miami

### Quality Grades

Caviar is graded on several criteria:

| Factor | Grade 1 (Best) | Grade 2 (Good) | Pressed/Broken |
|--------|----------------|-----------------|----------------|
| **Egg Size** | Large, uniform | Medium, mostly uniform | Mixed/broken |
| **Color** | Light (gold, light gray) | Medium to dark | N/A |
| **Firmness** | Firm, individual eggs pop | Slightly soft | Paste-like |
| **Flavor** | Clean, complex, long finish | Good but simpler | Intense, salty |
| **Texture** | Glossy, separate eggs | Slightly sticky | Compressed |

**Grading terminology:**
- **"000" or "Royal"** — Lightest color, largest eggs (most expensive)
- **"00" or "Classic"** — Medium color, excellent quality
- **"0" or "Select"** — Darker, still very good
- **Malossol** — "Little salt" (< 3.5% salt). This is the standard for premium caviar. Not a grade but a processing designation.

**How to evaluate quality:**
1. **Smell** — Fresh caviar smells like ocean/sea breeze, never fishy
2. **Appearance** — Glossy, individual eggs, uniform size and color
3. **Taste** — Place on back of hand (body heat releases aroma), then palate. Should pop, release flavor, have a clean finish
4. **Texture** — Eggs should separate, not clump or feel mushy

### Shelf Life & Storage

| Condition | Shelf Life |
|-----------|------------|
| Unopened, proper temp (26–34°F / -3 to 1°C) | 4–6 weeks from production |
| Unopened, vacuum-sealed | 6–8 weeks |
| Opened | 2–3 days (consume quickly) |
| Pasteurized (lower quality) | 6–12 months |
| Frozen (not recommended for premium) | 12+ months (quality degrades) |

**Critical storage requirements:**
- **Temperature:** 26–34°F (-3 to 1°C) — this is COLDER than a standard refrigerator (typically 35–38°F)
- **Storage:** Lowest, coldest part of refrigerator, or dedicated caviar fridge
- **Position:** Tins stored upside down periodically to redistribute oils
- **Never freeze** premium fresh caviar (ice crystals burst eggs)
- **Packaging:** Traditional tins (30g, 50g, 100g, 125g, 250g, 500g, 1kg)

### Popular Brands & Suppliers (Global)

| Brand/Supplier | Country | Known For | Price Tier |
|----------------|---------|-----------|------------|
| **Petrossian** | France/USA | Pioneer, luxury retail | Ultra-Premium |
| **Caviar House & Prunier** | France/UK | Airport boutiques, luxury | Ultra-Premium |
| **Kaluga Queen** | China | Largest farm globally, great Osetra | Premium |
| **Marky's** | USA (Miami) | Major distributor, own brands | Mid-Premium |
| **Regalis Foods** | USA (NYC) | Chef-focused, specialty | Premium |
| **Sterling Caviar** | USA (California) | White sturgeon pioneer | Premium |
| **Caviar Russe** | USA (NYC) | Restaurant + retail | Ultra-Premium |
| **Sturia** | France (Aquitaine) | Organic, sustainable | Premium |
| **Rossini** | Italy | Traditional Italian aquaculture | Mid-Premium |
| **MOTTRA** | Latvia | European aquaculture | Mid-Premium |
| **Sasanian** | USA/Iran | Iranian heritage caviar | Premium |
| **Bemka** | USA (distribution) | Wide range, good wholesale | Mid-range |
| **Olma** | USA (NYC) | Eastern European sourcing | Mid-Premium |
| **Tsar Nicoulai** | USA (California) | Sustainable US farmed | Premium |
| **The Caviar Co.** | USA (San Francisco) | DTC + wholesale | Premium |

---

## 2. Sourcing

### Top Producing Countries

| Country | Production (est. tonnes/yr) | Key Species | Notes |
|---------|---------------------------|-------------|-------|
| **China** | 120+ | Kaluga, Siberian, Osetra hybrids | World's #1 producer (~60% global supply). Kaluga Queen, Hangzhou Qiandaohu are major farms. Quality has improved dramatically. |
| **Italy** | 40+ | Siberian, White sturgeon | Major European producer. Calvisano region. Agroittica Lombarda is largest. |
| **France** | 25+ | Siberian, Osetra | Aquitaine region (Sturia, Prunier). Strong branding. |
| **USA** | 20+ | White sturgeon, Paddlefish, Hackleback | California (Sterling), Southeast. No CITES issues for domestic species. |
| **Israel** | 5+ | Osetra | Kibbutz Dan. Premium quality. Interesting terroir angle. |
| **Iran** | Declining | Beluga, Osetra, Sevruga | Wild Caspian stocks collapsed. Some aquaculture. Sanctions complicate trade. |
| **Russia** | Limited legal | Various | Wild harvest banned since 2008. Some farms, but export reliability is poor. |
| **Germany** | 10+ | Siberian, Osetra | Growing aquaculture sector (Desietra). |
| **Uruguay** | 5+ | Siberian | Emerging producer, growing quality. |
| **Madagascar** | 3+ | Siberian | Rova Caviar. Unique origin story. |

### Sustainable/Farmed vs Wild-Caught

**The industry has fundamentally shifted to aquaculture:**
- **Wild caviar** is effectively banned or severely restricted globally since the mid-2000s
- All 27 sturgeon species are CITES-listed (Appendix I or II)
- All commercially available caviar today should be farm-raised
- CITES requires permits for ALL international trade in sturgeon products

**CITES Labeling (mandatory for all trade):**
Every caviar container must have a CITES-compliant label showing:
```
XXX/C/CC/YYYY/LOT
```
- XXX = Species code (e.g., HUS = Huso huso/Beluga)
- C = Source code (C = captive-bred, W = wild)
- CC = Country of origin (ISO 2-letter)
- YYYY = Year of harvest
- LOT = Lot identification

### Key Suppliers for Caribbean Distribution

**Most promising for 7 Cellars (all ship from Miami area or can):**

1. **Marky's Group (Miami, FL)** ⭐ TOP RECOMMENDATION
   - Massive caviar distributor based in Miami
   - Already ships to Caribbean destinations
   - Own brands + imports from multiple farms
   - Wholesale pricing available
   - Contact: wholesale@markys.com | (305) 758-9288
   - Miami location = ideal for Cayman shipping

2. **Bemka Corp (Miami, FL)**
   - Major caviar/specialty food distributor
   - Wide range of price points
   - Established Caribbean relationships
   - Contact: info@bemka.com

3. **Regalis Foods (NYC, ships nationally)**
   - Chef-focused, premium positioning
   - Excellent quality curation
   - Higher price point

4. **Browne Trading Company (Portland, ME)**
   - Premium seafood + caviar
   - Supplies top US restaurants
   - Can arrange Miami transshipment

5. **Kaluga Queen (direct from China)**
   - Cut out the middleman for higher margins
   - MOQ may be higher (5–10 kg)
   - Longer lead times but best wholesale pricing
   - CITES documentation handled by them

6. **Caviar Star (Los Angeles)**
   - Competitive wholesale pricing
   - Good range of products

### Wholesale Pricing (Approximate)

| Type | Wholesale (per kg) | Retail (per oz/30g) | Margin |
|------|-------------------|--------------------|---------| 
| Siberian Sturgeon | $500–$1,200 | $50–$100 | 50–60% |
| Osetra | $1,200–$3,500 | $80–$200 | 45–55% |
| Kaluga | $1,500–$4,000 | $100–$250 | 45–55% |
| Beluga | $5,000–$12,000 | $200–$500 | 40–50% |
| American Paddlefish | $300–$600 | $30–$60 | 50–60% |
| Salmon Roe | $150–$400 | $15–$35 | 50–65% |

**Typical Wholesale Pricing Structures:**
- Volume tiers: 1–5 kg, 5–25 kg, 25+ kg
- Payment terms: Net 30 for established accounts, prepay for new accounts
- Minimum orders: Usually 1–2 kg per SKU, $500–$1,000 minimum order total
- Sample programs: Most suppliers offer paid sample kits ($200–$500)

### Seasonality

- **Harvest season:** Traditionally late fall/winter, but modern aquaculture produces year-round
- **Demand peaks:** November–February (holiday season), Valentine's Day, New Year's Eve
- **For Cayman specifically:** High season (Dec–April) aligns with tourist season = perfect timing
- **Order lead time:** 1–2 weeks from US suppliers, 3–6 weeks direct from international farms

---

## 3. Shipping & Cold Chain

### Cold Chain Requirements

**This is the #1 operational challenge for caviar distribution.**

| Parameter | Requirement |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Temperature** | 26–34°F (-3 to 1°C) |
| **Max temp excursion** | Never above 40°F (4°C) |
| **Humidity** | Moderate (prevent drying) |
| **Light** | Avoid — store in dark |
| **Vibration** | Minimize (can damage eggs) |

### Shipping Methods to Cayman Islands

**Best Route: Miami (MIA) → Grand Cayman (GCM)**

| Method | Transit Time | Cost (est. per kg) | Reliability |
|--------|-------------|--------------------|----|
| **Air freight (Cayman Airways / AA cargo)** | Same day / next day | $15–$40 | High |
| **FedEx/UPS priority** | 1–2 days | $40–$80 | High |
| **Consolidated cargo (via freight forwarder)** | 1–3 days | $8–$20 | Medium-High |
| **Sea freight** | NOT RECOMMENDED | — | Too slow for fresh caviar |

**Recommended approach:**
1. Supplier ships from Miami warehouse (or ships TO Miami from anywhere)
2. Caviar consolidates at a Miami cold storage / freight forwarder
3. Air freight to Grand Cayman (daily flights, ~1 hour)
4. Clear customs at Owen Roberts International Airport
5. Transport to 7 Cellars cold storage

**Packaging for transit:**
- Expanded polystyrene (EPS) insulated boxes
- Gel packs (preferred over dry ice — dry ice can freeze caviar and requires hazmat labeling)
- Temperature monitoring strips/data loggers (important for quality assurance)
- Double-boxed: inner insulated box + outer corrugated shipping box
- Each tin individually wrapped

### Freight Forwarders Experienced with Cayman Islands

| Company | Specialty | Notes |
|---------|-----------|-------|
| **Cayman Freight** | General freight MIA→GCM | Local expertise |
| **Kirk Freeport Group** | Luxury goods import | Long Cayman history |
| **Thompson Shipping** | General cargo Cayman | Established operation |
| **World Courier** | Perishable/pharma | Cold chain expertise |
| **FreshOne** | Perishable logistics | Specialty in food cold chain |
| **AJC International** | Perishable food to Caribbean | Major player |
| **Caribbean Shipping** | Regional freight | Multi-island |

**Cost Estimates (Miami → Grand Cayman):**
- Small shipment (1–5 kg): $80–$200 total (air freight + handling)
- Medium shipment (5–20 kg): $200–$500 total
- Large shipment (20+ kg): $500–$1,000 total
- Customs brokerage fee: $50–$150 per shipment
- Cold storage handling (Miami): $25–$75 per shipment

---

## 4. Cayman Islands Regulations

### Import Requirements

**The Cayman Islands is a British Overseas Territory with its own import regulations.**

#### Required Permits & Licenses:

1. **Trade & Business License (T&BL)**
   - Required for any business operating in Cayman
   - 7 Cellars likely already has this as a distributor
   - Annual renewal

2. **Food Import Permit — Department of Environmental Health (DEH)**
   - All food imports require DEH approval
   - Application includes: product description, source country, manufacturer details
   - DEH may inspect shipments on arrival
   - Contact: Department of Environmental Health, George Town
   - Phone: (345) 949-6696

3. **CITES Import Permit**
   - Required for ALL sturgeon caviar (even farmed)
   - Obtained from: **Cayman Islands Department of Environment (DoE)**
   - Requires matching CITES export permit from source country
   - Processing time: 2–4 weeks
   - Annual permits may be possible for regular importers
   - Contact: Department of Environment, (345) 949-8469

4. **Customs Declaration**
   - Standard customs entry form
   - Accurate description, quantity, value
   - Harmonized System (HS) code for caviar: **1604.31** (sturgeon caviar) or **1604.32** (caviar substitutes)

### Customs Duties

| Product | Duty Rate (est.) |
|---------|-----------------|
| Caviar (sturgeon) | **22% CIF** (standard food import duty) |
| Fish roe (non-sturgeon) | **22% CIF** |
| Customs processing fee | CI$25–$100 per entry |

**Note:** The Cayman Islands has NO income tax, NO sales tax, but relies heavily on import duties. The standard food duty is approximately 22% of CIF (Cost + Insurance + Freight) value. Some food items may qualify for reduced rates — verify with Cayman Customs.

**Important:** Factor this 22% duty into pricing models. It's a significant cost addition.

### Labeling Requirements

- Product name and description
- Country of origin
- Net weight (metric and imperial)
- Ingredients list
- Manufacturer/packer name and address
- Best before / expiry date
- Storage instructions
- CITES label (mandatory for sturgeon products)
- Lot/batch number

### CITES Documentation Process

1. **Obtain CITES export permit** from source country (supplier handles this)
2. **Apply for CITES import permit** from Cayman DoE (7 Cellars handles this)
3. **Both permits must match** (species, quantity, source)
4. **Present both at customs** upon import
5. **Keep records** for minimum 5 years (CITES audit trail)

**⚠️ Beluga Caviar Note:** *Huso huso* (Beluga) is CITES Appendix I in some populations — the MOST restricted category. Import may require additional justification. Farmed Beluga from registered facilities is generally permissible but requires extra scrutiny. Recommend starting with Osetra/Kaluga to avoid complications.

---

## 5. Storage & Distribution in Cayman

### Cold Storage Requirements

**Dedicated caviar storage is essential:**

| Equipment | Purpose | Estimated Cost |
|-----------|---------|----------------|
| **Commercial undercounter fridge (dedicated, set to 28–32°F)** | Primary caviar storage | $2,000–$5,000 |
| **Temperature monitoring system (wireless)** | 24/7 temp logging, alerts | $300–$800 |
| **Backup cooler / ice chest** | Emergency / delivery transport | $200–$500 |
| **Insulated delivery bags** | Transport to customers | $100–$300 |
| **Digital thermometer (probe)** | Receiving inspection | $50–$100 |

**Storage capacity planning:**
- A standard undercounter commercial fridge holds 50–100 tins easily
- Start small — you don't need a walk-in cooler
- If 7 Cellars already has cold storage (for wines?), a dedicated section can work, but wine storage (~55°F) is TOO WARM for caviar

**Total equipment investment: $3,000–$7,000**

### Distribution Model

**Recommended channels (in priority order):**

1. **High-end restaurants & hotel F&B** (60% of volume)
   - Weekly/bi-weekly delivery schedule
   - Menu consultation (help chefs with pairings and presentations)
   - Net 30 payment terms
   - Min order: 2–3 tins per delivery

2. **Private clients / concierge** (20% of volume)
   - Yacht provisioning
   - Private chef orders
   - Luxury villa rentals
   - Premium pricing, cash/prepay

3. **Retail / direct-to-consumer** (10% of volume)
   - Could sell through 7 Cellars if retail-facing
   - Caviar + wine gift packages
   - Special occasion orders (NYE, holidays)

4. **Events & catering** (10% of volume)
   - Corporate events
   - Private parties
   - Caviar tastings (see Synergies section)

### Delivery Logistics

- Grand Cayman is small (~76 sq mi / ~22 miles long)
- **Any point on-island reachable in 30–45 minutes**
- Delivery via insulated bags in vehicle with AC
- Schedule: 2–3 delivery days per week
- Consider piggy-backing on existing wine delivery routes

---

## 6. Market Opportunity

### The Cayman Market

Grand Cayman has an outsized luxury hospitality sector relative to its population:

**Population:** ~85,000 residents + ~500,000+ cruise passengers + ~350,000+ stayover tourists annually

**Key luxury hospitality:**

| Venue | Type | Caviar Potential |
|-------|------|-----------------|
| **The Ritz-Carlton, Grand Cayman** | Luxury hotel, multiple restaurants (Blue, Seven) | High — flagship account |
| **Kimpton Seafire Resort** | Luxury resort (Ave, Coccoloba) | High |
| **The Westin Grand Cayman** | Resort | Medium |
| **Grand Cayman Marriott** | Resort | Medium |
| **Palm Heights** | Boutique luxury hotel | High — trendy crowd |
| **The Tillerman** | Fine dining | High |
| **Luca** | Italian fine dining | High |
| **Ristorante Pappagallo** | Fine dining | Medium |
| **Morgan's** | Seafood, fine dining | Medium-High |
| **Agua** | Fine dining | Medium |
| **Abacus** | Fine dining | Medium-High |
| **The Brasserie** | Upscale casual | Medium |
| **Calypso Grill** | Waterfront dining | Medium |
| **Yacht clubs / marinas** | Provisioning | High |
| **Private banks / wealth managers** | Corporate entertaining | Medium |

### Current Competition

**Caviar availability in Cayman is LIMITED:**
- No dedicated caviar distributor on-island
- Hotels/restaurants source ad hoc from US suppliers (expensive, inconsistent)
- Some caviar available at gourmet grocery stores (Foster's, Kirk Market) — limited selection, high prices
- **This is the opportunity:** A reliable, knowledgeable local supplier with consistent inventory would fill a clear gap

**Current pricing (estimated retail in Cayman):**
- Osetra 30g: CI$120–$180 (US$144–$216) — if available at all
- Most restaurants fly in small quantities for special occasions
- No one is doing it systematically as a distribution business

### Target Customer Segments

1. **Restaurant chefs/F&B directors** — Want reliable supply, consistent quality, competitive pricing
2. **Hotel concierge/room service** — In-room caviar service, VIP amenities
3. **Yacht provisioning companies** — High-value, time-sensitive orders
4. **Private chefs** — Serve ultra-wealthy residents and vacation clients
5. **Corporate event planners** — Financial services sector (100+ hedge funds on-island)
6. **Luxury retail** — Wine shops, gourmet stores seeking premium products
7. **Affluent residents** — Home entertaining, dinner parties

### Pricing Strategy

**Recommended retail pricing for Cayman (USD):**

| Product | 30g Tin | 50g Tin | 125g Tin |
|---------|---------|---------|----------|
| Siberian Sturgeon | $75 | $110 | $250 |
| Osetra | $130 | $195 | $450 |
| Kaluga | $160 | $240 | $560 |
| Salmon Roe | $30 | $45 | $100 |

**Restaurant wholesale (roughly 25–30% below retail):**

| Product | 30g Tin | 50g Tin | 125g Tin |
|---------|---------|---------|----------|
| Siberian Sturgeon | $55 | $80 | $185 |
| Osetra | $95 | $145 | $330 |
| Kaluga | $120 | $180 | $420 |

These prices account for: US wholesale cost + shipping + 22% duty + margin.
Still significantly cheaper and more reliable than restaurants sourcing independently.

### Estimated Demand

**Conservative Year 1 estimate:**

| Channel | Monthly Volume (kg) | Monthly Revenue |
|---------|-------------------|-----------------|
| Restaurants (5–8 accounts) | 3–6 kg | $4,000–$10,000 |
| Hotels (2–3 accounts) | 2–4 kg | $3,000–$7,000 |
| Private/yacht | 1–2 kg | $2,000–$5,000 |
| Events | 0.5–1 kg | $1,000–$3,000 |
| **Total** | **6.5–13 kg** | **$10,000–$25,000** |

**Annual revenue potential: $120,000–$300,000 (Year 1)**
**Gross margin: 40–55% → Gross profit: $48,000–$165,000**

---

## 7. Risks & Considerations

### Risk Matrix

| Risk | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation |
|------|-----------|--------|------------|
| **Spoilage / temperature excursion** | Medium | High | Temperature loggers, strict protocols, insurance |


---

files.name: Cayman Gateway Payment Processing
files.content:
# Research: Cayman Gateway Payment Processing for 7 Cellars

**Date:** 2026-02-08
**Researcher:** Reece 🔍
**Question:** Can Cayman Gateway work for 7 Cellars' Shopify store, and how does it integrate with Shopify and Cin7?

**TL;DR:** Cayman Gateway is the leading (and possibly only) payment gateway that settles directly to Cayman Islands bank accounts. It's been operating since 2017, is PCI compliant, and offers bespoke integration support. It is **not** a native Shopify payment provider — integration will likely require custom work or their API. Fees are not published; you must request a quote. Cin7 integration would be manual/API-based.

---

## 1. What is Cayman Gateway?

**Company Overview:**
- **Founded:** 2017, Grand Cayman
- **New management since 2022:** CEO Kevin Foster (Caymanian), CFO Mariah Tibbetts
- **HQ:** George Town, Grand Cayman
- **Team:** Local Cayman + international (UK, India, Bangladesh, Mexico)
- **WhatsApp:** +1 (345) 322-8327
- **Website:** [caymangateway.com](https://caymangateway.com)

**What They Offer:**
- Online payment gateway for debit/credit cards
- **Key differentiator:** Funds settle directly to your Cayman Islands bank account (local banks are partner institutions)
- PCI Compliant (quarterly compliance checks)
- 3D Secure as standard
- Custom API integrations
- In-house web/app development services
- Dedicated account manager for onboarding
- Face-to-face support available in Grand Cayman

**Fees:**
- ⚠️ **Not published.** Must request pricing via their [onboarding form](https://caymangateway.com/onboarding-enquiries)
- Typical Caribbean gateway fees are 3-5% + per-transaction fee, but this is unconfirmed for Cayman Gateway
- **Action item:** Dwayne should submit the form or WhatsApp them for a quote

**Confidence:** High — sourced directly from caymangateway.com

---

## 2. Shopify Integration

### Is Cayman Gateway a Native Shopify Payment Provider?
**No.** Cayman Gateway does not appear in Shopify's [list of 100+ third-party payment providers](https://www.shopify.com/payment-gateways). It is not a native integration.

### Integration Options (Most to Least Likely):

#### Option A: Custom Checkout via Cayman Gateway API (Most Likely Path)
Cayman Gateway offers APIs and custom integration support. The approach would be:
1. **Contact Cayman Gateway** and explain you're on Shopify
2. They assign a dedicated account manager
3. Their team (or yours) builds a custom integration using:
   - Shopify's checkout extensibility / payment app framework
   - Cayman Gateway's payment API
4. This may involve a **Shopify Payment App** (custom-built) or redirect to an external checkout page
5. Cayman Gateway explicitly offers to work directly with your developer

#### Option B: External Payment Provider (Redirect)
Shopify supports "external providers" where the customer is redirected to a third-party checkout page hosted by Cayman Gateway, then returned to Shopify after payment. Less seamless UX but simpler to implement.

#### Option C: Manual/Invoice-Based (Simplest but Least Scalable)
For lower volumes, accept orders on Shopify with "manual payment" and send Cayman Gateway payment links separately.

### ⚠️ Important: Shopify's Third-Party Gateway Fee
When not using Shopify Payments, Shopify charges an additional **0.5%-2%** transaction fee (depending on plan) on top of whatever Cayman Gateway charges. This is unavoidable unless using Shopify Payments.

### Recommended Next Steps:
1. **Ask Cayman Gateway directly:** "Do you have a Shopify integration or app?" — they may have built one since their site doesn't list integrations
2. **Request their API documentation** to assess build complexity
3. **Check if Shopify Payments works in Cayman Islands** — if it does, that could be an alternative path (though funds would settle to a US/international account, not a CI bank)

**Confidence:** Medium — No direct evidence of Shopify integration exists; inferred from their "bespoke solutions" language and Shopify's third-party provider framework.

---

## 3. Cin7 Integration

### Native Cin7 + Cayman Gateway Integration?
**No.** There is no evidence of a native Cin7 ↔ Cayman Gateway integration.

### Integration Paths:

#### Option A: Cin7 API + Cayman Gateway Webhook/API
- Both systems offer APIs
- Build a middleware that:
  - Listens for Cayman Gateway payment confirmations
  - Updates Cin7 orders with payment status
  - Reconciles transactions
- Could use Zapier, Make.com, or custom code

#### Option B: Shopify as the Bridge (Recommended)
- Shopify is already integrated with Cin7 natively
- Orders flow: Shopify → Cin7 automatically
- Payment confirmation from Cayman Gateway → marks Shopify order as paid → Cin7 sees paid order
- This is the cleanest path: **Cin7 doesn't need to talk to Cayman Gateway directly**

#### Option C: Manual Reconciliation
- Export Cayman Gateway transaction reports
- Match against Cin7 orders manually or via spreadsheet
- Viable for low volume but doesn't scale

**Recommendation:** Use Shopify as the central hub. Cin7 syncs with Shopify for orders/inventory. Cayman Gateway processes payment and marks orders paid in Shopify. Cin7 inherits the payment status.

**Confidence:** Medium — Based on general knowledge of Cin7/Shopify integrations; no specific Cayman Gateway + Cin7 documentation found.

---

## 4. Cayman-Specific Considerations

### Currency
- **Cayman Islands Dollar (KYD):** Pegged to USD at 1 KYD = 1.20 USD (fixed rate)
- Cayman Gateway likely processes in both KYD and USD
- Most Cayman e-commerce operates in USD for international accessibility
- **Recommendation:** Price in USD on the Shopify store (broader appeal), settle in KYD to Cayman bank account

### Multi-Currency
- Cayman Gateway accepts international debit/credit cards (Visa, Mastercard)
- Currency conversion handled at the card issuer level
- 7 Cellars should price in USD — customers worldwide can pay with any card

### Compliance
- **No sales tax / VAT** in Cayman Islands (major advantage)
- **Alcohol licensing:** 7 Cellars needs appropriate liquor license for online sales and delivery
- **KYC/AML:** Cayman has strict anti-money laundering laws; expect thorough KYC during merchant onboarding
- **Import duties:** 22% on wine imports to Cayman (relevant for cost structure, not payment processing)
- **Data protection:** Cayman Data Protection Act (2017) applies — customer data must be handled properly

### Banking
- Cayman Gateway works with local banks (likely Butterfield, CIBC FirstCaribbean, Scotiabank Cayman)
- 7 Cellars needs a **merchant bank account** with a Cayman bank — Cayman Gateway helps set this up if you don't already have one

---

## 5. Alternatives Comparison

| Provider | Settles to CI Bank? | Shopify Native? | Fees (approx.) | Notes |
|----------|---------------------|-----------------|-----------------|-------|
| **Cayman Gateway** | ✅ Yes | ❌ Custom | Quote-based | Only local option for CI bank settlement |
| **Shopify Payments** | ❌ No (US account needed) | ✅ Native | 2.4-2.9% + $0.30 | Not available in Cayman Islands |
| **PayPal** | ❌ US/intl account | ✅ Native on Shopify | 2.9% + $0.30 | Works but funds go to PayPal balance, not CI bank |
| **Stripe** | ❌ Not in Cayman | ✅ Native on Shopify | 2.9% + $0.30 | **Stripe does not support Cayman Islands** merchants directly |
| **Square** | ❌ Not in Cayman | ⚠️ Limited | 2.6% + $0.10 | No Cayman presence |
| **WorldPay (FIS)** | ⚠️ Possible | ✅ Via integration | Varies | Enterprise-focused, may work but complex onboarding |
| **Payoneer** | ❌ | ❌ | 1-3% | Better for B2B/freelancer, not e-commerce checkout |

### Key Insight:
**Cayman Gateway is essentially the only option if you want funds settling directly to a Cayman Islands bank account.** This is their core value proposition. Alternatives like PayPal or Stripe would require funds to route through US or international accounts first, adding complexity, FX costs, and potential compliance issues.

### Hybrid Approach (Possible):
- **Cayman Gateway** for primary card processing (settles to CI bank)
- **PayPal** as an additional checkout option (for customer preference)
- Both can coexist on a Shopify checkout

---

## Recommended Action Plan for Dwayne

1. **Contact Cayman Gateway today:**
   - WhatsApp: +1 (345) 322-8327
   - Email: sales@caymangateway.com
   - Submit: [caymangateway.com/onboarding-enquiries](https://caymangateway.com/onboarding-enquiries)
   - Ask specifically about: Shopify integration, API docs, pricing, timeline

2. **Confirm 7 Cellars has a Cayman merchant bank account** (or Cayman Gateway can help set one up)

3. **Ask Cayman Gateway these questions:**
   - "Do you have a Shopify app or plugin?"
   - "Can you provide API documentation for custom Shopify integration?"
   - "What are your per-transaction fees and monthly costs?"
   - "Do you support USD and KYD processing?"
   - "What's the typical onboarding timeline?"

4. **Once pricing is confirmed**, evaluate whether to use Cayman Gateway alone or hybrid (CG + PayPal)

5. **Cin7 integration** can follow — use Shopify as the bridge layer

---

## Sources
- [caymangateway.com](https://caymangateway.com) — Homepage, About, How It Works, Contact, Onboarding
- [payatlas.com/countries/cayman-islands-ky](https://payatlas.com/countries/cayman-islands-ky) — Cayman e-commerce market overview
- [help.shopify.com/en/manual/payments/third-party-providers](https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/payments/third-party-providers) — Shopify third-party payment docs
- [investors.directory](https://investors.directory/top-5-psps-payment-service-providers-in-cayman-islands/) — PSP comparison for Cayman

## Confidence Level
**Medium-High** — Company details are well-sourced from their website. Integration specifics (Shopify, Cin7) are inferred since Cayman Gateway doesn't publish technical documentation publicly. Fees unknown until quoted. The biggest unknown is whether they already have a Shopify integration ready.

files.name: Cayman Wine Markup Research
files.content:
# Cayman Islands Wine Markup Research
**Prepared for:** 7 Cellars / Dwayne Schofield
**Date:** February 9, 2026
**Researcher:** Reece (Research Agent)

---

## TL;DR

**Rule of thumb: US retail × 1.8–2.2 = Cayman retail price (in USD)**

For quick pricing, multiply US retail by **2.0× for wines under $30 US** and **1.5–1.7× for wines over $50 US**. The markup percentage decreases as wine price increases because duty is per-litre (fixed), not ad valorem.

---

## 1. Cayman Islands Import Duty Rates

Source: Customs Tariff Act (2026 Revision), CBC Gov.ky

Duty is charged **per litre**, not as a percentage of value. This is critical — it means cheap wines get hit proportionally harder than expensive ones.

| Category | Duty Rate (KYD per litre) | Per 750ml Bottle |
|----------|--------------------------|------------------|
| **Table Wine** (red/white/rosé, still) | $3.30/L | ~$2.48 |
| **Sparkling Wine / Champagne** | $7.50–$10.50/L | ~$5.63–$7.88 |
| **Spirits** (≤50% ABV) | $11.55/L | ~$8.66 |
| **Spirits** (>50% ABV) | $15.68/L | ~$11.76 |
| **Beer** | ~$1.50–$2.50/L | varies by format |

**Key insight:** No sales tax, no VAT, no income tax in Cayman. Import duty is the **only** government charge. This is actually favorable compared to many US states that layer excise tax + sales tax.

### Personal Allowances (travelers)
- 1 litre of spirits OR 2 litres of wine duty-free
- Anything above must be declared and duty paid

---

## 2. Freight / Shipping Costs to Cayman

Estimated costs for commercial wine shipments (container/LCL from Miami or US East Coast):

| Method | Cost per Case (12 bottles) | Per Bottle |
|--------|---------------------------|------------|
| **Ocean freight (FCL container)** | $8–$15/case | $0.67–$1.25 |
| **Ocean freight (LCL/consolidated)** | $15–$25/case | $1.25–$2.08 |
| **Air freight** | $35–$60/case | $2.92–$5.00 |
| **Small parcel (FedEx/DHL)** | $60–$100/case | $5.00–$8.33 |

**Notes:**
- Most commercial importers use ocean freight from Miami (closest major port)
- Temperature-controlled containers add ~20–30% premium
- Customs brokerage fees: ~$50–$150 per shipment (amortized across cases)
- Port handling/package tax: additional ~$0.50–$1.00 per case

**Realistic all-in freight cost: ~$2–3 per bottle** for a commercial importer doing regular container shipments from Miami.

---

## 3. Price Comparison: US Retail vs. Cayman Retail

Prices from Jacques Scott (Cayman's largest retailer) vs. Total Wine / US average retail. KYD converted to USD at 1 KYD = $1.20 USD.

| Wine | US Retail (USD) | Jacques Scott (KYD) | Jacques Scott (USD) | Markup % |
|------|----------------|--------------------|--------------------|----------|
| **19 Crimes Cabernet Sauvignon** | $9.99 | $18.99 | $22.79 | **128%** |
| **19 Crimes Red Blend** | $9.99 | $18.99 | $22.79 | **128%** |
| **19 Crimes Pinot Noir** | $9.99 | $18.99 | $22.79 | **128%** |
| **Oyster Bay Pinot Grigio** | $12.99 | $20.99 | $25.19 | **94%** |
| **Oyster Bay Rosé** | $14.99 | $21.99 | $26.39 | **76%** |
| **Whispering Angel Rosé** | $22.99 | $30.99 | $37.19 | **62%** |
| **Frank Family Chardonnay** | $42.99 | $54.00 | $64.80 | **51%** |
| **Ridge Lytton Springs Zinfandel** | $44.99 | $57.00 | $68.40 | **52%** |
| **Rombauer Cabernet Sauvignon** | $74.99 | $94.00 | $112.80 | **50%** |

### Pattern Analysis

| US Price Range | Average Markup over US Retail | Multiplier |
|---------------|------------------------------|------------|
| **Under $15 US** | 90–130% | **~2.0–2.3×** |
| **$15–$30 US** | 60–80% | **~1.6–1.8×** |
| **$30–$50 US** | 50–55% | **~1.5–1.6×** |
| **$50+ US** | 45–55% | **~1.5×** |

**Why the sliding scale?** Import duty is a flat ~$2.48/bottle regardless of wine price. On a $10 wine, that's 25% just in duty. On a $75 wine, it's only 3%. Freight costs are also fixed per bottle.

---

## 4. Cost Buildup Analysis

Here's how a $20 US retail wine becomes ~$36–40 in Cayman:

| Component | Amount (USD) |
|-----------|-------------|
| Wholesale cost (US wholesale ~60% of retail) | $12.00 |
| Import duty ($3.30 KYD/L = ~$2.98 USD per bottle) | $2.98 |
| Freight to Cayman (per bottle) | $2.00 |
| Customs brokerage & handling | $0.50 |
| **Landed cost** | **$17.48** |
| Retail margin (50–60%) | $17.48–$26.22 |
| **Cayman retail price** | **$34.96–$43.70** |

Retailers typically work on **50–65% gross margin** (markup of 100–185% on landed cost).

---

## 5. Duty-Free & Tax Advantages

**Cayman has NO:**
- Income tax
- Sales tax / VAT
- Capital gains tax
- Withholding tax

**The only charge is import duty** — which for wine is $3.30 KYD/litre (~$2.98 USD per 750ml bottle). This is actually **lower** than many US states' combined excise + sales tax burden.

**For 7 Cellars specifically:**
- As a licensed liquor retailer/distributor, you pay duty on import
- No additional taxes on retail sales
- No licensing-related percentage taxes
- Bonded warehouse option available (defer duty until goods are released for sale)

---

## 6. Recommended Markup Formula for 7 Cellars

### Simple Multiplier Method (Quick Pricing)

| US Retail Price | Multiply By | Example |
|----------------|-------------|---------|
| Under $15 | **× 2.0** | $12 US → $24 KYD ($20 KYD) |
| $15–$30 | **× 1.75** | $25 US → $43.75 KYD ($36.46 KYD) |
| $30–$50 | **× 1.55** | $40 US → $62 KYD ($51.67 KYD) |
| $50–$100 | **× 1.50** | $75 US → $112.50 KYD ($93.75 KYD) |
| $100+ | **× 1.40** | $150 US → $210 KYD ($175 KYD) |

> **Note:** Results above are in USD. Divide by 1.20 to get KYD, or simply price in KYD at these USD-equivalent levels since Jacques Scott prices in KYD.

### More Precise Cost-Plus Method

For exact pricing when you know your landed cost:

```
Cayman Retail = (Wholesale Cost + Duty + Freight + Handling) × 2.0 to 2.5
```

Where:
- **Wholesale cost** = your buy price from supplier
- **Duty** = $3.30 KYD per litre ($2.48 KYD per 750ml bottle)
- **Freight** = ~$1.50–$2.50 KYD per bottle (container from Miami)
- **Handling** = ~$0.50 KYD per bottle (brokerage, port fees)

### Competitive Positioning

Jacques Scott is the market leader with 6 locations. To compete:
- **Match or undercut by 5–10%** on popular wines to build traffic
- **Premium wines ($50+)**: match Jacques Scott — customers expect consistent pricing
- **Value wines (under $20 KYD)**: this is where you can win on price with lower overhead

---

## 7. Summary: Rule of Thumb

> ### 🍷 **US Retail × 1.75 = Cayman Retail (in USD)**
>
> This is the single best middle-ground multiplier. It works for wines in the $15–$50 range, which is the bulk of retail wine sales.
>
> For budget wines (under $15 US): use **× 2.0**
> For premium wines (over $50 US): use **× 1.5**

### Quick Reference Card

| If US retail is... | 7 Cellars KYD price should be ~... |
|--------------------|------------------------------------|
| $10 | $16–$17 KYD |
| $15 | $22–$24 KYD |
| $20 | $29–$32 KYD |
| $25 | $35–$38 KYD |
| $30 | $40–$44 KYD |
| $40 | $52–$56 KYD |
| $50 | $63–$67 KYD |
| $75 | $90–$95 KYD |
| $100 | $115–$125 KYD |

---

## Confidence Level: **Medium-High**

- Duty rates: **High confidence** — sourced from 2026 Customs Tariff Act
- Freight costs: **Medium** — estimated from industry norms for Caribbean shipping; actual costs depend on 7 Cellars' shipping arrangements
- Price comparisons: **High confidence** — live prices from Jacques Scott website (Feb 2026) vs. Total Wine US prices
- Markup formula: **Medium-High** — derived from actual price comparisons; may vary by supplier relationships

## Sources

1. Cayman Islands Customs Tariff Act (2026 Revision) — gov.ky
2. Jacques Scott Online (jacquesscott.com) — live prices, Feb 9, 2026
3. Total Wine & More (totalwine.com) — US retail prices
4. Wine-Searcher.com — global average prices
5. Google AI Overview — Cayman customs duty rate summary
6. Cayman Islands Customs & Border Control (CBC) — gov.ky/web/cbc
7. The Customs Tariff (Amendment) Bill, 2009 — parliament.ky

files.name: Charcuterie Cheese Research
files.content:
# Premium Charcuterie, Cheese & Specialty Food Import Research

## A Comprehensive Guide for 7 Cellars

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 9, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, 7 Cellars

---

## TL;DR

Grand Cayman has **zero dedicated Italian/French specialty food importers** — a massive gap in a market with ~80,000 residents, 2M+ annual tourists, and one of the world's highest GDP per capita (~$100K+). 7 Cellars can launch a premium charcuterie, cheese, and pantry program with virtually no new infrastructure: Phase 1 products are entirely shelf-stable and ship ambient in existing wine containers. Start with 10–15 hero SKUs (Parmigiano Reggiano, Prosciutto di Parma, truffle honey, Laudemio EVOO, aged balsamic) via an aggregator like Gustiamo, then go direct to producers as volume grows. Expected Year 1 gross profit: **CI$67,000–176,000** at 80% blended margin, with yacht provisioning alone worth CI$50–100K+ once established. Every wine sale becomes a food upsell — and vice versa.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Market Opportunity & Competitor Analysis](#1-market-opportunity--competitor-analysis)
2. [Aged Cheeses](#2-aged-cheeses)
3. [Whole Cured Meats](#3-whole-cured-meats)
4. [Truffle Products](#4-truffle-products)
5. [Premium Olive Oils](#5-premium-olive-oils)
6. [Specialty Pantry Items](#6-specialty-pantry-items)
7. [Phase 2: Fresh/Cold Chain Products](#7-phase-2-freshcold-chain-products)
8. [Supplier & Producer Recommendations](#8-supplier--producer-recommendations)
9. [Logistics & Import Considerations](#9-logistics--import-considerations)
10. [Margin Analysis](#10-margin-analysis)
11. [Pairing Strategy & Cross-Selling](#11-pairing-strategy--cross-selling)
12. [Gift Box Concepts](#12-gift-box-concepts)
13. [Events, Experiences & Yacht Provisioning](#13-events-experiences--yacht-provisioning)
14. [Recommended Action Plan](#14-recommended-action-plan)
15. [Summary & Recommendations](#15-summary--recommendations)

---

## 1. Market Opportunity & Competitor Analysis

Grand Cayman has ~80,000 residents plus ~2 million tourists annually, with one of the highest GDP per capita globally. The demand for premium European food products is real — upscale restaurants currently source through general distributors or ad-hoc imports.

**No competitor is doing dedicated Italian/French specialty food importing.** This is a wide-open market.

### Competitor Landscape

| Competitor | Primary Business | Food Offering | Gap for 7 Cellars |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Jacques Scott** | Wine & spirits (2,200+ SKUs) | Gift baskets only — no standalone food | Zero Italian/French specialty food focus |
| **The Tasting Room** | Wine retail + hospitality venues | Food as accessory to wine, not standalone | Could be a *customer* for 7 Cellars food |
| **Tortuga** | Rum cakes, distillery, liquor | Mass-market tourist snacks | Completely different segment |
| **Blackbeard's** | Liquor store chain | None | Not a competitor in this space |

### Target Customer Segments

**B2B (Primary):**
Ritz-Carlton, Kimpton Seafire, Luca, The Brasserie, Agua, Blue by Eric Ripert, Kaibo, Abacus, Ristorante Pappagallo.

**B2C (High-Net-Worth):**
Seven Mile Beach, South Sound, Rum Point estates — frequent entertainers who want premium European ingredients at home.

**Corporate/Events:**
Law firms and hedge funds hosting client dinners. Real estate closing gifts. Curated wine + food gift boxes for holidays.

---

## PHASE 1 PRODUCTS: SHELF-STABLE

All Phase 1 products require no cold chain, have 12–36 month shelf lives, and fit in a 40-foot container alongside wine cases. Ship ambient (15–25°C).

---

## 2. Aged Cheeses

Hard aged cheeses are the anchor category — shelf-stable, high-margin, and essential for every restaurant and entertaining household on the island. Whole wheels for restaurant supply; vacuum-sealed wedges (200g, 500g, 1kg) for retail.

**Region Focus:** Emilia-Romagna, Tuscany, Jura (France), Netherlands

| Product | Producer | Region | Price Range | Shelf Life | Pairing Notes |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Parmigiano Reggiano DOP 24-mo** | Caseificio Hombre, 4 Madonne | Emilia-Romagna | €8–12/kg | 18–24 months | Anchor product — restaurants & retail |
| **Parmigiano Reggiano 36-mo** | Bertinelli, Giorgio Cravero | Emilia-Romagna | €14–18/kg | 24+ months | Crystalline, umami-rich — premium tier |
| **Pecorino Romano DOP** | Brunelli, Fulvi | Lazio/Sardinia | €8–11/kg | 12–18 months | Staple for Italian restaurants |
| **Pecorino Toscano Stagionato** | Il Forteto, Busti | Tuscany | €10–14/kg | 12+ months | Pairs with Brunello (Caparzo, ColleMassari) |
| **Grana Padano DOP** | Zanetti, Ambrosi | Po Valley | €6–9/kg | 18–24 months | More accessible price point than Parmigiano |
| **Aged Gouda (18–36 mo)** | Reypenaer, L'Amuse | Netherlands | €12–18/kg | 24+ months | Exceptional shelf-stable cheese |
| **Comté AOP (18+ months)** | Marcel Petite (Fort Saint Antoine) | Jura, France | €14–20/kg | 18+ months | Pairs with Burgundy (Marchand-Tawse) |
| **Mimolette Extra-Vieille** | Isigny Sainte-Mère | Normandy | €12–16/kg | 18+ months | Distinctive, eye-catching, great shelf appeal |

**Shipping note:** Vacuum-sealed hard cheese ships perfectly at ambient temperature for the ~14–21 day transit from Italy to Cayman.

---

## 3. Whole Cured Meats

Whole cured meats are the second anchor category — flagship products like prosciutto legs sell to restaurants and can be sliced-to-order at retail. All ship ambient when vacuum-sealed.

**Region Focus:** Emilia-Romagna, Friuli, Lombardy, Tuscany, Calabria, France

| Product | Producer | Region | Price Range | Shelf Life | Pairing Notes |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Prosciutto di Parma DOP** | Ruliano, Galloni | Emilia-Romagna | €12–18/kg | 12–18 months | Flagship — restaurants & slice-to-order retail |
| **Prosciutto di San Daniele DOP** | Prolongo, DOK Dall'Ava | Friuli | €14–20/kg | 12–18 months | Sweeter, more refined than Parma |
| **Culatello di Zibello DOP** | Antica Corte Pallavicina (Spigaroli) | Emilia-Romagna | €35–50/kg | 12+ months | "King of salumi" — ultra-premium gift product |
| **Bresaola della Valtellina IGP** | Rigamonti, Pini | Lombardy | €18–25/kg | 6–9 months | Lean, elegant — pairs with Barolo (Massolino) |
| **Salame Felino IGP** | Tanara, Villani | Emilia-Romagna | €10–15/kg | 6–12 months | Classic table salami |
| **Finocchiona IGP** | Savigni, Macelleria Falorni | Tuscany | €12–16/kg | 6–12 months | Fennel salami — pairs with Chianti (Brancaia) |
| **'Nduja di Spilinga** | Nduja Artisans, Ndujeria Cascella | Calabria | €15–20/kg | 12+ months | Spreadable, spicy — also available jarred |
| **Saucisson Sec** | Maison Loste, Justin Bridou | France | €15–22/kg | 6–12 months | French addition — pairs with Burgundy |

**Import note:** Cayman Islands follow USDA-aligned import rules but also accept EU-certified products as a British Overseas Territory. Confirm with Department of Agriculture that Italian/EU health certificates are accepted.

---

## 4. Truffle Products

Shelf-stable truffle products (24+ months) are high-margin, gift-friendly, and create powerful cross-selling opportunities with aged cheeses and wines.

**Region Focus:** Umbria, Piedmont, Tuscany

| Product | Producer | Region | Price Range | Shelf Life | Pairing Notes |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Black truffle paste/sauce** | Urbani Tartufi, Savini Tartufi, Tartuflanghe | Umbria/Tuscany | €8–15 / 90–180g jar | 24+ months | Versatile — pasta, bruschetta, risotto |
| **Truffle honey** | Urbani, Mieli Thun | Umbria/Trentino | €6–10 / 120g jar | 24+ months | Incredible with aged cheese — perfect cross-sell |
| **Truffle oil (white/black)** | Urbani Tartufi, Sabatino Tartufi | Umbria | €8–15 / 250ml | 24+ months | Use real truffle infusion, not synthetic |
| **Truffle salt** | Tartuflanghe, Savini | Piedmont/Tuscany | €5–8 / 100g | 24+ months | Gift-friendly, great impulse buy |
| **Whole preserved truffles (jarred)** | Urbani Tartufi | Umbria | €20–40 / 25–50g jar | 24+ months | Premium tier for restaurants & serious cooks |
| **Truffle butter (shelf-stable)** | Urbani | Umbria | €10–15 / 80g | 24+ months | Cross-sells with steak, pasta |

**Key supplier:** Urbani Tartufi (Scheggino, Umbria) — world's largest truffle company, full export program, US distribution arm, experienced with Caribbean logistics.
Contact: export@urbanitartufi.it · urbanitartufi.com

---

## 5. Premium Olive Oils

Extra virgin olive oil is a daily-use staple with strong gifting potential. Best within 18 months of harvest — plan orders around the November–January harvest season for freshest product arriving by March/April.

**Region Focus:** Tuscany, Puglia, Liguria, Sicily, Provence

| Product | Producer | Region | Price Range | Shelf Life | Pairing Notes |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **EVOO — Tuscan blend** | Laudemio (consortium) | Tuscany | €12–18 / 500ml | 18 months | Gold standard — some wine producers also make oil |
| **EVOO — Monocultivar Coratina** | Galantino | Puglia | €8–14 / 500ml | 18 months | Robust, peppery — great for restaurants |
| **EVOO — Ligurian Taggiasca** | Roi, Anfosso | Liguria | €10–16 / 500ml | 18 months | Delicate, buttery — premium positioning |
| **EVOO — Sicilian Nocellara** | Ferraro, Ravida | Sicily | €8–14 / 500ml | 18 months | Beautiful bottles, great for gifting |
| **Huile d'Olive — Provence** | Château d'Estoublon, Domaine Salvator | Provence, France | €12–20 / 500ml | 18 months | French partner line |

---

## 6. Specialty Pantry Items

The pantry category rounds out the offering — balsamic, pasta, crackers, olives, and condiments complete both the restaurant supply line and the gift box program.

**Region Focus:** Modena, Abruzzo, Puglia, Calabria, Camargue

| Product | Producer | Region | Price Range | Shelf Life | Pairing Notes |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Balsamic (IGP, 6–12 yr)** | Acetaia Leonardi, Giuseppe Giusti, Acetaia Malpighi | Modena | €6–15 / 250ml | 5–10+ years | Aged — drizzle on Parmigiano |
| **Balsamic Tradizionale DOP (25+ yr)** | Same producers | Modena | €80–150 / 100ml | Indefinite | Ultra-premium — gift & tasting item |
| **Premium Pasta (bronze-die)** | Felicetti, Rustichella d'Abruzzo, Pasta Mancini, Martelli | Abruzzo/Tuscany | €2–5 / 500g | 24–36 months | Foundation pantry item |
| **Grissini & Breadsticks** | Mario Fongo | Piedmont | €3–6 / pack | 9–12 months | Essential for cheese boards |
| **Taralli** | Fratelli Ferrara, Fiore di Puglia | Puglia | €3–6 / pack | 9–12 months | Snacking, aperitivo |
| **Castelvetrano Olives & Antipasti** | Ferrara, Frantoi Cutrera | Sicily | €4–8 / jar | 18–24 months | Charcuterie board essential |
| **Mostarda** | Luccini, Boschetto | Cremona | €6–10 / jar | 18–24 months | Classic pairing with aged cheese |
| **Italian Tuna Ventresca** | Callipo, Flott, Tonnino | Calabria | €6–12 / jar or tin | 24–36 months | Premium pantry staple |
| **Bomba Calabrese / Chili Paste** | Tutto Calabria, Calabria Food | Calabria | €4–8 / jar | 18–24 months | Trending condiment |
| **Sea Salt / Fleur de Sel** | Le Saunier de Camargue, Ferrara (Trapani) | France/Sicily | €4–8 / pack | Indefinite | Finishing salt — gift & culinary |

---

## 7. Phase 2: Fresh/Cold Chain Products

**Timeline:** 12–18 months after Phase 1 proves the market.
**Requires:** Refrigerated storage and reefer container capacity.

### Soft & Semi-Soft Cheeses

- **Burrata** (24–48 hr shelf life, air freight) — Caputo, Andriese
- **Fresh Mozzarella di Bufala DOP** — Vannulo, Caseificio La Baronia
- **Taleggio DOP** — Mauri, Arrigoni
- **Gorgonzola DOP (Dolce & Piccante)** — Igor, Latteria Soresina
- **Époisses, Brie de Meaux, Reblochon** — French soft cheese program

### Fresh Charcuterie

- **Mortadella Bologna IGP** — Felsineo, Alcisa
- **Fresh sausages (salsiccia fresca)** — Regional Italian
- **Pâté and terrines** — Maison Dubernet, Rougié
- **Foie gras** — Rougié, Lafitte — huge luxury market potential in Cayman

### Other Fresh Items

- **Fresh pasta** (ravioli, tortellini) — air freight required
- **Italian gelato bases** — pre-made mixes for restaurants
- **Pre-sliced charcuterie** — prosciutto, coppa, board-ready

---

## 8. Supplier & Producer Recommendations

### Tier 1: Full-Service Exporters (Simplest Route)

Aggregators who source from dozens of producers and handle export documentation, consolidation, and shipping. Ideal for first orders.

| Company | Specialty | Contact | Why They Fit |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Eataly Distribution** | Premium Italian food aggregator | distribution@eataly.it | World-class curation, brand recognition |
| **Valsana** | Specialty cheese & charcuterie | valsana.it | Huge artisan producer portfolio |
| **Longino & Cardenal** | Ultra-premium food sourcing (Milan) | longino.it | White-glove service, luxury market expertise |
| **Esperya / Gustiamo** | Italian artisan food export to Americas | gustiamo.com | Already handle US/Caribbean distribution |

### Tier 2: Direct from Producers (Higher Margins)

Once relationships are established, go direct for key products:

**Italian:**
- **Urbani Tartufi** (truffles) — urbanitartufi.com
- **Consorzio Parmigiano Reggiano** — parmigianoreggiano.com
- **Acetaia Giuseppe Giusti** (balsamic, est. 1605) — giusti.it
- **Rustichella d'Abruzzo** (pasta) — rustichella.it
- **Ruliano** (prosciutto) — one of Parma's finest

**French:**
- **Marcel Petite** (Comté) — marcel-petite.com
- **Isigny Sainte-Mère** (butter, cream, Mimolette) — isigny-ste-mere.com
- **Rougié** (foie gras, pâté — Phase 2) — rougie.com
- **Le Saunier de Camargue** (fleur de sel) — saunierdecamargue.com

### Tier 3: Multi-Category Distributors

- **Italfoods** (UK-based, handles Italy → Caribbean)
- **AG Ferrari Foods** — already distributes Italian specialty foods in the Americas

### MOQ Expectations

| Route | Minimum Order | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Through aggregators | Mixed pallets; ~€3,000–5,000 | Best for initial testing |
| Direct from producers | €1,000–3,000 per producer per SKU | Full pallet minimums |
| Container economics | 2–4 pallets per shipment | €6,000–20,000 in food cost |

---

## 9. Logistics & Import Considerations

### Shipping Food Alongside Wine

Phase 1 products ship ambient (15–25°C) — the same conditions as wine. This is the key insight that makes the food program nearly free from a logistics standpoint.

| Parameter | Requirement |
|---|---|
| **Temperature** | Ambient (15–25°C), climate-monitored |
| **Separation** | Palletize food separately for customs inspection |
| **Capacity** | 1 pallet = ~400–500kg cheese or ~30–40 prosciutto legs |
| **Transit time** | Italy → Cayman: 18–25 days via US Gulf or Kingston transship |

### Cayman Islands Import Requirements

| Requirement | Details |
|---|---|
| **Import permit** | Department of Agriculture (DoA) — apply 7+ days before arrival |
| **Health certificates** | EU health/veterinary certificates for meat and dairy (Italian ASL) |
| **Labeling** | English labels: ingredients, allergens, net weight, country of origin |
| **Customs duty** | 22% on food imports (general rate) |
| **USDA requirement** | None — Cayman accepts EU certificates directly (advantage over US) |
| **Phytosanitary** | Required for plant-based; olive oil and dry pasta generally exempt |

### Shelf Life & Reorder Planning

| Category | Shelf Life | Reorder Frequency |
|---|---|---|
| Hard cheeses (vacuum-sealed) | 18–24 months | Every 3–6 months |
| Cured meats (vacuum-sealed) | 12–18 months | Every 3–4 months |
| Truffle products (jarred) | 24–36 months | Every 6 months |
| Olive oil | 18 months from harvest | Annually (post-harvest) |
| Balsamic vinegar | 5–10+ years | Annually |
| Dry pasta | 24–36 months | Every 6 months |
| Crackers/breadsticks | 9–12 months | Every 3–4 months |

---

## 10. Margin Analysis

### Markup Structure (Caribbean Specialty Foods)

| Channel | Typical Markup | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Wholesale to restaurants/hotels | 30–50% | Volume accounts, consistent reorders |
| Direct retail (B2C) | 80–150% | Premium positioning justifies high margins |
| Gift boxes/curated sets | 100–200% | Value-added curation; highest margin |
| Tasting events | 200–400% | Per-person pricing with wine pairings |

### Cost Buildup Example: Parmigiano Reggiano 24-month

| Component | Per kg |
|---|---|
| Producer cost (Italy) | €10.00 |
| Export handling & documentation | €0.50 |
| Ocean freight (allocated) | €0.80 |
| Cayman customs duty (22%) | €2.49 |
| Local handling & storage | €0.50 |
| **Total landed cost** | **€14.29 (~CI$14.50 / US$17.50)** |
| **Retail price (100% markup)** | **CI$29 / US$35 per kg** |
| **Restaurant wholesale (40% markup)** | **CI$20 / US$24.50 per kg** |

**Benchmark:** Foster's Food Fair sells Parmigiano at ~CI$30–40/kg. 7 Cellars would be competitive with healthy margins on direct-sourced product.

### Projected Revenue (Conservative Year 1)

- 2–4 food pallets × 6 containers/year = 12–24 pallets
- Average food cost per pallet: €3,000–4,000
- Total food investment: €36,000–96,000 (~CI$37,000–98,000)
- **At 80% blended margin: CI$67,000–176,000 gross profit**
- Upside: Restaurant reorder volumes could significantly increase by Year 2

---

## 11. Pairing Strategy & Cross-Selling

The wine business becomes the gateway to food sales and vice versa. This is 7 Cellars' true differentiator.

### Curated Wine + Food Pairings

| Wine | Food Pairing | Occasion |
|---|---|---|
| **Foss Marai Prosecco** | Prosciutto di Parma, Parmigiano, grissini | Aperitivo set |
| **Caparzo Brunello** | Pecorino Toscano, finocchiona, truffle honey | Tuscan dinner experience |
| **ColleMassari Montecucco Riserva** | Bresaola, 36-mo Parmigiano, Laudemio oil | Premium red pairing |
| **Brancaia Chianti Classico** | Salame Felino, sundried tomatoes, taralli | Classic Chianti board |
| **Massolino Barolo** | Culatello di Zibello, truffle paste, aged Comté | Ultra-premium pairing |
| **Gimonnet Champagne** | Comté 18-month, saucisson sec, cornichons | French celebration |
| **Marchand-Tawse Burgundy** | Comté, Époisses (Phase 2), Dijon mustard | Burgundy board |
| **Domaine Montrose Rosé** | Taleggio (Phase 2), prosciutto, olives | Summer rosé board |

---

## 12. Gift Box Concepts

| Box Name | Contents | Target Price (CI$) | Margin |
|---|---|---|---|
| **"The Italian Aperitivo"** | Foss Marai Prosecco + Prosciutto (200g) + Parmigiano (200g) + grissini + olives | $85–95 | ~150% |
| **"Tuscan Evening"** | Brancaia Chianti + Pecorino Toscano + finocchiona + truffle honey + Laudemio oil | $120–140 | ~120% |
| **"The Grand Cayman Collection"** | Massolino Barolo + Culatello + 36-mo Parmigiano + truffle paste + aged balsamic | $200–250 | ~130% |
| **"French Connection"** | Gimonnet Champagne + Comté + saucisson sec + fleur de sel + cornichons | $130–150 | ~120% |
| **"The Essentials Pantry"** | No wine — Parmigiano + olive oil + balsamic + truffle salt + pasta + sea salt | $95–110 | ~150% |

---

## 13. Events, Experiences & Yacht Provisioning

### Events & Experiences

- **Monthly wine + cheese tastings** — $75–125/person, 20–30 guests, at retail location or partner venues
- **Private "Italian Table" dinners** — chef-prepared meals for corporate clients featuring 7 Cellars wines + food
- **Restaurant launch events** — staff tastings when onboarding new restaurant accounts
- **Real estate closing gifts** — partner with luxury realtors for branded gift boxes (common in Cayman)

### Yacht & Villa Provisioning

Grand Cayman is a major superyacht destination. Yacht chefs need consistent premium Italian ingredients. 7 Cellars as the go-to provisioner for:

- Whole prosciutto legs
- Wheels of Parmigiano
- Premium olive oils and truffle products
- Full wine + food packages for charter trips

**Revenue potential:** CI$50,000–100,000+ annually once established, with premium pricing for expedited delivery.

---

## 14. Recommended Action Plan

### Month 1–2: Foundation

- [ ] Contact Gustiamo or Valsana for initial mixed-pallet trial order
- [ ] Apply for Cayman DoA food import permit
- [ ] Select 10–15 hero SKUs for Phase 1 launch
- [ ] Design branding/packaging for gift boxes

### Month 3–4: First Shipment

- [ ] Include 2 pallets of food in next Italy container
- [ ] Approach 3–5 top restaurants (The Brasserie, Luca, Agua, Pappagallo) with samples
- [ ] Set up retail display at 7 Cellars location
- [ ] Launch first gift box collection

### Month 5–8: Growth

- [ ] Expand to 4 pallets per container based on demand
- [ ] Add French products via France shipments
- [ ] Host first wine + cheese tasting event
- [ ] Develop yacht provisioning channel

### Month 9–12: Scale

- [ ] Go direct to top-performing producers (cut out aggregator for key SKUs)
- [ ] Begin planning Phase 2 (cold chain infrastructure)
- [ ] Target CI$100K+ in food revenue for Year 1

---

## 15. Summary & Recommendations

### Key Findings

1. **Massive competitive gap** — No competitor on Grand Cayman is importing dedicated Italian/French specialty foods
2. **Perfect logistics fit** — Phase 1 products are shelf-stable and ship alongside wine in existing containers
3. **High margins** — 80–150% markup on retail, 100–200% on gift boxes
4. **Built-in cross-selling** — Every wine sale is a food upsell opportunity and vice versa
5. **Untapped channels** — Yacht provisioning alone could generate CI$50K–100K+ annually

### Top Priority Products (Phase 1 Heroes)

| # | Product | Why It's a Hero |
|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Parmigiano Reggiano 24-month** | Anchor — every restaurant needs it |
| 2 | **Prosciutto di Parma (whole leg)** | Flagship showpiece product |
| 3 | **Truffle honey** | Highest cross-sell with cheese |
| 4 | **Laudemio EVOO** | Gold-standard olive oil |
| 5 | **Giuseppe Giusti balsamic** | Oldest producer in the world — story sells |

### Recommended First Move

Contact **Gustiamo** (gustiamo.com) — they already handle US/Caribbean distribution and can ship a mixed trial pallet of 10–15 SKUs. This proves the concept with minimal risk before committing to container-scale orders.

### Confidence Assessment

| Area | Confidence | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Market opportunity | **High** | Gap is enormous and confirmed |
| Product selection | **High** | Proven categories with established export infrastructure |
| Pricing/MOQs | **Medium** | Requires direct supplier outreach to confirm |
| Logistics | **High** | Shipping ambient alongside wine is straightforward |

---

## Key Contacts

| Contact | Purpose | Details |
|---|---|---|
| **Gustiamo** | Aggregator (first order) | gustiamo.com |
| **Urbani Tartufi** | Truffle products | export@urbanitartufi.it |
| **Cayman DoA** | Food import permits | Apply 7+ days before arrival |
| **Giuseppe Giusti** | Balsamic (est. 1605) | giusti.it |
| **Valsana** | Cheese & charcuterie aggregator | valsana.it |

---

*Report prepared February 9, 2026. Prices and regulations subject to change.*
