files.name: Competitive Landscape Analysis
files.content:
# Cayman Islands Competitive Landscape Analysis

## TL;DR

We scraped **4,113 products with full pricing** from all four Cayman Islands beverage competitors. The findings reveal a highly fragmented market with clear white space for 7 Cellars.

- **The Tasting Room** is the luxury king — median wine price $219, ultra-premium Italian focus
- **Jacques Scott** is the volume king — 2,140 SKUs, broadest selection on-island
- **Tortuga** occupies the accessible middle — budget-friendly, tourist-oriented
- **Blackbeard's** is the smallest player — mainstream spirits, price-conscious shoppers
- Only **59 products** overlap across two or more competitors — the market is remarkably fragmented
- **7 Cellars sweet spot:** curated Italian wines $30–$100, premium rosé and sparkling, non-alcoholic beverages, and stealing ultra-premium Italian from Mario's at better prices

---

## Competitor Profiles

### The Tasting Room (Mario's Empire)

**Owner:** Mario (also owns Wine Bar, Mario's Restaurant, and The Goat)

Mario has built an integrated luxury hospitality empire on Grand Cayman. The Tasting Room serves as his retail wine shop, feeding directly into his restaurant and bar operations. This gives him a captive audience but also limits his need to compete on price — his customers are already dining with him.

| Metric | Value |
|---|---|
| **Total SKUs** | ~780 |
| **Primary Category** | Wine (overwhelmingly) |
| **Avg Wine Price** | $485 |
| **Median Wine Price** | $219 |
| **Price Range** | $18 – $12,000+ |
| **Platform** | Lightspeed |
| **Website** | thetastingroom.ky |

**Positioning:** Ultra-premium wine boutique for high-net-worth residents and fine dining guests. Heavy Italian and French focus with trophy wines (Sassicaia, Ornellaia, top Burgundy).

**Strengths:**
- Captive restaurant/bar ecosystem drives sales
- Deep ultra-premium Italian inventory (only source for Sassicaia on-island)
- Brand cachet among luxury buyers

**Weaknesses:**
- Extremely high price floor excludes mid-market buyers
- No real online shopping experience
- Vulnerable to competitors with direct Italian producer relationships offering better pricing
- Limited spirits selection

---

### Jacques Scott

**The dominant player on Grand Cayman by sheer volume.** Jacques Scott has been the island's go-to wine and spirits merchant for decades, with the broadest catalog and most established distribution relationships.

| Metric | Value |
|---|---|
| **Total SKUs** | ~2,140 |
| **Primary Categories** | Wine (~1,200), Spirits (~540), Beer & Cider (~250), Accessories (~150) |
| **Avg Wine Price** | $98 |
| **Median Wine Price** | $48 |
| **Price Range** | $8 – $3,500+ |
| **Platform** | WooCommerce |
| **Website** | jacquesscott.com |

**Positioning:** Full-service beverage retailer. Everything from $8 table wine to premium Champagne. The Costco of Cayman liquor — if you need it, they probably have it.

**Strengths:**
- Largest selection on-island by a wide margin
- Established B2B relationships with hotels and restaurants
- Full WooCommerce e-commerce with search and filtering
- Broadest spirits catalog (~540 SKUs)

**Weaknesses:**
- Breadth over depth — catalog is a mile wide, inch deep
- No curation or storytelling — products listed like a phone book
- Premium Italian wine selection is shallow despite volume
- Website UX is dated

---

### Tortuga

**Best known for rum cakes and the distillery tour,** Tortuga has expanded into a broader retail beverage operation targeting tourists and budget-conscious residents.

| Metric | Value |
|---|---|
| **Total SKUs** | ~650 |
| **Primary Categories** | Wine (~350), Spirits (~180), Beer (~70), Food/Gifts (~50) |
| **Avg Wine Price** | $61 |
| **Median Wine Price** | $43 |
| **Price Range** | $10 – $250 |
| **Platform** | Shopify |
| **Website** | tortuga.ky |

**Positioning:** Accessible, tourist-friendly beverage retail with strong rum heritage. The "easy choice" for visitors and casual shoppers.

**Strengths:**
- Strong tourist brand recognition (rum cakes are iconic)
- Most affordable wine selection on-island (55% under $30)
- Modern Shopify platform
- Food and gift items drive incremental traffic

**Weaknesses:**
- Perceived as tourist-oriented, not premium
- Very few wines above $100 (only 4%)
- Limited Italian selection beyond basics
- No sommelier credibility or wine expertise positioning

---

### Blackbeard's

**The smallest of the four competitors,** Blackbeard's operates as a straightforward liquor store focused on mainstream brands and competitive pricing. Owned by the Dart group.

| Metric | Value |
|---|---|
| **Total SKUs** | ~540 |
| **Primary Categories** | Spirits (~280), Wine (~160), Beer (~80), Mixers (~20) |
| **Avg Wine Price** | $83 |
| **Median Wine Price** | $44 |
| **Price Range** | $9 – $800 |
| **Platform** | Wix |
| **Website** | blackbeards.ky |

**Positioning:** No-frills liquor retail for everyday buyers. Strong spirits selection, basic wine offering. Think convenience and price over experience.

**Strengths:**
- Dart ownership provides financial stability and prime locations
- Competitive pricing on mainstream spirits
- Serves the "just need a bottle" everyday buyer well

**Weaknesses:**
- Smallest wine selection of all four competitors
- No wine expertise or curation
- Wix platform limits e-commerce capabilities
- No premium or luxury positioning whatsoever

> **Note:** Blackbeard's prices are originally listed in KYD. All figures in this report have been converted to USD at 1 KYD = 1.22 USD for consistent comparison.

---

## Pricing Intelligence

### Wine Pricing Comparison

| Competitor | Avg Price | Median Price | % Under $30 | % Over $100 |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **The Tasting Room** | $485 | $219 | 2% | 64% |
| **Jacques Scott** | $98 | $48 | 33% | 21% |
| **Blackbeard's** | $83 | $44 | 46% | 26% |
| **Tortuga** | $61 | $43 | 55% | 4% |

### What the Numbers Reveal

**The Tasting Room lives in a different universe.** With a median wine price of $219 and an average of $485 (skewed by trophy bottles), Mario's shop is pure luxury. Only 2% of his wines cost under $30 — this isn't a shop for everyday drinking.

**Jacques Scott and Blackbeard's cluster in the mid-market,** with medians of $48 and $44 respectively. Jacques Scott's higher average ($98 vs $83) reflects their deeper premium tail.

**Tortuga is the value play.** More than half their wines are under $30, and only 4% crack $100. This is tourist and everyday pricing.

**The gap between $43 (Tortuga median) and $219 (Tasting Room median) is massive.** There's a wide-open space in the **$30–$100 premium-but-accessible** range — exactly where 7 Cellars should live with curated Italian selections.

---

## Italian Wine Landscape — 7 Cellars Core

This is where it gets strategic. Italian wine is 7 Cellars' primary focus, and Roberto's expertise as a sommelier gives us credibility no competitor can match. Here's what's currently available on-island:

| Varietal / Region | Jacques Scott | Tasting Room | Tortuga | Blackbeard's |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Brunello** | 6 | 20 | 2 | — |
| **Barolo** | 21 | 10 | 1 | — |
| **Barbaresco** | 3 | 1 | 1 | — |
| **Chianti** | 12 | 11 | 8 | — |
| **Amarone** | 7 | 7 | 3 | — |
| **Sassicaia** | — | 6 | — | — |
| **Ornellaia** | 4 | 8 | — | — |
| **Prosecco** | 15 | 5 | 7 | 3 |

### Key Takeaways

**Sassicaia is exclusive to The Tasting Room** — Mario has the only six listings on-island. This is a brand that commands $200–$500+ per bottle. If 7 Cellars can source Sassicaia direct from Tenuta San Guido, we immediately challenge his monopoly on Italy's most iconic wine.

**Ornellaia is nearly exclusive to Mario** — only Jacques Scott has 4 listings vs. Mario's 8. Another direct-producer opportunity for 7 Cellars.

**Brunello is Mario's territory** — 20 listings vs. only 6 at Jacques Scott and 2 at Tortuga. With Roberto's Tuscan connections, 7 Cellars can bring curated Brunello at multiple price points ($40–$200) that neither competitor covers well.

**Barolo is Jacques Scott's strength** — 21 listings, more than any competitor. But volume doesn't mean curation. 7 Cellars can compete with story-driven selections from specific producers.

**Prosecco is everywhere but premium sparkling is nowhere.** 30 total Prosecco listings across all competitors, but zero Franciacorta or Trento DOC. This is a massive gap — Franciacorta is Italy's answer to Champagne, and nobody on the island carries it.

---

## Category Gap Analysis

### Rosé — Massively Underserved

| Competitor | Rosé SKUs | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| The Tasting Room | 9 | Premium but tiny selection |
| Tortuga | 31 | Budget-focused ($15–$30 range) |
| Jacques Scott | — | Negligible dedicated rosé |
| Blackbeard's | — | No rosé category |

Rosé consumption has exploded globally, especially in warm-weather luxury markets. Grand Cayman — a Caribbean island with wealthy residents and year-round sunshine — should be swimming in premium rosé. It isn't. **7 Cellars should own this category** with Provence rosé, Italian rosato, and premium sparkling rosé.

### Non-Alcoholic Beverages — Near Zero

The non-alcoholic and low-ABV category is the fastest-growing segment in global beverages. On Grand Cayman? Virtually non-existent across all four competitors. **This is a wide-open greenfield opportunity.** Premium non-alc wines (Oddbird, Leitz Eins Zwei Zero), non-alc spirits (Lyre's, Seedlip), and craft sodas could all find a home exclusively through 7 Cellars.

### Premium Mixers — Minimal Presence

Fever-Tree, Q Mixers, and craft tonic waters are barely represented. As cocktail culture grows on Grand Cayman — driven by upscale restaurants and private chefs — demand for premium mixers will follow. First-mover advantage is available.

### Franciacorta & Trento DOC Sparkling — Nobody

Zero listings across all competitors. These are Italy's finest sparkling wines — comparable to Champagne in quality, more interesting in character, and priced 30–50% below equivalent Champagne. With Foss Marai already in 7 Cellars' portfolio, this is a category we can own from day one.

### Gourmet Food & Pantry — Nearly Empty

Only The Tasting Room has ventured here, with just 3 food items. Premium olive oils, aged balsamic vinegar, artisanal pasta, Italian preserves — these complement wine sales perfectly and create basket-building opportunities. Roberto's Italian sourcing relationships extend naturally to food producers.

---

## Market Overlap Analysis

### The Fragmentation Surprise

| Overlap | Count |
|---|---|
| Products at 2+ competitors | 59 |
| Products at 3+ competitors | 1 |
| That one product | Santa Margherita Pinot Grigio |

Out of 4,113 total products scraped, only **59 appear at two or more competitors**. Only a single product — Santa Margherita Pinot Grigio — shows up at three or more stores.

### What This Means for 7 Cellars

**You don't need to undercut anyone on price.** The market isn't a price war — it's a portfolio war. Each competitor has carved out a distinct niche with minimal overlap. 7 Cellars doesn't need to compete head-to-head; it needs to **fill the gaps** with products nobody else carries.

This fragmentation also means **customers are likely shopping at multiple stores** to find what they want. A curated, well-positioned 7 Cellars catalog could consolidate those shopping trips — especially for Italian wine enthusiasts who currently split between Jacques Scott and The Tasting Room.

---

## Strategic Recommendations for 7 Cellars

### 1. Own Italian $30–$100

This is the sweet spot. The Tasting Room is too expensive for everyday Italian wine. Jacques Scott has breadth but no curation. Tortuga is too cheap to convey quality. **7 Cellars should be the definitive Italian wine destination in the $30–$100 range** — curated by Roberto, with producer stories, regional context, and sommelier recommendations baked into every selection.

### 2. Steal Premium Italian from Mario

Sassicaia (6 listings, Tasting Room exclusive), Ornellaia (8 at Tasting Room), and deep Brunello (20 at Tasting Room) — these are high-margin, prestige products. Through direct producer relationships in Italy, 7 Cellars can offer the same wines at better prices with a more compelling buying experience. Roberto's connections make this achievable.

### 3. Own Rosé + Sparkling

Franciacorta (nobody carries it), premium Provence rosé (massively underserved), and sparkling rosé represent an uncontested category. Foss Marai is already in the portfolio. Build around it with 15–20 rosé and sparkling selections to become Grand Cayman's rosé destination.

### 4. Own Non-Alc + Premium Mixers

Zero competition. Full stop. The non-alcoholic category is growing 25%+ annually globally, and nobody on Grand Cayman has moved into it. Premium mixers are equally neglected. Being first with a curated non-alc and mixer selection creates a category monopoly.

### 5. Skip Commodity Spirits

Jacques Scott has ~540 spirits SKUs. Blackbeard's is mainstream spirits-heavy. The commodity spirits market (Absolut, Bacardi, Jack Daniel's) is locked up. Don't compete here. Focus spirits efforts on craft and artisanal selections — as outlined in the separate Craft Spirits Portfolio Research — where gaps exist in Japanese whisky, mezcal, and premium amaro.

---

## Data Methodology

| Detail | Value |
|---|---|
| **Scrape Date** | February 11, 2026 |
| **Total Products** | 4,113 |
| **Sources** | thetastingroom.ky, jacquesscott.com, tortuga.ky, blackbeards.ky |
| **Platforms** | Lightspeed, WooCommerce, Shopify, Wix |
| **Currency** | All prices in USD |
| **Conversion** | Blackbeard's KYD prices converted at 1 KYD = 1.22 USD |
| **Full Dataset** | cayman-competitor-master.xlsx |

All data was collected via automated scraping of public-facing e-commerce catalogs. Prices reflect listed retail prices at time of scrape and may not include promotions or volume discounts. Category classifications were standardized across competitors for consistent comparison.

files.name: Competitor Price Analysis
files.content:
# Grand Cayman Wine & Spirits — Competitive Price & Margin Analysis
**Date:** February 11, 2026  
**Prepared for:** 7 Cellars — Roberto Logioia & Partners  
**Data Sources:** Jacques Scott, Blackbeard's, Tortuga Fine Wines & Spirits, Wine-Searcher (US avg prices), Total Wine  

---

## Executive Summary

This analysis compares **166 products** across Grand Cayman's three main retailers against **US retail prices**, estimating competitor landed costs and margins. The goal: identify where competitors are making fat margins (opportunities for 7 Cellars to undercut) and where margins are razor-thin (avoid price wars).

### Key Findings at a Glance

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Products analyzed | 166 (99% matched with US prices) |
| Avg Cayman markup vs US retail | **+18.4%** across all categories |
| Highest-margin category | **French Red Wine** (42.7% avg competitor margin) |
| Lowest-margin category | **Vermouth/Aperitif** (negative margins — loss leaders) |
| Biggest 7 Cellars opportunity | **Champagne & French/Italian Wine** — 30-50% margins for competitors |
| Categories to avoid price competition | **Vodka, Rum, Gin** — razor-thin margins due to brutal spirits duty |

---

## The Full Markup Chain: How Cayman Prices Are Built

### Understanding the Cost Stack

```
US Retail Price ($50.00 wine example)
    ↓ × 50% (importer buys at wholesale/FOB)
Importer Cost: $25.00
    + Shipping: $2.50/bottle
    + Insurance: $0.38 (1.5%)
    + Cayman Duty: $5.03 (CI$5.50/L for wine × 0.75L × 1.22 USD/KYD)
    ═══════════════════════
Landed Cost: $32.91
    + Retailer Markup: 40-80%
    ═══════════════════════
Cayman Retail: $46.07 - $59.24 (KYD $37.76 - $48.56)
```

### Duty Impact by Category (per 750ml bottle)

| Category | Duty Rate | Duty per Bottle (USD) | Impact on $20 US Retail | Impact on $100 US Retail |
|----------|-----------|----------------------|------------------------|-------------------------|
| Still Wine | CI$5.50/L | $5.03 | +25.2% | +5.0% |
| Sparkling/Champagne | CI$9.50/L | $8.69 | +43.5% | +8.7% |
| Spirits | CI$15.98/L | $14.62 | +73.1% | +14.6% |
| Food/Non-Alc | 22% ad valorem | varies | +22% | +22% |

**Key insight:** Specific (per-liter) duty on spirits is brutally regressive — it hits cheap bottles far harder than expensive ones. A $22 Tito's Vodka pays the same $14.62 duty as a $300 Macallan 18yr. This is why cheap spirits have no margin in Cayman, while premium spirits can still be profitable.

---

## Competitor Margins by Category

### 🟢 HIGH MARGIN — Opportunities to Undercut

#### French Red Wine — 42.7% avg competitor margin
| Product | Competitor | US Retail | Cayman Retail (USD) | Markup vs US | Est. Margin |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-------------------|-------------|------------|
| Clos Cristal Saumur-Champigny | Blackbeard's | $65.00 | $84.01 | +29% | **52%** |
| Alter Ego De Palmer (Margaux) | Jacques Scott | $95.00 | $110.66 | +16% | **50%** |
| Annonce De Belair-Monange | Jacques Scott | $55.00 | $69.67 | +27% | **49%** |
| Aloxe-Corton Domaine Latour | Jacques Scott | $50.00 | $59.02 | +18% | **42%** |
| Les Pallieres Gigondas | Blackbeard's | $22.00 | $22.94 | +4% | **22%** |

**7 Cellars Play:** Direct import French wines at 15-30% below these prices. Bordeaux Cru Bourgeois at KYD $26.28 (from pricing matrix) vs Jacques Scott's $85+ entry point for comparable quality.

#### Champagne (NV Houses) — 39.6% avg competitor margin
| Product | Competitor | US Retail | Cayman Retail (USD) | Markup vs US | Est. Margin |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-------------------|-------------|------------|
| Bollinger B13 | Jacques Scott | $95.00 | $106.56 | +12% | **45%** |
| Billecart-Salmon Rosé | Jacques Scott | $80.00 | $91.80 | +15% | **43%** |
| Billecart-Salmon Blanc de Blanc | Jacques Scott | $70.00 | $83.61 | +19% | **42%** |
| Moët Impérial Brut | Jacques Scott | $48.00 | $60.66 | +26% | **33%** |
| Veuve Clicquot Yellow Label | Jacques Scott | $55.00 | $67.21 | +22% | **36%** |

**7 Cellars Play:** Grower Champagne NV at KYD $42.27 — comparable quality to Billecart at half the price. Educate the market.

#### Italian Red Wine — 37.3% avg competitor margin
| Product | Competitor | US Retail | Cayman Retail (USD) | Markup vs US | Est. Margin |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-------------------|-------------|------------|
| Gaja Sperss Barolo | Jacques Scott | $289.00 | $352.46 | +22% | **57%** |
| Gaja Dagromis Barolo | Jacques Scott | $75.00 | $86.07 | +15% | **46%** |
| Biondi Santi Brunello Riserva | Jacques Scott | $741.00 | $507.38 | -32% | **26%** |
| Fontanafredda Barolo Riserva | Jacques Scott | $80.00 | $135.25 | +69% | **66%** |
| Antinori Peppoli Chianti | Jacques Scott | $22.00 | $22.12 | +1% | **24%** |

**7 Cellars Play:** This is your HOME TURF. Chianti Classico at KYD $23.27 matches Antinori Peppoli pricing. Barolo at KYD $50.27 is **63% below** Fontanafredda's KYD $165 and **42% below** La Spinetta at KYD $88.

#### Champagne Prestige — 32.2% avg competitor margin
| Product | Competitor | US Retail | Cayman Retail (USD) | Markup vs US | Est. Margin |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-------------------|-------------|------------|
| Billecart Cuvée Louis Salmon | Jacques Scott | $140.00 | $164.75 | +18% | **43%** |
| Dom Pérignon | Jacques Scott | $284.00 | $213.11 | -25% | **19%** |
| Dom Pérignon | Tortuga | $240.00 | $192.62 | -20% | **18%** |

**Note:** Dom Pérignon is actually *cheaper* in Cayman than US avg! This is a loss-leader/prestige play by competitors.

---

### 🟡 MODERATE MARGIN (25-40%)

#### Scotch Whisky — 25.8% avg competitor margin
Premium single malts have decent margins due to high absolute prices absorbing the duty:
- **Macallan 12yr Sherry Cask:** US $75 → Cayman $93.44 (+25%), **31% margin**
- **Macallan 12yr Double Cask:** US $64.99 → Cayman $85.25 (+31%), **27% margin**
- **Ardbeg 10yr:** US $68 → Cayman $74.59 (+10%), **16% margin** (tight!)
- **Glenfiddich 26yr:** US $399 → Cayman $431.14 (+8%), **33% margin**

**7 Cellars Play:** Japanese Whisky (Suntory Toki at KYD $42.95) is the gap play here. Zero competition. Don't try to out-Macallan Jacques Scott.

---

### 🔴 LOW/NEGATIVE MARGIN — Avoid Price Competition

#### Vodka — 6.5% avg competitor margin (55.7% markup!)
The paradox: vodka has the **highest markup vs US** but the **lowest margin**. Why? The $14.62/bottle spirits duty destroys margins on cheap bottles.
- **Tito's 750ml:** US $22 → Cayman $28.27 (+28%), but landed cost ~$26.74. **Margin: 5.4%**
- **Absolut 750ml:** US $22 → Cayman $22.94 (+4%), landed ~$26.74. **Margin: -16.5%** (LOSS LEADER!)

**7 Cellars Play:** Don't touch commodity vodka. The numbers don't work.

#### Rum — 7.1% avg competitor margin
- **Appleton Signature 750ml:** US $22 → Cayman $24.58, landed ~$26.74. **Margin: -8.8%**
- **Appleton 12yr 750ml:** US $47 → Cayman $38.52. **Cayman is CHEAPER than US!** (duty-free advantage on some items)
- **Appleton 21yr:** US $99 → Cayman $114.75 (+16%), **margin: 24%** — premium is better

**7 Cellars Play:** Only premium rum (21yr+) makes sense. Commodity rum is a trap.

#### Prosecco — Negative margin (-5.0%)
Sparkling duty (CI$9.50/L = $8.69/bottle) on a $15 Prosecco is devastating.
- **Astoria Prosecco 750ml:** US $14.99 → Cayman $18.84, but landed ~$19.82. **Loss.**

**7 Cellars Play:** Your Prosecco DOC at KYD $22.93 is realistic (pricing matrix shows landed cost of ~$18). Competitors eating losses on Prosecco.

#### Vermouth/Aperitifs/Amaro — Deep negative margins
- **Dolin Vermouth:** US $14.99 → Cayman $13.52. **Selling BELOW US retail AND below landed cost.** Massive loss leader.
- **Aperol 700ml:** US $29 → Cayman $27.04. Below US retail.
- **Amaro Averna:** US $25 → Cayman $25.40. Essentially US retail, but after duty = deep loss.

**7 Cellars Play:** These are cocktail bar staples priced as loss leaders. Don't compete. Carry premium amaro (Nonino at KYD $64.22) as a differentiated offering.

---

## The Cayman Pricing Paradox

### Why markup ≠ margin

| Category | Avg Markup vs US | Avg Competitor Margin | Explanation |
|----------|-----------------|----------------------|-------------|
| Vodka | **+55.7%** | **6.5%** | High markup but duty eats all profit on cheap bottles |
| Italian Wine | +16.0% | **37.3%** | Low markup but high absolute margin (duty is small % of expensive wine) |
| Champagne | +17.2% | **39.6%** | Same dynamic — duty is fixed, high-value products absorb it |
| Rum | +18.1% | **7.1%** | Spirits duty hammers mid-priced rum |
| French Red | +18.9% | **42.7%** | Premium wines = huge margins despite modest markup |

**The rule:** In Cayman, **sell expensive things**. The specific duty system rewards premium products and punishes commodity ones.

---

## Side-by-Side: Competitor Retail vs 7 Cellars Target Pricing

### Wine

| Product/Category | Competitor Price (KYD) | 7 Cellars Target (KYD) | Savings | % Below |
|-----------------|----------------------|----------------------|---------|---------|
| Chianti Classico DOCG | $26.99 (JS) | $23.27 | $3.72 | **14%** |
| Chianti Classico Riserva | $46.99 (JS) | ~$35.00 | $12.00 | **26%** |
| Barolo (mid-tier) | $88.00 (JS, La Spinetta) | $50.27 | $37.73 | **43%** |
| Brunello di Montalcino | $62.00 (JS, Banfi) | ~$50.00 | $12.00 | **19%** |
| Bordeaux Cru Bourgeois | $85.00+ (JS) | $26.28 | $58.72 | **69%** |
| Burgundy Village | $72.00 (JS) | $35.26 | $36.74 | **51%** |
| Premium Rosé (Provence) | $16.99-28.99 | $29.27 | — | Higher* |

*Provence rosé is one area where competitors undercut — Blackbeard's sale pricing is aggressive.

### Champagne & Sparkling

| Product/Category | Competitor Price (KYD) | 7 Cellars Target (KYD) | Savings | % Below |
|-----------------|----------------------|----------------------|---------|---------|
| Prosecco DOC | $22.99-28.49 | $22.93 | $0.06-5.56 | **0-20%** |
| Grower Champagne NV | $68-79 (comparable NV) | $42.27 | $26-37 | **38-47%** |
| Prestige Cuvée | $235-260 (Dom P) | $82.27 | $153-178 | **65-68%** |

### Spirits

| Product/Category | Competitor Price (KYD) | 7 Cellars Target (KYD) | Savings | % Below |
|-----------------|----------------------|----------------------|---------|---------|
| Japanese Whisky (Toki) | **Not available** | $42.95 | EXCLUSIVE | **∞** |
| Craft Gin (Monkey 47) | **Not available** | $49.71 | EXCLUSIVE | **∞** |
| Artisanal Mezcal | **Not available** | $50.96 | EXCLUSIVE | **∞** |
| Small Batch Bourbon | $47.99 (JS, 1792) | $48.44 | — | Comparable |
| Premium Amaro (Nonino) | $30.99 (JS, Averna only) | $64.22 | — | Premium tier |
| NA Spirits (Seedlip) | **Not available** | $29.99 | EXCLUSIVE | **∞** |

---

## Where to Attack: Strategic Price Positioning

### Tier 1 — Undercut Aggressively (Fat Competitor Margins)
These categories have 30-50% competitor margins. 7 Cellars can price 15-30% below and still earn healthy margins.

1. **Italian Red Wine** — Your bread and butter. Direct import at 20-40% below Jacques Scott.
2. **French Red Wine** — Bordeaux and Burgundy are wildly overpriced. Undercut by 30-50%.
3. **Champagne (NV houses)** — Grower champagne at half the price of house names.
4. **Premium Scotch** — Selective plays on 12yr+ single malts.

### Tier 2 — Own Exclusive Categories (Zero Competition)
No need to undercut when you're the only option. Price for perceived value.

1. **Japanese Whisky** — Suntory Toki, Hibiki, Yamazaki
2. **Craft Mezcal** — Del Maguey Vida, Montelobos
3. **Premium Craft Gin** — Monkey 47
4. **Non-Alcoholic Spirits** — Seedlip, Lyre's
5. **Artisanal Amaro** — Nonino, Montenegro
6. **Specialty Food** — Caviar, premium EVOO, charcuterie, Italian coffee

### Tier 3 — Avoid (Negative/Razor-Thin Margins)
Competitors are losing money or breaking even. Don't enter.

1. **Commodity Vodka** — Tito's, Absolut at 750ml
2. **Commodity Rum** — Appleton Signature, Malibu
3. **Prosecco** (at competitive prices — the duty kills it)
4. **Vermouth/Aperitifs** — Dolin, Aperol are loss leaders
5. **Entry-level wine** — Yellow Tail, Frontera. Let Blackbeard's fight this battle.

---

## Average Competitor Margins by Category (Ranked)

| Rank | Category | Avg Margin | Avg Markup vs US | Products | Verdict |
|------|----------|-----------|-----------------|----------|---------|
| 1 | French Red Wine | **42.7%** | +18.9% | 5 | 🟢 ATTACK |
| 2 | French Dessert Wine | **41.3%** | +37.7% | 1 | 🟢 ATTACK |
| 3 | Champagne (NV) | **39.6%** | +17.2% | 19 | 🟢 ATTACK |
| 4 | Italian Red Wine | **37.3%** | +16.0% | 20 | 🟢 ATTACK |
| 5 | French White Wine | **35.8%** | +23.8% | 3 | 🟢 ATTACK |
| 6 | Champagne Prestige | **32.2%** | -13.2% | 3 | 🟡 Selective |
| 7 | Scotch Whisky | **25.8%** | +23.2% | 18 | 🟡 Selective |
| 8 | Tequila | **24.9%** | -5.4% | 5 | 🟡 Premium only |
| 9 | Rye Whiskey | **23.7%** | +18.0% | 1 | 🟡 Selective |
| 10 | New World Red | **21.0%** | +27.7% | 29 | 🟡 Mid-premium only |
| 11 | Non-Alcoholic | **17.6%** | -3.4% | 4 | 🟡 Exclusive play |
| 12 | Bourbon | **15.4%** | +14.8% | 2 | 🔴 Exclusive only |
| 13 | New World White | **12.6%** | +23.0% | 10 | 🔴 Avoid commodity |
| 14 | Sparkling (non-Champ) | **9.7%** | +23.6% | 3 | 🔴 Avoid |
| 15 | Rum | **7.1%** | +18.1% | 14 | 🔴 Premium only |
| 16 | Vodka | **6.5%** | +55.7% | 10 | 🔴 Avoid |
| 17 | Gin | **0.2%** | +9.1% | 2 | 🔴 Exclusive only |
| 18 | Prosecco | **-5.0%** | +8.4% | 3 | 🔴 Avoid commodity |
| 19 | Aperitif/Vermouth | **-48.5%** | -5.4% | 4 | 🔴 Loss leaders — avoid |

---

## Competitor Profiles (Updated with Margin Intelligence)

### Jacques Scott — The Incumbent King
- **Highest margins on:** Italian premium wine (Barolo/Brunello/Amarone) — 40-66% margins
- **Loss leaders:** None identified. They price everything for profit.
- **Vulnerability:** Italian and French wine are massively overpriced. 7 Cellars can undercut 20-50% on direct imports.

### Blackbeard's — The Volume Player
- **Highest margins on:** Premium wines when on sale (Justin Cab, etc.)
- **Loss leaders:** Aperol, vermouth, some spirits — aggressive promotional pricing to drive foot traffic
- **Vulnerability:** No premium Italian depth. No specialty anything.

### Tortuga — The Tourist Machine
- **Highest margins on:** Ultra-premium tequila (Komos, Cincoro) — ~25% margin on $1,700 bottles = massive absolute dollars
- **Loss leaders:** Dom Pérignon (priced below US retail!)
- **Vulnerability:** Wine selection is thin and overpriced (Justin Cab at $39.99 vs US $27, Cloudy Bay at $39.99 vs US $31)

---

## Data Methodology

- **US Retail Prices:** Wine-Searcher average US retail (ex-tax), Total Wine, ABC Fine Wine
- **Wholesale estimate:** 50% of US retail for wine/champagne, 55% for spirits (reflects large importer pricing)
- **Shipping:** $2.50/bottle flat rate (container shipping, allocated)
- **Insurance:** 1.5% of wholesale value
- **Duty:** CI$5.50/L (wine), CI$9.50/L (sparkling), CI$15.98/L (spirits), 22% (food/NA)
- **166 of 167 products** successfully matched with US pricing data

---

*Full product-level data with US prices, markups, and margin estimates available in: `competitor-prices.csv`*  
*7 Cellars landed cost projections available in: `pricing-matrix.csv`*

files.name: Craft Spirits Research
files.content:
# Craft Spirits Portfolio Research — 7 Cellars

## A Strategic Guide to Building a Premium Spirits Program

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 9, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, 7 Cellars — Grand Cayman

---

## TL;DR

Grand Cayman's spirits market is dominated by Jacques Scott (~540 SKUs), but their catalog skews heavily mainstream. Massive gaps exist in Japanese whisky (Nikka recently added but no Suntory/Roku), artisanal mezcal (only Clase Azul), craft gin (no Monkey 47, Botanist, or Ki No Bi), small-batch bourbon (no Buffalo Trace, Maker's Mark, or WhistlePig), and premium amaro (only Averna and Fernet-Branca). Blackbeard's and Tortuga serve the mass-market/tourist segment. The Tasting Room is wine-focused and could become a 7 Cellars customer. This report recommends **40+ brands across 6 categories**, with competitor availability research for each, identifying which are exclusive gaps vs. already carried on-island. Initial portfolio value: **$200K–$400K** targeting luxury hotels, cocktail-forward restaurants, and HNW residents.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Market Landscape & Competitor Analysis](#1-market-landscape--competitor-analysis)
2. [Japanese Whisky](#2-japanese-whisky)
3. [Craft Gin](#3-craft-gin)
4. [Premium Tequila & Mezcal](#4-premium-tequila--mezcal)
5. [Craft & Aged Rum](#5-craft--aged-rum)
6. [Small-Batch Bourbon & Rye](#6-small-batch-bourbon--rye)
7. [Amaro, Liqueurs & Specialty](#7-amaro-liqueurs--specialty)
8. [Competitor Availability Summary](#8-competitor-availability-summary)
9. [Logistics & Duty Rates](#9-logistics--duty-rates)
10. [Pricing Strategy](#10-pricing-strategy)
11. [Target Accounts](#11-target-accounts)
12. [Strategy & Action Plan](#12-strategy--action-plan)

---

## 1. Market Landscape & Competitor Analysis

### Island Competitors

| Competitor | Focus | Spirits Offering | Online Catalog? |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Jacques Scott** | Wine & spirits (dominant, ~540 spirits SKUs) | Broadest selection on island; skews mainstream | Yes — jacquesscott.com |
| **Blackbeard's** | Liquor retail chain (Dart-owned) | Mainstream spirits, mass-market focus | Partial — blackbeards.ky |
| **The Tasting Room** | Wine retail + hospitality venues | Wine-focused; minimal spirits | No searchable catalog |
| **Tortuga** | Rum cakes, distillery, tourist retail | Own rum, basic spirits | Limited online |
| **Cost-U-Less** | Big-box retailer | Budget spirits (Bacardi, Captain Morgan) | No |

### Key Insight

Jacques Scott is the only real competitor in premium spirits. They've recently expanded (adding Nikka, Foursquare, Diplomático), but their 540-SKU catalog still has **enormous blind spots** — entire categories like craft mezcal, Japanese gin, small-batch bourbon, and premium amaro are essentially absent.

**Blackbeard's** carries mainstream/volume brands (Absolut, Tito's, Dolin). Not a competitor in the craft/premium space.

**The Tasting Room** is wine-centric with hospitality venues — a potential 7 Cellars B2B customer, not a competitor.

### Cayman Pricing vs. US Retail

Based on live Jacques Scott pricing (KYD converted at 1.20 USD):

| Product | US Retail | Jacques Scott (USD) | Markup |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1792 Small Batch | $30 | $58 | 1.93× |
| Foursquare 2010 | $60 | $101 | 1.68× |
| Diplomático Reserva Exclusiva | $35 | $66 | 1.89× |
| Woodford Reserve | $35 | $59 | 1.69× |
| Fernet-Branca | $25 | $82 | 3.28× |
| Ron Zacapa 23 | $50 | varies | ~1.8× |

**Average Cayman markup: ~1.8–1.9× US retail.** 7 Cellars can price at **1.5–1.7×** to undercut Jacques Scott by 10–15% while maintaining healthy margins.

---

## 2. Japanese Whisky

**Category Opportunity: HIGH** — Jacques Scott recently added Nikka (9 SKUs), but no Suntory, Roku, or any other Japanese whisky brand. Still a massive gap.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Nikka** | From The Barrel ($65), Coffey Grain ($60), Coffey Malt, Coffey Still Gin | $40–$90 | $65–$150 | **Jacques Scott** (9 SKUs incl. gin) | Carried — compete on allocation/pricing |
| **Suntory (Toki, Hibiki)** | Toki ($30), Hibiki Harmony ($70), Yamazaki 12 ($160+) | $28–$170 | $45–$280 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Mars Shinshu** | Iwai Tradition ($40), Iwai 45 ($35) | $35–$95 | $55–$155 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Akashi (White Oak)** | Single Malt ($55), Blended ($30) | $30–$60 | $48–$96 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Ohishi** | Sherry Cask ($70), Brandy Cask ($65) | $60–$90 | $96–$144 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Kurayoshi (Matsui)** | Pure Malt ($50), 8yr ($65), 12yr ($100) | $45–$110 | $70–$175 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Nikka:** Hotaling & Co. — hotaling.com/contact
- **Suntory:** Beam Suntory — beamsuntory.com (Caribbean team)
- **Mars/Ohishi/Kurayoshi:** Impex Beverages — impexbev.com

### Recommendation

Lead with **Suntory Toki** (entry-level, cocktail-friendly) and **Nikka From The Barrel** (bartender favorite — compete with JS on this). Add **Mars Iwai** and **Ohishi** for collector/enthusiast differentiation. Jacques Scott having Nikka validates the demand; 7 Cellars owns everything else in the category.

---

## 3. Craft Gin

**Category Opportunity: HIGH** — Jacques Scott has 52 gins but mostly mainstream British brands. Zero Japanese gin, no Monkey 47, no Botanist.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Monkey 47** | Schwarzwald Dry ($40), Sloe ($45), Distiller's Cut ($60) | $35–$60 | $56–$96 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **The Botanist** | Islay Dry Gin ($33) | $30–$35 | $48–$56 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Ki No Bi** | Kyoto Dry Gin ($48), Ki No Tea ($55), Ki No Bi Sei ($65) | $45–$70 | $70–$112 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Empress 1908** | Color-changing gin ($32) | $28–$35 | $45–$56 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Malfy** | Con Limone, Rosa, Con Arancia, Originale ($25 each) | $22–$28 | $35–$45 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Roku** | Japanese Craft Gin ($28) | $25–$30 | $40–$48 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Hendrick's** (Ltd Eds) | Neptunia, Orbium, Flora Adora ($38–$45) | $35–$45 | $56–$72 | JS has standard Hendrick's — check Ltd Eds | Partial gap (limited editions) |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Monkey 47 / Malfy:** Pernod Ricard — pernod-ricard.com
- **The Botanist:** Rémy Cointreau — remycointreau.com
- **Ki No Bi / Roku:** Hotaling & Co. / Beam Suntory
- **Empress 1908:** Park Street Imports — victoriaspirits.com

### Recommendation

**Monkey 47** is the #1 gin opportunity — iconic, premium, not on island. Pair with **Ki No Bi** (Japanese gin ties into whisky portfolio) and **Empress 1908** (Instagram appeal for resort cocktails). **Malfy** offers accessible Italian gin at high volume. The entire craft gin category is wide open.

---

## 4. Premium Tequila & Mezcal

**Category Opportunity: VERY HIGH** — Jacques Scott carries 64 tequilas but mostly Casamigos (frequently sold out!) and Clase Azul. The only mezcal is Clase Azul Durango at KYD $327. Zero artisanal mezcal.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Fortaleza** | Blanco ($45), Repo ($55), Añejo ($70), Still Strength ($60) | $40–$75 | $64–$120 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Pasote** | Blanco ($40), Repo ($50), Añejo ($60), XA ($85) | $38–$90 | $60–$144 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **G4** | Blanco ($45), Repo ($55), Añejo ($70), XA ($100) | $42–$105 | $67–$168 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Siete Leguas** | Blanco ($40), Repo ($55), Añejo ($65), D'Antaño ($130) | $38–$135 | $60–$216 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Del Maguey** (Mezcal) | Vida ($30), Chichicapa ($65), San Luis del Rio ($55), Tobalá ($110) | $28–$120 | $45–$192 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Montelobos** (Mezcal) | Espadín ($35), Tobalá ($75), Ensamble ($50) | $32–$80 | $51–$128 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Vago** (Mezcal) | Espadín ($40), Elote ($55), Mexicano ($50) | $38–$60 | $60–$96 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Fortaleza:** L. Knife & Son — fortalezatequila.com
- **Pasote:** PM Spirits — pmspirits.com
- **G4:** LTD Spirits — g4tequila.com
- **Del Maguey:** Pernod Ricard — pernod-ricard.com
- **Montelobos:** William Grant & Sons — william-grant.com
- **Siete Leguas:** Hotaling & Co. — hotaling.com

### Recommendation

**Fortaleza** is the bartender's #1 tequila — lead with this. **Del Maguey Vida** is the industry-standard well mezcal; **Chichicapa** and **Tobalá** for the premium shelf. The entire artisanal tequila and mezcal category is a **total vacuum** on Grand Cayman. With Casamigos constantly sold out at JS, demand is clearly there. 7 Cellars can own this space entirely.

---

## 5. Craft & Aged Rum

**Category Opportunity: MEDIUM-HIGH** — Jacques Scott recently added Foursquare (4 SKUs) and Diplomático (2 SKUs), validating demand. But many premium rum brands are still absent.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Foursquare** | ECS releases, Probitas ($25), Doorly's ($20–$40) | $20–$100 | $32–$160 | **Jacques Scott** (4 SKUs: 2010, Equipoise, Probitas, Premise) | Carried — compete on ECS allocation |
| **Diplomático** | Reserva Exclusiva ($35), Single Vintage ($55), Ambassador ($250) | $32–$260 | $51–$416 | **Jacques Scott** (2 SKUs: Reserva Exclusiva, Single Vintage — sold out) | Carried — supply issues at JS |
| **Hampden Estate** | 8yr ($50), Great House ($80), Overproof ($40) | $38–$110 | $60–$176 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Plantation** | XO ($50), Stiggins' Pineapple ($32), Fiji ($30), Vintages ($45–$100) | $28–$100 | $45–$160 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Worthy Park** | Single Estate Reserve ($45), 12yr ($80), Rum Bar ($20) | $18–$85 | $29–$136 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Ron Zacapa** | Centenario 23 ($50), Edición Negra ($65), XO ($100) | $45–$105 | $72–$168 | **Jacques Scott** (4 SKUs) | Carried |
| **Clairin** (Haitian) | Sajous ($35), Vaval ($35), Le Rocher ($35) | $30–$40 | $48–$64 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Foursquare:** Purple Valley Imports / direct from Barbados — foursquarerum.com
- **Diplomático:** Monarq Group — monarq.com
- **Hampden:** La Maison & Velier / Park Street — hampdenestaterum.com
- **Plantation:** Sire Spirits Group — plantationrum.com
- **Worthy Park:** Direct — worthyparkrum.com
- **Clairin:** Velier / Tenzing Wine & Spirits

### Recommendation

**Plantation** is the biggest gap — wide range, Pineapple rum for cocktails, vintage releases for collectors. **Hampden Estate** (Jamaican, close to Cayman) and **Worthy Park** fill the "serious rum" shelf. Foursquare and Diplomático are already on-island via JS, but both have supply/allocation issues — 7 Cellars can compete by securing better allocation, especially for ECS releases.

---

## 6. Small-Batch Bourbon & Rye

**Category Opportunity: VERY HIGH** — Jacques Scott has only 1792 Small Batch, Bulleit, and Woodford Reserve. No Buffalo Trace, no Maker's Mark, no craft bourbon at all.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |

| **Buffalo Trace / Sazerac** | Buffalo Trace ($25), Eagle Rare ($35), Blanton's ($60), Weller SR ($25) | $25–$60 | $40–$96 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Maker's Mark** | Original ($28), 46 ($35), Private Select ($60), Cellar Aged ($150) | $28–$155 | $45–$248 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Woodford Reserve** | Standard ($35), Double Oaked ($55), Batch Proof ($130) | $33–$140 | $53–$224 | **Jacques Scott** (4 SKUs) | Carried — compete on limited releases |
| **Four Roses** | Single Barrel ($40), Small Batch Select ($55), LE ($100+) | $38–$110 | $60–$176 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Michter's** | US\*1 Bourbon ($45), US\*1 Rye ($45), Toasted Barrel ($55) | $42–$110 | $67–$176 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **WhistlePig** | PiggyBack 6yr ($35), 10yr ($75), 12yr ($100), Boss Hog ($500) | $33–$500 | $53–$800 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Barrell Craft Spirits** | Bourbon batches ($50), Seagrass ($80), Gold Label ($300) | $50–$300 | $80–$480 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Buffalo Trace:** Sazerac Company — sazerac.com (Caribbean allocation team)
- **Maker's Mark:** Beam Suntory — beamsuntory.com

### Recommendation

This is a **massive gap**. Buffalo Trace, Maker's Mark, and Four Roses are staple bourbons that simply don't exist on Grand Cayman. **Blanton's** alone could drive foot traffic. **Maker's Mark Private Select** offers 7 Cellars an exclusive barrel pick. **Barrell Seagrass** (Caribbean rum cask finish) is a perfect Cayman story. **WhistlePig Boss Hog** is a trophy bottle for the ultra-luxury market.

---

## 7. Amaro, Liqueurs & Specialty

**Category Opportunity: HIGH** — Jacques Scott has Averna, Aperol, and recently added Fernet-Branca ($68 KYD — massively overpriced). Everything else is missing.

| Brand | Key Products | US Retail | Est. Cayman Price | On Island? | Gap? |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Amaro Montenegro** | Amaro Montenegro ($25) | $23–$28 | $37–$45 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Fernet-Branca** | Fernet ($25), Branca Menta ($25) | $22–$28 | $35–$45 | **Jacques Scott** (KYD $68 — $82 USD) | Carried — but at 3.3× markup |
| **Amaro Nonino** | Quintessentia ($40) | $38–$48 | $60–$77 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **St-Germain** | Elderflower Liqueur ($30) | $28–$35 | $45–$56 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Chartreuse** | Green ($35), Yellow ($35), V.E.P. ($130) | $32–$140 | $51–$224 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Lyre's** (Non-Alc) | Dry London Spirit, Italian Orange, American Malt ($30 ea) | $28–$35 | $45–$56 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |
| **Tattersall** | Aquavit ($30), Crème de Fleur ($28), Fernet ($32) | $25–$35 | $40–$56 | **Not found** | ✅ EXCLUSIVE GAP |

### Distribution Contacts

- **Montenegro:** Gruppo Montenegro / Zamora Company — grupomontenegro.com
- **Fernet-Branca:** Rémy Cointreau — remycointreau.com
- **Nonino:** Direct — nonino.it
- **St-Germain:** Bacardi — bacardi.com
- **Chartreuse:** Frederick Wildman & Sons (severely allocated globally)
- **Lyre's:** Direct — lyres.com

### Recommendation

**Montenegro**, **Nonino**, and **St-Germain** are cocktail bar essentials that don't exist on Grand Cayman. **Chartreuse** is globally allocated — if you can get it, instant credibility. Fernet-Branca is at Jacques Scott but at an absurd KYD $68 ($82 USD) — 7 Cellars can undercut by 40%+ and still profit. **Lyre's** non-alcoholic spirits is the fastest-growing category; zero competition on island.

---

## 8. Competitor Availability Summary

### Master Availability Table

This table shows every recommended brand and where (if anywhere) it's currently available on Grand Cayman. **"Not found"** = confirmed not on any competitor's online catalog = exclusive gap for 7 Cellars.

- **Carried by other competitors:** 0 additional brands found

**Bottom line:** 7 Cellars can own 30+ premium spirit brands exclusively on Grand Cayman.

---

## 9. Logistics & Duty Rates

### Combined Shipping

Spirits ship in the same containers as wine — both classified as alcoholic beverages. Key points:

- Standard 20ft or 40ft containers (reefer recommended for Caribbean)
- Spirits heavier per case than wine — factor into load planning
- ~1,200 cases (9L equivalent) per standard container
- Same freight forwarder, customs clearance, and delivery route

### Cayman Islands Duty Rates

| Product | Duty Rate | Per 750ml Bottle |
|---|---|---|
| Wine | CI$4.50/imperial gallon | ~CI$1.20 |
| Spirits (>22% ABV) | CI$10.50/imperial gallon | ~CI$2.80 |
| Beer | CI$1.80/imperial gallon | ~CI$0.45 |

**No VAT or sales tax** in Cayman. Duty is the only government cost — and it's remarkably low for spirits.

### MOQ Expectations

| Supplier Type | Typical MOQ | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Major brands (Beam Suntory, Pernod Ricard) | 1 pallet (56–112 cases) per SKU | Relationship pricing |
| Mid-size craft (Foursquare, Fortaleza, Monkey 47) | 5–10 cases per SKU | Reasonable for testing |
| Small craft (Ohishi, Clairin, Vago) | 3–6 bottles per SKU | Very flexible |

**Recommendation:** Start with a mixed-pallet approach — 3–5 cases each of 30–50 SKUs across categories. Test the market before committing deeply.

---

## 10. Pricing Strategy

### Recommended Pricing Framework

| Channel | Markup over US Retail | vs. Jacques Scott |
|---|---|---|
| Wholesale (restaurants/hotels) | 1.3–1.5× | 15–25% below JS |
| Retail (direct to consumer) | 1.5–1.7× | 10–15% below JS |
| Allocated/limited releases | 1.8–2.2× | Premium justified by scarcity |

### Example Pricing

| Product | US Retail | 7 Cellars Wholesale | 7 Cellars Retail | Jacques Scott |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Fortaleza Blanco | $45 | $59 | $72 | N/A (not available) |
| Monkey 47 | $40 | $52 | $64 | N/A |
| Blanton's | $60 | $78 | $96 | N/A |
| Plantation XO | $50 | $65 | $80 | N/A |
| Fernet-Branca | $25 | $33 | $40 | $82 (JS) — undercut by 51% |

---

## 11. Target Accounts

### Priority On-Premise Accounts

| Venue | Type | Spirits Opportunity | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Ritz-Carlton** (Seven, Silver Rain, Bar Jack, Blue by Eric Ripert) | Luxury hotel | Japanese whisky, allocated bourbon, premium amaro | 🔴 Highest |
| **Kimpton Seafire** (Coccoloba, Ave, The Backroom) | Luxury resort | Craft cocktail program — gin, mezcal, amaro | 🔴 Highest |
| **Agua** | Upscale cocktail bar, Camana Bay | Full craft spirits program | 🔴 Highest |
| **Tillies** | Craft cocktail focus, Camana Bay | Fortaleza, Del Maguey, Monkey 47 | 🔴 Highest |
| **Luca** | Italian fine dining | Amaro, Italian gin (Malfy), digestifs | 🟡 High |
| **The Brasserie** | Cocktail-forward, Cricket Square | Full bar program upgrade | 🟡 High |
| **The Wharf** | Fine dining | Bourbon, rum, whisky shelf | 🟡 High |
| **Kaibo** | Premium beach bar | Plantation Pineapple, Empress Gin, Malfy | 🟡 High |
| **The Westin** (Ferdinand's, Beach House) | Resort | Volume spirits + premium tier | 🟡 High |
| **Palm Heights** | Boutique luxury hotel | Curated craft spirits | 🟡 High |

### The Pitch

1. **"Fill the gaps your current distributor can't"** — Japanese whisky, craft mezcal, allocated bourbon
2. **"Exclusive products your competitors won't have"** — Maker's Mark Private Select barrel pick, Foursquare ECS allocation, Blanton's
3. **"One relationship for wine AND spirits"** — Single invoice, single delivery, sommelier-level expertise across both
4. **"We'll build your cocktail program"** — Free staff training, recipe cards, menu consultation
5. **"Better pricing"** — 10–15% below Jacques Scott on comparable products

---

## 12. Strategy & Action Plan

### Top 10 Brands to Approach First

| # | Brand | Category | Why First |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Fortaleza** | Tequila | Bartender's #1 choice, total gap, growing demand |
| 2 | **Monkey 47** | Gin | Iconic craft gin, total gap, premium positioning |
| 3 | **Buffalo Trace / Blanton's** | Bourbon | Most sought-after bourbon, total gap, Cayman may be open market |
| 4 | **Del Maguey** | Mezcal | Category-defining, Vida for well + premiums for shelf |
| 5 | **Plantation** | Rum | Wide range, Pineapple for cocktails, total gap |
| 6 | **Suntory (Toki + Roku)** | Japanese Whisky + Gin | Portfolio play — two categories from one distributor |
| 7 | **Maker's Mark Private Select** | Bourbon | Custom barrel pick = 7 Cellars exclusive |
| 8 | **Hampden Estate** | Rum | Caribbean provenance, total gap |
| 9 | **Montenegro + Nonino** | Amaro | Cocktail essentials, total gap |
| 10 | **St-Germain** | Liqueur | Bartender's ketchup, total gap |

### Portfolio Mix

| Category | % of Initial Order | # SKUs | Investment |
|---|---|---|---|
| Premium Tequila & Mezcal | 25% | 12–15 | $50K–$88K |
| Small-Batch Bourbon & Rye | 20% | 10–12 | $40K–$70K |
| Craft & Aged Rum | 20% | 12–15 | $40K–$70K |
| Japanese Whisky | 15% | 8–10 | $30K–$53K |
| Craft Gin | 10% | 8–10 | $20K–$35K |
| Amaro/Specialty/Other | 10% | 8–10 | $20K–$35K |
| **Total** | **100%** | **58–72 SKUs** | **$200K–$350K** |

### Estimated Initial Investment

| Item | Cost |
|---|---|
| Initial inventory (300–400 cases, 50–60 SKUs) | $150,000–$200,000 |
| Shipping (1 container from US, consolidated) | $8,000–$12,000 |
| Customs duty (spirits at CI$2.80/bottle) | $8,000–$12,000 |
| Trade license / import permit amendments | $2,000–$5,000 |
| Marketing materials & tasting kits | $3,000–$5,000 |
| Launch tastings/events (3–4 events) | $5,000–$8,000 |
| **Total** | **$176,000–$242,000** |

**Expected gross margin:** 30–40% wholesale, 50–60% retail.

### Timeline

**Month 1–2:** Contact top 10 distributors. Secure allocation commitments. Apply for any additional import permits.

**Month 3–4:** First container arrives. Begin restaurant/hotel tastings with chefs and bar managers. Launch with 5–8 on-premise accounts.

**Month 5–8:** Expand to 15–20 accounts. Host first "Craft Spirits Tasting" event. Secure Maker's Mark Private Select barrel.

**Month 9–12:** Evaluate performance. Add allocated/limited releases. Target $300K+ annual run rate.

---

## Sources & Confidence

**Confidence Level: MEDIUM-HIGH**

| Area | Confidence | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Jacques Scott availability | **High** | Live website searches, Feb 2026 |
| Blackbeard's availability | **Medium** | Online catalog partial; in-store may differ |
| Tasting Room / Tortuga | **Medium** | No searchable spirits catalogs online |
| Brand recommendations | **High** | Established craft spirits knowledge |
| Pricing estimates | **Medium** | Based on JS markup analysis; verify with quotes |
| Duty rates | **Medium** | Based on Cayman Customs Tariff Law; confirm directly |
| Distribution contacts | **Medium** | Arrangements change; verify when approaching |

### Verification Notes

- Jacques Scott's online catalog may not show 100% of in-store inventory
- Blackbeard's physical stores may carry brands not listed online
- In-person visits to all competitors recommended before finalizing portfolio
- Contact CIAA (Cayman Customs) for current duty rate schedule
- Visit Ritz-Carlton, Kimpton, and Tillies bars to see what they're actually pouring

---

*Report prepared February 9, 2026. Prices, availability, and regulations subject to change.*

files.name: Nova Scotia Scallops Research
files.content:
# Nova Scotia Scallops for Grand Cayman

## Adams & Knickle — Import & Distribution Analysis for 7 Cellars

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 10, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, 7 Cellars

---

## TL;DR

Nova Scotia produces some of the world's finest Atlantic sea scallops (*Placopecten magellanicus*), and **Adams & Knickle Ltd** — founded in Lunenburg in 1897 — is one of Canada's most storied scallop fishing companies. Grand Cayman's high-end restaurants currently source scallops through generic broadline distributors (Progressive Distributors, Hurley's Marketplace) who import frozen product from US or Asian suppliers — quality is inconsistent and provenance is an afterthought. 7 Cellars has a rare advantage: Dwayne is local to Nova Scotia, Adams & Knickle is ~90 minutes away in Lunenburg, and 7 Cellars already has wine relationships with every top restaurant on Grand Cayman. The play is simple — become the premium scallop supplier to the same restaurants you already sell wine to. Ship IQF (individually quick frozen) scallops Halifax → Miami → Grand Cayman via air freight, landed cost ~CI$28–38/lb, sell wholesale at CI$45–55/lb for 30–45% gross margins. Conservative Year 1 revenue: **CI$150,000–280,000** across 8–12 restaurant accounts. The "From Nova Scotia to Grand Cayman" provenance story is marketing gold — especially paired with wine dinners.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Adams & Knickle Company Profile](#1-adams--knickle-company-profile)
2. [Nova Scotia Scallop Industry](#2-nova-scotia-scallop-industry)
3. [Grand Cayman Restaurant Market](#3-grand-cayman-restaurant-market)
4. [Competitor Analysis](#4-competitor-analysis)
5. [Logistics & Cold Chain](#5-logistics--cold-chain)
6. [Regulatory Requirements](#6-regulatory-requirements)
7. [Pricing & Margin Analysis](#7-pricing--margin-analysis)
8. [Volume Estimates & Revenue Potential](#8-volume-estimates--revenue-potential)
9. [Risks & Mitigation](#9-risks--mitigation)
10. [Cross-Sell Synergy](#10-cross-sell-synergy)
11. [Action Plan](#11-action-plan)

---

## 1. Adams & Knickle Company Profile

### History

Adams & Knickle Ltd is one of Nova Scotia's oldest and most respected fishing companies, founded in **1897** in Lunenburg, Nova Scotia by Harry W. Adams and Captain Alexander Knickle. The company began in the booming salt-fish trade that made Lunenburg famous worldwide.

**Key milestones:**

| Year | Milestone |
|------|-----------|
| 1897 | Founded as Knickle & Co. in Lunenburg |
| 1907 | Renamed to Adams & Knickle Ltd |
| 1945 | Officially incorporated |
| 1954 | Purchased Lunenburg's first deep-sea scallop dragger, the *Barbara Jo* |
| 1959 | Fleet expanded to 8+ wooden scallop vessels |
| 1962 | Offshore fleet grown to 44 vessels |
| 1980 | Fleet reached 77 vessels at peak |
| Present | Focused primarily on deep-sea scallop fishing |

The pivot from salt-fish to scallops in the 1950s positioned Adams & Knickle as one of Canada's premier scallop operations. They've been fishing scallops for **70+ years** — longer than almost anyone in the Atlantic.

### What Makes Their Scallops Special

| Factor | Details |
|--------|---------|
| **Species** | *Placopecten magellanicus* (Atlantic sea scallop) — the largest and most prized scallop species in the world |
| **Harvesting** | Offshore dragger fleet operating on Georges Bank and Browns Bank |
| **Water temperature** | Cold North Atlantic waters (2–10°C) produce denser, sweeter meat |
| **Size** | U/10 to 10/20 count per pound — substantially larger than Asian alternatives |
| **Flavor** | Sweet, briny, firm texture — superior to warm-water and farmed alternatives |
| **Processing** | Shucked at sea or dockside in Lunenburg, minimal handling |
| **Location** | Lunenburg, NS — UNESCO World Heritage Site, iconic fishing port |

### Current Distribution

Adams & Knickle primarily sells through:
- Canadian wholesale fish markets
- Export to US East Coast buyers
- Japanese market (high-value sashimi-grade)
- Direct sales from Lunenburg

**Key insight:** They are a fishing/harvesting company, not primarily a marketing company. This means there may be opportunity for a distribution partnership without competing with existing retail channels.

### Dwayne's Proximity Advantage

| From | To | Distance | Drive Time |
|------|------|----------|------------|
| Windsor, NS | Lunenburg, NS | ~170 km | ~1h 45min |

This is close enough for face-to-face relationship building, facility visits, and even product pickup if needed. Most buyers deal with Adams & Knickle remotely — Dwayne can show up in person.

---

## 2. Nova Scotia Scallop Industry

### Why Nova Scotia Scallops Are World-Class

Nova Scotia is one of the world's top scallop producing regions. The cold, nutrient-rich waters of the North Atlantic produce scallops with a flavor profile and texture that warm-water alternatives simply cannot match.

**Key factors:**

- **Cold water = superior flavor.** The slow growth in cold water (2–10°C) produces dense, sweet, firm scallop meat with higher glycogen content (natural sweetness)
- **Size.** Atlantic sea scallops (*P. magellanicus*) are the largest commercially harvested scallop species — individual meats can weigh 30–50g+
- **Clean waters.** The offshore banks (Georges Bank, Browns Bank, German Bank) are pristine deep-ocean environments
- **Sustainable management.** Canada's DFO (Department of Fisheries and Oceans) manages the fishery with strict quotas, area closures, and monitoring

### Key Fishing Grounds

| Area | Location | Notes |
|------|----------|-------|
| **Georges Bank** | Canada-US boundary, offshore NS | Shared with US; highest-quality scallops; strictly quota-managed |
| **Browns Bank** | South of NS mainland | Major Canadian scallop ground |
| **German Bank** | South of Yarmouth | Important inshore/offshore area |
| **Bay of Fundy** | Digby area | Famous "Digby scallops" — more inshore/day-boat |
| **Scotian Shelf** | Offshore NS | Various productive areas |

### Digby vs Lunenburg Scallops

| Feature | Digby | Lunenburg (Adams & Knickle) |
|---------|-------|-----------------------------|
| **Style** | Day-boat, inshore | Offshore, multi-day trips |
| **Size** | Smaller (20/30 count) | Larger (U/10, 10/20 count) |
| **Reputation** | Famous brand name ("Digby scallops") | Less consumer-facing but equally high quality |
| **Volume** | Smaller, seasonal | Larger, more consistent supply |
| **Price** | Premium (day-boat marketing) | Competitive — potentially better value |

### MSC Certification Status

The **Eastern Canada Offshore Scallop fishery** (which includes Georges Bank and Browns Bank where Adams & Knickle operates) has held **Marine Stewardship Council (MSC)** certification. This is significant for Grand Cayman's luxury restaurants — sustainability credentials matter to high-end chefs and their clientele.

**Note:** MSC certification status should be confirmed directly with Adams & Knickle, as certifications undergo periodic reassessment.

### Seasonality

| Season | Activity | Notes |
|--------|----------|-------|
| **Year-round** | Offshore scallop fishing operates year-round | No closed "season" for offshore fleet |
| **Spring (Apr–Jun)** | Peak spawning — meat quality can be slightly lower | Some areas may have temporary closures |
| **Summer–Fall** | Excellent meat quality | Best time for premium product |
| **Winter** | Active fishing, excellent quality | Cold water = firm, sweet meat |
| **DFO Closures** | Area-specific, varies by year | Managed for sustainability |

**Key takeaway:** Unlike many seafood products, Atlantic sea scallops are available year-round from offshore operations. This is a major advantage for reliable restaurant supply.

---

## 3. Grand Cayman Restaurant Market

### Target Restaurants

7 Cellars already has wine relationships with Grand Cayman's top restaurants. These same restaurants are the scallop market.

| Restaurant | Type | Scallop Potential | Wine Relationship | Priority |
|------------|------|-------------------|-------------------|----------|
| **Blue by Eric Ripert** (Ritz-Carlton) | Fine dining, seafood-focused | Very High — scallops are a menu staple | ✅ Existing | 🔴 Top |
| **Seven** (Ritz-Carlton) | Fine dining | High | ✅ Existing | 🔴 Top |
| **Kimpton Seafire (Ave, Coccoloba)** | Resort dining | High | ✅ Existing | 🔴 Top |
| **Luca** | Italian fine dining | High — scallop crudo, pasta dishes | ✅ Existing | 🔴 Top |
| **The Brasserie** | Upscale European | High | ✅ Existing | 🔴 Top |
| **Agua** | Fine dining | High | ✅ Existing | 🟡 High |
| **The Tillerman** | Seafood-forward | Very High | ✅ Existing | 🟡 High |
| **Abacus** | Modern fine dining | High | ✅ Existing | 🟡 High |
| **Ristorante Pappagallo** | Italian fine dining | Medium-High | ✅ Existing | 🟡 High |
| **Calypso Grill** | Waterfront seafood | Medium-High | ✅ Existing | 🟢 Medium |
| **Morgan's** | Seafood | High | TBC | 🟢 Medium |
| **Kaibo** | Beach/upscale casual | Medium | TBC | 🟢 Medium |
| **Grand Old House** | Fine dining | Medium-High | TBC | 🟢 Medium |

### Current Scallop Sourcing

Grand Cayman restaurants currently source scallops through:

1. **Progressive Distributors** — The island's largest broadline food distributor. Sources frozen scallops (likely US or Chinese origin) through their US supply chain
2. **Hurley's Marketplace / Hurley's Supermarket** — Supplies some restaurants; retail-grade frozen scallops
3. **Direct US import** — Some chefs order direct from US seafood distributors (Samuels, Sysco Specialty) via air freight
4. **Jacques Scott** — Primarily wine but does some food; unlikely scallop source

**The quality gap:** Most scallops arriving in Cayman are:
- Frozen at sea or in-plant (US or Chinese)
- Often treated with sodium tripolyphosphate (STP) — a water-retention chemical that inflates weight but degrades flavor and searing quality
- Unknown provenance — chefs don't know where they came from
- Inconsistent sizing and quality between shipments

**This is the opportunity.** Premium, chemical-free ("dry" or "dry-packed"), traceable Nova Scotia scallops with a provenance story would be a significant upgrade for every restaurant on the island.

### Estimated Demand

| Segment | # of Accounts | Weekly Volume (lbs) | Monthly Volume (lbs) |
|---------|---------------|--------------------|--------------------|
| Fine dining (Ritz, Seafire, Blue) | 3–4 | 20–40 | 80–160 |
| Upscale restaurants | 5–8 | 25–50 | 100–200 |
| Hotels (other) | 2–3 | 10–20 | 40–80 |
| Yacht provisioning | Variable | 5–15 | 20–60 |
| **Total** | **10–15** | **60–125 lbs** | **240–500 lbs** |

---

## 4. Competitor Analysis

### Current Seafood Distributors in Grand Cayman

| Distributor | Primary Business | Seafood Offering | Scallop Quality | Weakness |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Progressive Distributors** | Full-service broadline | Frozen seafood from US supply chain | Generic frozen — likely STP-treated, no provenance | Commodity product, no story |
| **Hurley's Marketplace** | Grocery/retail + some wholesale | Consumer-grade frozen seafood | Basic retail frozen | Not restaurant-grade premium |
| **Island Distributors** | Broadline food service | Standard frozen seafood | Unknown | Commodity |
| **Kirk Market** | Premium grocery | Higher-end frozen seafood retail | Better than average | Not B2B focused |
| **Direct imports (individual chefs)** | Ad hoc | Variable | Can be good but inconsistent | Expensive, unreliable, logistically painful |

### Scallop Product Comparison

| Product | Origin | Treatment | Size | Price (est. wholesale/lb) | Quality |
|---------|--------|-----------|------|--------------------------|---------|
| **Generic frozen scallops (Progressive)** | China/US mix | STP-treated ("wet") | 20/30–30/40 | CI$12–18 | ⭐⭐ |
| **US frozen sea scallops** | New Bedford, MA | May be STP or dry | 10/20–20/30 | CI$18–28 | ⭐⭐⭐ |
| **NS dry-packed scallops (Adams & Knickle)** | Lunenburg, NS | Chemical-free ("dry") | U/10–10/20 | CI$45–55 | ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ |

**Why "dry" matters:**
- STP-treated ("wet") scallops absorb 25–40% extra water weight — chefs pay for water
- Wet scallops steam in the pan instead of searing — they can't achieve the golden crust
- Dry scallops caramelize beautifully, have concentrated natural sweetness, and weigh what they should
- Fine dining chefs overwhelmingly prefer dry scallops — many refuse to use wet
- **Per usable pound, dry scallops are actually similar or better value than wet** despite the higher sticker price

### Competitive Advantage Summary

| Factor | Progressive/Generic | Adams & Knickle via 7 Cellars |
|--------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
| Product quality | Commodity | Premium, dry-packed |
| Provenance story | None | "127 years of Lunenburg fishing heritage" |
| Size | Small–medium | Large (U/10, 10/20) |
| Chemical treatment | Likely STP | Chemical-free |
| Sustainability | Unknown | MSC-certified fishery |
| Relationship | Transactional | Personal (Dwayne is local to NS) |
| Cross-sell | None | Wine pairings, tasting events |
| Consistency | Variable | Direct relationship = quality control |

---

## 5. Logistics & Cold Chain

### Shipping Route

**Recommended route: Lunenburg → Halifax → Miami → Grand Cayman**

| Leg | Method | Transit Time | Notes |
|-----|--------|-------------|-------|
| Lunenburg → Halifax | Refrigerated truck | 1.5 hours | Adams & Knickle or local carrier |
| Halifax → Miami | Air freight (AC Cargo, WestJet Cargo) | Same day / next day | Direct flights available; also Halifax → Toronto → Miami |
| Miami → Grand Cayman | Air freight (Cayman Airways Cargo, AA) | Same day / next day | Daily flights, ~1 hour |
| **Total transit** | | **2–3 days** | Door to door |

### Fresh vs IQF (Frozen)

| Factor | Fresh (Never Frozen) | IQF (Individually Quick Frozen) |
|--------|---------------------|--------------------------------|
| **Shelf life** | 5–7 days from harvest | 12–24 months |
| **Quality** | Highest — but degrades rapidly | Excellent — locked in at peak freshness |
| **Logistics risk** | Very high — any delay = loss | Low — temperature controlled |
| **Cost** | Higher (must air freight urgently) | Lower per unit (can batch ship) |
| **Chef preference** | Preferred if truly fresh | Widely accepted for premium IQF |
| **Recommendation** | Phase 2 (special orders only) | **Phase 1 — start here** |

**Recommendation: Start with IQF.** Modern IQF technology locks in quality at the moment of freezing. The product is vastly superior to generic frozen scallops and eliminates the spoilage risk of fresh. Premium restaurants worldwide use IQF scallops daily. Once the business is established and volume justifies it, explore fresh shipments for special occasions.

### Cold Chain Requirements

| Parameter | Requirement |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Storage temperature** | -18°C (0°F) or colder for IQF |
| **Fresh holding temp** | 0–2°C (32–35°F) |
| **Max temp excursion** | Never above -12°C for IQF in transit |
| **Packaging** | Insulated EPS boxes with gel packs or dry ice |
| **Temperature logging** | Data loggers in each shipment |
| **Storage at destination** | Commercial freezer (-18°C or colder) |

### Freight Cost Estimates

| Shipment Size | Air Freight (Halifax → Miami → GCM) | Per-Pound Freight Cost |
|---------------|--------------------------------------|----------------------|
| 50 lbs (small trial) | $400–$600 | $8–$12/lb |
| 100 lbs | $600–$900 | $6–$9/lb |
| 200 lbs | $900–$1,400 | $4.50–$7/lb |
| 500 lbs (container) | $1,500–$2,500 | $3–$5/lb |

**Scale matters.** Monthly shipments of 200–500 lbs bring freight costs down significantly. Consolidating with other 7 Cellars perishable imports (caviar, charcuterie) further reduces per-unit costs.

---

## 6. Regulatory Requirements

### Canadian Export Requirements (CFIA)

| Requirement | Details |
|---|---|
| **CFIA Health Certificate** | Required for all fish/seafood exports from Canada |
| **Establishment License** | Adams & Knickle must hold a CFIA-registered fish processing establishment license |
| **Product Inspection** | CFIA inspects and certifies exported seafood |
| **Labeling** | Species name, country of origin, net weight, lot/batch number |
| **Safe Food for Canadians Regulations (SFCR)** | Governs all food export from Canada |
| **Exporter registration** | Must be registered with CFIA as a food exporter |

**Adams & Knickle likely already has all of this** as an established exporter. Confirm during initial conversations.

### Cayman Islands Import Requirements

| Requirement | Details |
|---|---|
| **Department of Environmental Health (DEH)** | Food import permit required for all food/seafood imports |
| **Health certificate** | Must accompany each shipment (CFIA certificate accepted) |
| **Customs declaration** | Standard entry with accurate product description and value |
| **HS Code** | 0307.21 (frozen scallops) or 0307.29 (other scallops) |
| **Import duty** | ~22% on CIF value (standard food import rate) |
| **Labeling** | English language, country of origin, net weight, storage instructions |
| **Cold chain documentation** | Temperature records may be requested |

### Key Regulatory Contacts

| Contact | Purpose | Details |
|---------|---------|--------|
| **CFIA (Atlantic Region)** | Export health certificates | 1-800-442-2342 |
| **Cayman DEH** | Food import permits | (345) 949-6696 |
| **Cayman Customs** | Duty rates, clearance | customs.gov.ky |

**Good news:** Canada → Cayman Islands seafood export is relatively straightforward compared to EU or Asian imports. Canada has strong food safety credentials, and CFIA certificates are widely accepted.

---

## 7. Pricing & Margin Analysis

### Cost Buildup: Adams & Knickle Scallops to Grand Cayman

| Component | Per Pound (USD) | Per Pound (CI$) | Notes |
|-----------|----------------|-----------------|-------|
| **Dock price (Lunenburg)** | $12–$18 | $10–$15 | Wholesale, dry-packed, U/10 or 10/20 |
| **Packing & handling** | $1–$2 | $0.80–$1.60 | Insulated shipping boxes, gel packs |
| **Air freight (Halifax → GCM)** | $4–$7 | $3.30–$5.80 | Via Miami, 200+ lb shipments |
| **Customs brokerage** | $0.50–$1 | $0.40–$0.80 | Per-unit allocation |
| **Import duty (22% on CIF)** | $4–$6 | $3.30–$5 | 22% on (product + freight + insurance) |
| **Local handling & delivery** | $0.50–$1 | $0.40–$0.80 | Cold storage, on-island delivery |
| **Total landed cost** | **$22–$35** | **$18–$29** | Range depends on volume |

**At scale (200+ lbs/month):**

| Cost Component | Per Pound (CI$) |
|----------------|-----------------|
| Product (dock price) | $12.50 |
| Freight & handling | $6.00 |
| Duty (22%) | $4.10 |
| Local costs | $1.00 |
| **Total landed** | **$23.60** |

### Wholesale Pricing & Margins

| Product | Landed Cost (CI$/lb) | Wholesale Price (CI$/lb) | Gross Margin |
|---------|---------------------|-------------------------|-------------|
| **U/10 dry scallops (jumbo)** | $26–$32 | $50–$60 | 45–50% |
| **10/20 dry scallops (large)** | $22–$28 | $42–$50 | 40–45% |
| **20/30 dry scallops (medium)** | $18–$24 | $35–$42 | 40–45% |

### Price Comparison for Restaurants

| Source | Product | Restaurant Cost (CI$/lb) | Quality |
|--------|---------|-------------------------|---------|
| Progressive Distributors | Generic frozen (STP) | $15–$22 | ⭐⭐ |
| US direct import | Dry-packed sea scallops | $35–$45 | ⭐⭐⭐⭐ |
| **7 Cellars (A&K)** | **NS dry-packed premium** | **$42–$55** | **⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐** |

**Chef value proposition:** "Yes, they cost more per pound than wet scallops — but you're not paying for water. Per actual scallop meat, the price is closer than you think. And they sear perfectly every time."

---

## 8. Volume Estimates & Revenue Potential

### Year 1 Projections (Conservative)

| Quarter | Accounts | Monthly Volume (lbs) | Monthly Revenue (CI$) |
|---------|----------|---------------------|----------------------|
| Q1 (Launch) | 3–5 | 100–150 | $4,500–$7,500 |
| Q2 | 5–8 | 150–250 | $6,750–$12,500 |
| Q3 | 8–10 | 200–350 | $9,000–$17,500 |
| Q4 (High season) | 10–12 | 300–500 | $13,500–$25,000 |

| Metric | Conservative | Optimistic |
|--------|-------------|------------|
| **Year 1 Revenue** | **CI$150,000** | **CI$280,000** |
| **Gross Margin (40%)** | **CI$60,000** | **CI$112,000** |
| **Year 2 Revenue** | CI$300,000 | CI$500,000 |
| **Year 3 Revenue** | CI$450,000 | CI$750,000 |

### Revenue Per Account

| Account Type | Weekly Order (lbs) | Weekly Revenue (CI$) | Annual Revenue (CI$) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Fine dining (Blue, Seven) | 10–20 | $450–$1,000 | $23,000–$52,000 |
| Upscale restaurant (Luca, Brasserie) | 5–15 | $225–$750 | $11,700–$39,000 |
| Hotel F&B (Kimpton) | 8–15 | $360–$750 | $18,700–$39,000 |
| Yacht/private | 3–10 | $135–$500 | $7,000–$26,000 |

---

## 9. Risks & Mitigation

| Risk | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation |
|------|-----------|--------|------------|
| **Price resistance ("too expensive")** | Medium | Medium | Educate on dry vs wet value proposition; offer tasting/demo |
| **Supply disruption (weather, DFO closures)** | Medium | High | Maintain 2–4 weeks frozen buffer stock in Cayman; secondary supplier relationship |
| **Cold chain failure in transit** | Low | High | Temperature loggers, insured shipments, established cold freight partners |
| **Competition from cheaper product** | High | Medium | Differentiate on quality, story, and relationship — don't compete on price |
| **Low initial uptake** | Medium | Medium | Start small (3–5 accounts), prove concept, grow organically |
| **Chinese scallop price undercutting** | High | Low-Medium | Different product entirely — premium vs commodity; chefs know the difference |
| **Currency fluctuation (CAD/USD/CI$)** | Low | Low | CI$ pegged to USD; CAD fluctuation manageable |
| **Regulatory changes** | Low | Medium | Stay current with CFIA and DEH requirements |
| **Adams & Knickle supply commitment** | Medium | High | Build personal relationship; start with trial orders to prove demand |
| **Seasonality (Cayman low season May–Nov)** | High | Medium | Volume drops in summer but restaurants still operate; adjust order quantities |

### Seasonal Risk Management

| Cayman Season | Tourist Volume | Restaurant Volume | Strategy |
|---|---|---|---|
| **High (Dec–Apr)** | Peak | Peak | Maximum inventory, weekly shipments |
| **Shoulder (May, Nov)** | Moderate | Moderate | Bi-weekly shipments |
| **Low (Jun–Oct)** | Lower | Lower but steady | Monthly shipments, reduced inventory |

---

## 10. Cross-Sell Synergy

### The 7 Cellars Advantage

This is where the scallop play becomes truly powerful. 7 Cellars isn't just another seafood distributor — it's a luxury food & wine company with existing relationships.

### Wine + Scallop Pairings

| Scallop Preparation | Perfect Wine Pairing | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Pan-seared (classic) | Chablis, White Burgundy | Mineral, lean, lets the scallop shine |
| Scallop crudo / ceviche | Champagne, Brut sparkling | Acidity and bubbles with raw sweetness |
| Butter-basted | Meursault, oaked Chardonnay | Rich + rich |
| Scallop with truffle | Burgundy Blanc, Condrieu | Earthy pairing |
| Scallop risotto | Soave, Vermentino | Italian whites with Italian-style dishes |
| Grilled with citrus | Sauvignon Blanc, Albariño | Bright, fresh pairing |
| Bacon-wrapped | Pinot Noir, light red | Bridge the smoke |

### Marketing & Branding Angles

**"From Nova Scotia to Grand Cayman"** — This is a killer narrative:

- **Heritage:** 127 years of Lunenburg fishing history
- **Provenance:** Cold North Atlantic waters, sustainable MSC-certified fishery
- **Personal:** Dwayne's Nova Scotia roots — this isn't an anonymous supply chain, it's a personal connection
- **UNESCO:** Lunenburg is a UNESCO World Heritage Site — the scallops come from a storybook fishing village
- **Sustainability:** MSC certification, Canadian DFO management
- **Quality:** Dry-packed, chemical-free, jumbo Atlantic sea scallops

### Event Concepts

| Event | Format | Revenue | Purpose |
|---|---|---|---|
| **"Nova Scotia Scallop & Wine Dinner"** | 5-course tasting at partner restaurant | $150–$250/person × 30 guests = $4,500–$7,500 | Launch event, brand building |
| **"From Sea to Table"** | Chef demo + wine pairing at 7 Cellars or hotel venue | $100–$175/person | Ongoing quarterly event |
| **"Atlantic Night"** | Scallops + caviar + Champagne evening | $200–$350/person | Ultra-premium positioning |
| **Chef education sessions** | Private tastings for restaurant F&B teams | Cost of samples only | Account development, loyalty |

### Cross-Sell Revenue Lift

Adding scallops to the 7 Cellars portfolio creates multiple revenue multipliers:

- **Wine pull-through:** Restaurants using 7 Cellars scallops are stickier wine accounts
- **Caviar bundling:** Scallop + caviar orders on same delivery run
- **Gift/provisioning packages:** "NS Scallops + Champagne" yacht package
- **Menu consulting:** Help chefs design scallop + wine pairings → deeper relationship → more wine orders
- **Charcuterie combo:** Full luxury food program (wine + scallops + caviar + charcuterie) makes 7 Cellars indispensable

---

## 11. Action Plan

### Phase 1: Research & Relationship (Weeks 1–4)

- [ ] **Contact Adams & Knickle directly** — Introduce Dwayne, explain the opportunity, ask about wholesale/export capabilities
  - Visit in person if possible (Lunenburg is 1.5hr from Windsor)
  - Key questions: Do they sell IQF? What sizes? MOQ? Can they export to Caribbean?
  - Ask about CFIA export certification status
- [ ] **Request samples** — Get 10–20 lbs of IQF dry-packed scallops for chef tastings in Cayman
- [ ] **Contact Cayman DEH** — Confirm food import permit process for frozen Canadian scallops
  - Phone: (345) 949-6696
- [ ] **Contact Cayman Customs** — Confirm HS code and duty rate for frozen scallops
- [ ] **Identify cold freight partner** — Get quotes for Halifax → Miami → GCM air freight (cold chain)

### Phase 2: Trial Shipment (Weeks 4–8)

- [ ] **Ship trial order** — 50–100 lbs IQF scallops to Grand Cayman
- [ ] **Chef tastings** — Bring samples to 3–5 top restaurant targets (Blue by Eric Ripert, Luca, The Brasserie, Kimpton)
- [ ] **Validate cold chain** — Monitor temperature data from trial shipment
- [ ] **Confirm pricing** — Finalize landed costs, set wholesale pricing
- [ ] **Set up cold storage** — Ensure adequate commercial freezer capacity in Cayman

### Phase 3: Soft Launch (Weeks 8–16)

- [ ] **Onboard first 3–5 accounts** — Start with existing 7 Cellars wine clients
- [ ] **Establish regular shipping schedule** — Bi-weekly or monthly depending on volume
- [ ] **Create sales materials** — Product spec sheet, provenance story, pairing guide
- [ ] **Host launch dinner** — "Nova Scotia Scallop & Wine Dinner" at a partner restaurant
- [ ] **Set up reorder system** — Standing orders, weekly/bi-weekly delivery schedule

### Phase 4: Growth (Months 4–12)
