files.name: Premium Mixers Research
files.content:
# Premium Mixers & Non-Alcoholic Spirits

## Market Analysis for 7 Cellars — Grand Cayman

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 10, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, 7 Cellars

---

## TL;DR

Grand Cayman's premium mixer and non-alcoholic spirits market is **severely underserved** — Jacques Scott carries a limited Fever-Tree range (7 SKUs) and basic Angostura bitters, but nobody on-island is doing dedicated premium mixer distribution. No Seedlip, no Lyre's, no Q Mixers, no premium syrups, no craft bitters beyond Angostura. For 7 Cellars, this is the **perfect complement to the craft spirits business**: every bottle of gin, vodka, or whiskey sold needs a mixer. The category is entirely shelf-stable, ships ambient, delivers 40–60% gross margins, and creates a natural upsell with every spirits sale. Start with Fever-Tree (broader range than Jacques Scott carries), add Q Mixers and East Imperial as differentiated alternatives, then layer in Seedlip/Lyre's for non-alc, and premium bitters/syrups for the cocktail bar trade. Expected Year 1 revenue: **CI$120,000–240,000** with 45% blended margins.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Current Grand Cayman Landscape](#1-current-grand-cayman-landscape)
2. [Premium Tonic & Mixers](#2-premium-tonic--mixers)
3. [Non-Alcoholic Spirits](#3-non-alcoholic-spirits)
4. [Premium Sodas & Sparkling Water](#4-premium-sodas--sparkling-water)
5. [Cocktail Ingredients — Bitters, Syrups & Shrubs](#5-cocktail-ingredients--bitters-syrups--shrubs)
6. [Market Sizing & Demand Analysis](#6-market-sizing--demand-analysis)
7. [Margin Analysis](#7-margin-analysis)
8. [Logistics & Shipping](#8-logistics--shipping)
9. [Recommended Action Plan](#9-recommended-action-plan)
10. [Summary & Recommendations](#10-summary--recommendations)

---

## 1. Current Grand Cayman Landscape

The single most important finding: **nobody is doing this category well on Grand Cayman.** The market is fragmented across general retailers with no dedicated premium mixer distributor.

### What's Currently Available (Verified)

| Retailer | What They Carry | Gaps |
|---|---|---|
| **Jacques Scott** | Fever-Tree (7 SKUs: Mediterranean Tonic, Club Soda, Elderflower Tonic, Ginger Ale, Ginger Beer, Tonic Water, Sparkling Lime & Yuzu). Angostura bitters (Aromatic, Cocoa, Orange). Bittered Sling (Celery, Grapefruit & Hops — sold out). San Pellegrino (1L, 500ml, 250ml). Finest Call Grenadine. Fre NA wines. Clever NA cocktails. | No Q Mixers. No East Imperial. No Fentimans. No London Essence. No Seedlip/Lyre's. No craft syrups. No Fee Brothers/Scrappy's bitters. No Monin. |
| **Blackbeard's** | Standard mixers (Schweppes, Canada Dry). Basic bitters. | Purely commodity-level mixers. No premium segment. |
| **The Tasting Room** | Limited Fever-Tree for on-premise consumption. | Not a distribution channel — retail wine bar. |
| **Tortuga** | Mass-market tourist products. Rum focus. | Not relevant to premium mixer category. |
| **Foster's Food Fair** | Schweppes, Canada Dry tonic/soda. San Pellegrino. Basic juice mixers. | No premium tonic brands. No NA spirits. No craft cocktail ingredients. |
| **Kirk Market** | Similar to Foster's — mainstream sodas, basic mixers. San Pellegrino available. | Same gaps as Foster's. |
| **Hurley's** | Standard grocery mixer selection. | No premium differentiation. |
| **Cost-U-Less** | Bulk mainstream sodas. Canada Dry. | Big-box pricing, no premium. |
| **Progressive Distributors** | Sysco-style foodservice distribution to hotels/restaurants. Likely carries basic Schweppes/Canada Dry for on-trade. | Unknown premium mixer range — worth investigating as potential customer OR competitor. |

### Key Insight

**Fever-Tree is the ONLY premium mixer brand on Grand Cayman**, carried exclusively by Jacques Scott with just 7 SKUs at KYD $1.99/200ml bottle. The full Fever-Tree range has 20+ varieties. Beyond Fever-Tree, the island has nothing — no Q Mixers, no East Imperial, no Fentimans, no London Essence, no Thomas Henry.

**Non-alcoholic spirits are completely absent** from the island. No Seedlip, no Lyre's, no Monday, no Ritual Zero Proof.

**Premium cocktail ingredients are virtually nonexistent.** Jacques Scott has Angostura and Bittered Sling (mostly sold out). No Fee Brothers, no Scrappy's, no craft syrups, no Small Hand Foods, no Liber & Co.

**This is a wide-open market.**

---

## 2. Premium Tonic & Mixers

### Tier 1: Anchor Brands (Must-Have)

#### Fever-Tree

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2005, London |
| **Market Position** | World's #1 premium mixer. ~40% global premium mixer market share. |
| **Revenue** | £364M (2024). NYSE-listed. |
| **Key Products** | Indian Tonic, Mediterranean Tonic, Elderflower Tonic, Aromatic Tonic, Light Tonic, Ginger Beer, Ginger Ale, Club Soda, Sparkling Lime & Yuzu, Lemon Tonic, Cucumber Tonic, Smoky Ginger Ale, Blood Orange Ginger Beer, Spiced Orange Ginger Ale |
| **Island Status** | ⚠️ **ALREADY ON ISLAND** — Jacques Scott carries 7 SKUs at KYD $1.99/200ml |
| **Opportunity** | Jacques Scott carries only 7 of 20+ varieties. 7 Cellars could carry the FULL range including Light tonics, specialty flavors, and 500ml bottles. Also target restaurant/hotel on-trade which Jacques Scott doesn't serve well. |
| **US Wholesale** | ~$0.90–1.10/200ml bottle (case of 24). US distributor: Fever-Tree USA (NYC). |
| **Contact** | sales@fever-tree.com · fever-tree.com |

**Strategy:** Don't compete head-to-head with Jacques Scott on the same 7 SKUs. Instead, carry the **extended range** (Light tonics, specialty flavors, 500ml format) and focus on **restaurant/hotel distribution** where Jacques Scott is weak.

#### Q Mixers

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2012, Brooklyn, NY |
| **Market Position** | #2 premium mixer in US. Fastest-growing mixer brand. Strong craft cocktail credibility. |
| **Revenue** | ~$200M+ (2024). Acquired by Keurig Dr Pepper 2023. |
| **Key Products** | Spectacular Tonic, Light Tonic, Ginger Beer, Ginger Ale, Club Soda, Elderflower Tonic, Indian Tonic |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** — Complete gap |
| **Differentiator** | Higher carbonation than Fever-Tree. Less sweet. Preferred by US bartenders. |
| **US Wholesale** | ~$0.85–1.00/bottle (187ml, case of 24). National distribution via KDP network. |
| **Contact** | info@qmixers.com · qmixers.com |

**Why it matters:** Q Mixers is the bartender's choice in the US. Grand Cayman's cocktail bars (The Tillerman, Agua, Luca) would snap this up. First-mover advantage is significant.

### Tier 2: Differentiated Alternatives

#### East Imperial

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2013, New Zealand |
| **Market Position** | Ultra-premium, cocktail-bar-focused. Used by top hotel bars globally. |
| **Key Products** | Burma Tonic, Yuzu Tonic, Old World Tonic, Grapefruit Tonic, Manila Mango Soda, Thai Ginger Ale, Royal Botanic Tonic |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Differentiator** | 150ml bottle (perfect single-serve for cocktails — no waste). Botanical-forward. Luxury hotel positioning. |
| **US Wholesale** | ~$1.20–1.50/150ml bottle. US importer based in NYC. |
| **Contact** | hello@eastimperial.com · eastimperial.com |

**Why it matters:** The 150ml format is ideal for Ritz-Carlton, Kimpton Seafire, and fine dining bars. Zero waste, premium positioning. The luxury hotel channel would love this.

#### Fentimans

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 1905, Northumberland, England |
| **Market Position** | Heritage botanical brewer. Botanically brewed (not just carbonated + flavored). |
| **Key Products** | Premium Indian Tonic, Rose Lemonade, Ginger Beer, Victorian Lemonade, Curiosity Cola, Dandelion & Burdock, Elderflower |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Differentiator** | 7-day botanical brewing process. Unique flavor depth. Beautiful Victorian-style bottles — incredible shelf appeal. |
| **US Wholesale** | ~$1.00–1.30/275ml bottle (case of 24). |
| **Contact** | export@fentimans.com · fentimans.com |

#### London Essence Company

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2016, London (backed by Britvic) |
| **Market Position** | Distilled essences approach. Low calorie, clean flavor. |
| **Key Products** | Classic London Tonic, Grapefruit & Rosemary Tonic, Blood Orange & Elderflower Tonic, Bitter Orange & Elderflower Soda, Delicate London Ginger Ale |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Differentiator** | Uses distilled botanicals — lighter, more elegant. Only 20 calories. Designed to complement, not compete with spirits. |
| **US Wholesale** | ~$1.00–1.20/200ml bottle. |
| **Contact** | info@londonessenceco.com · londonessenceco.com |

#### Thomas Henry

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2010, Berlin, Germany |
| **Market Position** | Europe's premium mixer leader, especially in Germany/Austria. |
| **Key Products** | Tonic Water, Elderflower Tonic, Spicy Ginger, Cherry Blossom Tonic, Mystic Mango, Ginger Beer, Slim Tonic |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Differentiator** | German engineering precision. Clean flavors. Strong in European hotel trade. |
| **US Wholesale** | Limited US distribution — better sourced via European channels. |

### Brand Comparison Matrix

| Brand | Price Tier | Best For | Bottle Size | On Island? | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Fever-Tree** | Premium | Broadest range, brand recognition | 200ml, 500ml | ⚠️ Limited (Jacques Scott) | HIGH — expand range |
| **Q Mixers** | Premium | US bartender market, higher carbonation | 187ml, 6.7oz | ❌ No | HIGH — first mover |
| **East Imperial** | Ultra-Premium | Luxury hotels, fine dining | 150ml | ❌ No | HIGH — hotel channel |
| **Fentimans** | Premium | Heritage appeal, retail gifting | 275ml | ❌ No | MEDIUM |
| **London Essence** | Premium | Low-calorie, health-conscious | 200ml | ❌ No | MEDIUM |
| **Thomas Henry** | Premium | European clientele | 200ml | ❌ No | LOW (limited US distribution) |

---

## 3. Non-Alcoholic Spirits

This is a **completely unserved category** on Grand Cayman. The global NA spirits market is projected to reach $1.7B by 2028 (CAGR ~7%). Grand Cayman's high-end restaurant scene and health-conscious luxury tourist demographic make this a natural fit.

### Tier 1: Must-Have Brands

#### Seedlip

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2015, England |
| **Market Position** | Category creator. World's first distilled non-alcoholic spirit. Owned by Diageo since 2019. |
| **Key Products** | Garden 108 (herbal/floral), Grove 42 (citrus), Spice 94 (aromatic) |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Retail Price (US)** | $28–35/700ml |
| **Wholesale** | ~$14–18/bottle. Distributed by Diageo/Southern Glazer's. |
| **Restaurant Demand** | Very high — every fine dining restaurant globally now needs a NA cocktail option. Seedlip is the default choice. |
| **Contact** | Via Diageo/Southern Glazer's Caribbean distribution · seedlipdrinks.com |

**Why it matters:** Seedlip is the gold standard. When a Ritz-Carlton guest asks for a non-alcoholic cocktail, the bar needs Seedlip. It's the category's Fever-Tree. Diageo distribution may simplify Caribbean access.

#### Lyre's

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2019, Melbourne, Australia |
| **Market Position** | Broadest NA spirits range globally. 18+ varieties mimicking specific spirit categories. |
| **Key Products** | American Malt (whiskey), Dry London Spirit (gin), Italian Orange (Aperol), Dark Cane Spirit (rum), Italian Spritz, Classico (prosecco), Coffee Originale (coffee liqueur), Amaretti |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Retail Price (US)** | $25–30/700ml |
| **Wholesale** | ~$12–16/bottle. US distribution through own network + select distributors. |
| **Restaurant Demand** | High — the range means bars can replicate any classic cocktail in NA form (NA Negroni, NA Espresso Martini, etc.) |
| **Contact** | wholesale@lyres.com · lyres.com |

**Why it matters:** While Seedlip is category-defining, Lyre's is the practical workhorse. A bar can build an entire NA cocktail menu around Lyre's range. The Italian Orange (Aperol alternative) would sell extremely well in Cayman's aperitivo culture.

### Tier 2: Strong Alternatives

#### Monday

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2021, Los Angeles |
| **Market Position** | Lifestyle-focused NA gin and whiskey. Strong branding. |
| **Key Products** | Monday Gin, Monday Whiskey, Monday Mezcal |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Retail Price** | $35–40/750ml |
| **Wholesale** | ~$17–20/bottle |

#### Ritual Zero Proof

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2019, Chicago |
| **Market Position** | US-focused, spirit-for-spirit replacement. |
| **Key Products** | Whiskey Alternative, Tequila Alternative, Gin Alternative, Rum Alternative, Aperitif Alternative |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Retail Price** | $25–30/750ml |
| **Wholesale** | ~$12–15/bottle |

#### Free Spirits / Spiritless

| Detail | Info |
|---|---|
| **Founded** | 2020, various US |
| **Market Position** | Newer entrants, competitive pricing |
| **Key Products** | Free Spirits: Spirit of Gin, Spirit of Tequila. Spiritless: Kentucky 74 (bourbon), Jalisco 55 (tequila). |
| **Island Status** | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** |
| **Retail Price** | $28–35/750ml |

### NA Spirits Recommendation Matrix

| Brand | Range Breadth | Taste Quality | Brand Recognition | Restaurant Fit | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Seedlip** | 3 expressions | Excellent | Highest — category creator | Essential | HIGH |
| **Lyre's** | 18+ expressions | Very Good | Strong | Excellent — full menu | HIGH |
| **Monday** | 3 expressions | Good | Growing (LA lifestyle) | Good | MEDIUM |
| **Ritual Zero Proof** | 5 expressions | Good | Medium | Good | MEDIUM |
| **Spiritless** | 2 expressions | Very Good | Medium | Niche (bourbon/tequila) | LOW |

---

## 4. Premium Sodas & Sparkling Water

### Currently on Island

- **San Pellegrino** — Available at Jacques Scott (1L KYD $4.25, 500ml, 250ml) and grocery stores (Foster's, Kirk Market). Well-distributed.
- **Perrier** — Available at grocery stores. Standard sparkling.
- **Topo Chico** — Increasingly available at grocery stores.

### Gap Opportunities

#### Premium Italian Sparkling

| Brand | Origin | Key Products | Island Status | Why It Fits |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **San Pellegrino Specialty** (Aranciata, Limonata, Pompelmo) | Italy | Italian soda range: Blood Orange, Lemon, Grapefruit, Chinotto | ⚠️ Partially available (grocery stores may carry 1–2 flavors) | Complements Italian restaurant positioning. Higher margin than plain sparkling. |
| **Lurisia** | Piedmont, Italy | Premium sparkling water, Chinotto, Gazzosa, Tonica | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | Ultra-premium Italian. Eataly exclusive in US. Beautiful bottles. Pairs with fine dining. |
| **Galvanina** | Rimini, Italy | Organic sparkling sodas, Bio range, Italian craft sodas | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | Organic positioning. Stunning glass bottles. Restaurant-grade. |
| **Acqua Panna** | Tuscany, Italy | Still water (San Pellegrino's sister brand) | ⚠️ Likely available at hotels | Fine dining table water. |

#### Other Premium Sparkling

| Brand | Origin | Key Products | Island Status | Why It Fits |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Voss** | Norway | Still & sparkling in glass | ⚠️ Likely at upscale grocers | Upmarket water for retail/restaurants |
| **Topo Chico** | Mexico (Coca-Cola) | Hard mineral sparkling | ⚠️ Available at some stores | Already penetrating, not a gap |
| **Saratoga Spring** | USA | Premium still & sparkling in cobalt blue glass | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | Beautiful presentation for restaurants |
| **Mountain Valley** | USA (Arkansas) | Premium spring water in glass | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | US fine dining staple |

### Recommendation

San Pellegrino is well-served. The gap is in **specialty Italian sodas** (Lurisia, Galvanina) and **premium glass-bottle waters** for the restaurant trade. These ship easily alongside other shelf-stable products.

---

## 5. Cocktail Ingredients — Bitters, Syrups & Shrubs

This is the **most underserved sub-category** on Grand Cayman. Jacques Scott has only Angostura (3 SKUs) and Bittered Sling (mostly sold out). For syrups, they carry only Finest Call Grenadine. That's it.

### Premium Bitters

| Brand | Origin | Key Products | Price Range (US Retail) | Island Status | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Angostura** | Trinidad | Aromatic, Orange, Cocoa | $10–20/bottle | ✅ On island (Jacques Scott) | Already served |
| **Fee Brothers** | Rochester, NY (est. 1864) | Old Fashioned Aromatic, West Indian Orange, Peach, Aztec Chocolate, Celery, Plum, Black Walnut, Whiskey Barrel Aged, Rhubarb — 40+ varieties | $8–12/5oz bottle | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | **HIGH** — broadest range, essential for cocktail bars |
| **Scrappy's Bitters** | Seattle | Cardamom, Lavender, Black Lemon, Chocolate, Grapefruit, Celery, Orleans, Firewater | $15–20/5oz bottle | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | HIGH — craft cocktail credibility |
| **Bittermens** | Brooklyn, NY | Xocolatl Mole, Hellfire Habanero Shrub, 'Elemakule Tiki, Burlesque, Hopped Grapefruit, Transatlantic Modern Aromatic | $15–22/5oz bottle | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | MEDIUM — niche but exceptional |
| **Bittered Sling** | Vancouver | Cascade Celery, Grapefruit & Hops, Kensington Aromatic, Clingstone Peach, Malagasy Chocolate | $18–22/120ml | ⚠️ Listed at Jacques Scott (mostly sold out) | LOW — already partially served |
| **Regans' Orange Bitters No. 6** | USA | Orange bitters (industry standard) | $8–10/10oz | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | HIGH — bartender essential |
| **Peychaud's** | New Orleans | Aromatic bitters (essential for Sazerac) | $8–12/10oz | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | HIGH — cocktail essential |

### Premium Cocktail Syrups

| Brand | Origin | Key Products | Price Range (US Retail) | Island Status | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Small Hand Foods** | San Francisco | Gum Syrup, Grenadine, Pineapple Gum, Orgeat, Raspberry Gum | $12–15/8.5oz | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | HIGH — craft bar essential |
| **Liber & Co** | Austin, TX | Fiery Ginger Syrup, Classic Gum Syrup, Almond Orgeat, Caramelized Fig Syrup, Spiced Tonic Syrup, Tropical Passion Fruit | $12–16/9.5oz | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | HIGH — excellent range |
| **BG Reynolds** | Portland, OR | Tiki-focused: Orgeat, Falernum, Passion Fruit, Don's Mix, Grenadine | $10–14/375ml | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | MEDIUM — tiki/tropical cocktails |
| **Jack Rudy Cocktail Co** | Charleston, SC | Small Batch Tonic, Elderflower Tonic, Classic Grenadine | $10–14/17oz | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | MEDIUM — tonic concentrate is unique |
| **Monin** | France | 150+ flavors: Vanilla, Lavender, Elderflower, Passion Fruit, Hazelnut, etc. | $8–12/750ml | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** (not at Jacques Scott) | HIGH — industry workhorse |
| **Torani** | San Francisco | Similar range to Monin, more US-focused | $6–10/750ml | ❌ **NOT ON ISLAND** | MEDIUM — commodity alternative to Monin |

### Shrubs & Specialty

| Brand | Product | Price Range | Island Status | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Pok Pok Som** | Drinking vinegars: Tamarind, Honey, Apple, Thai Chile | $10–14/16oz | ❌ | LOW |
| **Shrub & Co** | Apple Cider Vinegar shrubs: Lemon & Lime, Ginger, Berry | $12–15/16oz | ❌ | LOW |
| **Dale DeGroff's Pimento Aromatic Bitters** | Premium aromatic bitters from cocktail legend | $18–22/5oz | ❌ | MEDIUM |

### Cocktail Ingredients Priority Matrix

| Product Category | Restaurant Demand | Margin | Competition on Island | Recommended Brands | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Craft bitters (beyond Angostura)** | Very High | 50–60% | Almost none | Fee Brothers, Scrappy's, Peychaud's | **HIGHEST** |
| **Premium cocktail syrups** | Very High | 45–55% | None (only Finest Call) | Small Hand Foods, Liber & Co, Monin | **HIGHEST** |
| **Tonic syrups/concentrates** | Medium | 50–60% | None | Jack Rudy, Liber & Co | MEDIUM |
| **Shrubs/drinking vinegars** | Low (growing) | 50–60% | None | Shrub & Co | LOW |

---

## 6. Market Sizing & Demand Analysis

### Grand Cayman Market Context

| Factor | Data |
|---|---|
| **Population** | ~85,000 residents |
| **Annual tourists** | ~500,000 stayover + 2M+ cruise passengers |
| **GDP per capita** | ~$100,000+ (one of world's highest) |
| **Fine dining restaurants** | 30–40 with active cocktail programs |
| **Luxury hotels** | 5–8 major properties (Ritz-Carlton, Kimpton, Westin, Marriott, Palm Heights) |
| **Bars with cocktail programs** | 15–25 |
| **Yacht & villa provisioning** | Significant — superyacht destination |

### Addressable Market Segments

#### Segment 1: Restaurant & Hotel On-Trade (60% of revenue)

| Customer Type | # of Accounts | Monthly Spend (est.) | Annual Revenue |
|---|---|---|---|
| Fine dining restaurants | 10–15 | $500–1,500/month | $60,000–270,000 |
| Luxury hotels (F&B) | 4–6 | $1,000–3,000/month | $48,000–216,000 |
| Cocktail bars | 8–12 | $300–800/month | $28,800–115,200 |
| **Subtotal** | **22–33** | | **$136,800–$601,200** |

#### Segment 2: Retail & Off-Trade (25% of revenue)

| Customer Type | # of Accounts | Monthly Spend (est.) | Annual Revenue |
|---|---|---|---|
| Wine/spirits shops (own retail) | 1 (7 Cellars) | $2,000–5,000/month | $24,000–60,000 |
| Grocery stores | 3–5 | $500–1,000/month | $18,000–60,000 |
| **Subtotal** | **4–6** | | **$42,000–$120,000** |

#### Segment 3: Private & Yacht (15% of revenue)

| Customer Type | Volume | Annual Revenue |
|---|---|---|
| Yacht provisioning | 50–100 orders/year | $25,000–75,000 |
| Private clients/villa rental | 100–200 orders/year | $20,000–50,000 |
| Corporate events | 20–40 events/year | $10,000–30,000 |
| **Subtotal** | | **$55,000–$155,000** |

### Conservative Year 1 Estimate

Not all segments captured immediately. Realistic Year 1 ramp:

| Quarter | Revenue | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| Q1 | $15,000–25,000 | Launch, first 5–10 restaurant accounts |
| Q2 | $25,000–45,000 | Hotel accounts secured, retail launched |
| Q3 | $30,000–55,000 | Word of mouth, reorders building |
| Q4 | $50,000–80,000 | High season (Dec–Mar), yacht provisioning |
| **Year 1 Total** | **$120,000–$205,000** | |

### Global Market Trends Supporting This Category

| Trend | Data |
|---|---|
| Premium mixer market (global) | $12.8B by 2028, CAGR 5.4% |
| Non-alcoholic spirits (global) | $1.7B by 2028, CAGR 7.0% |
| "Sober curious" consumers | 31% of US adults reducing alcohol (Gallup 2024) |
| Premium tonic as % of total tonic | Growing from ~15% to ~35% (2019–2026) |
| Restaurant NA cocktail menus | 65% of fine dining now offers NA cocktails (NRA 2025) |

---

## 7. Margin Analysis

### Markup Structure by Channel

| Channel | Typical Markup over Landed Cost | Gross Margin |
|---|---|---|
| Restaurant/hotel wholesale | 30–50% | 25–35% |
| Retail (own store) | 60–100% | 40–50% |
| Private/yacht provisioning | 80–120% | 45–55% |
| Bundle/gift sets | 100–150% | 50–60% |

### Cost Buildup Example: Fever-Tree Tonic (200ml)

| Component | Per Bottle |
|---|---|
| US wholesale cost | $0.95 |
| Shipping (allocated, Miami → GCM) | $0.08 |
| Customs duty (22% of CIF) | $0.23 |
| Local handling/storage | $0.04 |
| **Total landed cost** | **$1.30** |
| **Restaurant wholesale price** | **$1.75 (35% margin)** |
| **Retail price** | **$2.40 (~KYD $2.00) (46% margin)** |

**Benchmark:** Jacques Scott retails Fever-Tree at KYD $1.99/200ml. 7 Cellars can match or slightly undercut for wholesale while maintaining healthy margins.

### Cost Buildup Example: Seedlip (700ml)

| Component | Per Bottle |
|---|---|
| US wholesale cost | $16.00 |
| Shipping (allocated) | $0.50 |
| Customs duty (22%) | $3.63 |
| Local handling | $0.30 |
| **Total landed cost** | **$20.43** |
| **Restaurant wholesale price** | **$28.00 (37% margin)** |
| **Retail price** | **$38.00 (46% margin)** |

### Blended Margin Projection

| Category | % of Revenue | Avg Margin | Weighted Contribution |
|---|---|---|---|
| Premium mixers/tonic | 45% | 38% | 17.1% |
| Non-alcoholic spirits | 15% | 45% | 6.8% |
| Bitters & cocktail ingredients | 25% | 50% | 12.5% |
| Premium sodas/sparkling | 15% | 35% | 5.3% |
| **Blended Gross Margin** | | | **41.7%** |

---

## 8. Logistics & Shipping

### The Good News: Everything Ships Ambient

Unlike caviar or fresh cheese, **this entire category is shelf-stable**. No cold chain required. No special permits (except standard food import). Long shelf lives (12–24 months for most products).

### Shipping Parameters

| Parameter | Requirement |
|---|---|
| **Temperature** | Ambient (15–25°C). Avoid extreme heat (>35°C) for extended periods. |
| **Format** | Cases of 4, 6, 12, or 24 depending on product |
| **Weight** | Glass bottles — heavy per unit. Plan pallets carefully. |
| **Fragility** | Glass = breakage risk. Proper cushioning/packaging essential. |
| **Shelf life** | Mixers: 12–18 months. Bitters: 3–5 years. Syrups: 12–24 months. NA spirits: 18–24 months. |

### Recommended Shipping Routes

| Route | Method | Transit | Cost (per pallet) | Best For |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **US Supplier → Miami → GCM (air)** | Air freight | 1–2 days | $200–500 | Urgent restock, small orders |
| **US Supplier → Miami → GCM (sea)** | Container/LCL | 5–10 days | $80–150 | Regular bulk orders |
| **UK/EU → Miami → GCM** | Ocean + transship | 18–25 days | $150–300 | Fentimans, London Essence, Thomas Henry |
| **Consolidated with wine shipments** | Existing logistics | Same as wine | Marginal add-on cost | **IDEAL — piggyback on existing containers** |

### Key Logistics Advantage

7 Cellars already ships wine from the US and Europe to Grand Cayman. **Mixers, bitters, and syrups can ride alongside wine** in the same containers at marginal incremental cost. This is a massive logistics advantage over a standalone mixer distributor.

### Import Requirements

| Requirement | Details |
|---|---|
| **Trade & Business License** | Already held by 7 Cellars |
| **Food import permit** | Department of Environmental Health (DEH) — straightforward for shelf-stable beverages |
| **Customs duty** | 22% on CIF value (standard food import rate) |
| **Labeling** | English labels required. Most US/UK products already comply. |
| **No CITES** | Not applicable (no animal products) |
| **No special permits** | Non-alcoholic products don't require liquor licenses |

### Storage

Standard warehouse storage. No refrigeration needed. Just keep dry, out of direct sunlight. **Can share space with existing 7 Cellars wine/spirits warehouse.**

---

## 9. Recommended Action Plan

### Phase 1: Foundation (Months 1–2)

**Target: Secure suppliers, place first order**

- [ ] Contact Fever-Tree USA for Caribbean wholesale pricing on full range (20+ SKUs)
  - Focus on varieties Jacques Scott doesn't carry (Light tonics, Cucumber, Smoky Ginger Ale, Aromatic Tonic)
  - Ask about 500ml format for restaurant/hotel use
- [ ] Contact Q Mixers (info@qmixers.com) — establish wholesale account
  - Emphasize first-to-market in Cayman Islands
  - Request introductory pricing / sample cases
- [ ] Contact East Imperial (hello@eastimperial.com) — luxury hotel positioning
- [ ] Contact Seedlip/Diageo Caribbean distribution — inquire about territory availability
  - May already be in Diageo's Caribbean portfolio → check Southern Glazer's
- [ ] Contact Lyre's wholesale (wholesale@lyres.com) — request Caribbean pricing
- [ ] Order sample sets of Fee Brothers, Scrappy's, Liber & Co, Small Hand Foods
- [ ] Contact Monin USA for Caribbean distribution terms


---

files.content:
# 7 Cellars — Pricing Matrix & Landed Cost Calculator Guide

**Last Updated:** February 11, 2026  
**Companion File:** `pricing-matrix.csv` (Google Sheets-ready)

---

## Table of Contents

1. [How to Use This Tool](#1-how-to-use-this-tool)
2. [Cost Components Explained](#2-cost-components-explained)
3. [Cayman Islands Import Duty Rates](#3-cayman-islands-import-duty-rates)
4. [Shipping Cost Estimates](#4-shipping-cost-estimates)
5. [Markup Strategy by Category](#5-markup-strategy-by-category)
6. [Competitor Pricing Context](#6-competitor-pricing-context)
7. [Break-Even Analysis](#7-break-even-analysis)
8. [Google Sheets Formulas](#8-google-sheets-formulas)
9. [Key Assumptions & Notes](#9-key-assumptions--notes)

---

## 1. How to Use This Tool

1. **Import `pricing-matrix.csv` into Google Sheets** (File → Import → Upload)
2. **Replace FOB costs** with actual supplier quotes as you get them
3. **Adjust shipping costs** based on your actual freight quotes (see Section 4)
4. **Formulas auto-calculate** landed cost, wholesale, and retail prices
5. **Use this for every purchasing decision** — if the margins don't work on paper, don't buy it

### Quick Decision Framework
- **Wholesale gross margin < 20%** → Don't carry (or negotiate better FOB)
- **Wholesale gross margin 20–30%** → Carry only if strategic (fills a gap, drives other sales)
- **Wholesale gross margin 30%+** → Core portfolio product
- **Retail gross margin < 35%** → Retail-only if high volume
- **Retail gross margin 45%+** → Prioritize retail channel

---

## 2. Cost Components Explained

### FOB Cost (Free On Board)
The supplier's price at their shipping point (e.g., winery gate in Bordeaux, warehouse in Miami). This is your base cost before any logistics.

**Negotiation levers:**
- Volume commitments (annual purchase agreements)
- Payment terms (net 30/60 vs. prepay)
- Exclusive distribution rights for Cayman
- Mixed pallets vs. full pallets

### Shipping Cost per Unit
The freight cost allocated to each unit. Varies dramatically by method:
- **Sea freight (container):** Cheapest per unit, 3–6 week transit
- **Air freight:** 5–10× more expensive, 1–3 day transit
- **LCL (Less than Container Load):** Middle ground, shared container

### Insurance
Typically 1–2% of CIF (Cost + Insurance + Freight) value. Marine cargo insurance covers loss/damage in transit. **Use 1.5% as default for most goods; 2% for perishables/fragile.**

### Import Duty
**This is the most critical cost component for Cayman Islands importers.** See Section 3 for detailed rates.

### Landed Cost
**Landed Cost = FOB + Shipping + Insurance + Import Duty**

This is your true cost basis. All markup calculations should be based on landed cost, never FOB.

---

## 3. Cayman Islands Import Duty Rates

**Source:** Customs Tariff Act (2023 Revision), Cayman Islands Customs & Border Control, PwC Tax Summaries

### ⚠️ CRITICAL: Alcohol Duty Is Per-Litre (Specific), NOT Ad Valorem

Unlike most goods (which are 22% of value), **alcohol is taxed per litre at specific rates.** This is a huge advantage for premium products — a $100 bottle of wine pays the same duty as a $10 bottle.

| Product | Duty Rate | Per Unit (750ml) | Notes |
|---------|-----------|-----------------|-------|
| **Still Wine** (≤14% ABV) | ~CI$5.50/litre | ~CI$4.13/bottle | Confirms wine is per-litre specific duty |
| **Sparkling Wine/Champagne** | ~CI$9.50/litre | ~CI$7.13/bottle | Higher rate for sparkling |
| **Spirits** (>22% ABV) | ~CI$15.98/litre | ~CI$11.99/bottle (750ml) | Highest alcohol rate |
| **Beer** | ~CI$1.95/litre | ~CI$0.65/can (330ml) | Lowest alcohol rate |
| **Liqueurs** (15–22% ABV) | ~CI$8.00–12.00/litre | Varies | Mid-range |

**Key insight:** Per-litre specific duty means **premium wines and spirits have LOWER effective duty rates** as a percentage. A $50 wine pays ~8% effective duty, while a $10 wine pays ~41%.

### Food & Non-Alcoholic Goods: 22% Ad Valorem

| Category | Duty Rate | Basis | Notes |
|----------|-----------|-------|-------|
| **Cheese** | 22% | CIF value | Same as general goods |
| **Cured Meats/Charcuterie** | 22% | CIF value | May require USDA/EU health certificate |
| **Olive Oil** | 22% | CIF value | Ships ambient with wine |
| **Caviar** | 22% | CIF value | CITES permit required for sturgeon roe |
| **Coffee** | 22% | CIF value | Shelf-stable, ambient shipping |
| **Chocolate** | 22% | CIF value | Temperature-sensitive; air freight preferred |
| **Wagyu/Beef** | 22% | CIF value | Frozen; requires import permit |
| **Scallops/Seafood** | 22% | CIF value | Frozen; requires import permit |
| **Mixers/Soft Drinks** | 22% | CIF value | Non-alcoholic = standard rate |
| **Non-Alc Spirits** | 22% | CIF value | Classified as beverage, not alcohol |
| **Books** | 0% (Free) | — | Duty-free |

### Environmental Protection Fee
An additional **CI$0.50–1.00 per item** may apply on certain packaged goods (glass bottles, etc.). Factor this into high-volume calculations.

---

## 4. Shipping Cost Estimates

### Sea Freight (Primary Method)

| Container | Dimensions | Capacity (wine cases) | Cost (US→Cayman) | Per Case (12 btls) |
|-----------|------------|----------------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| **20ft Standard** | 5.9m × 2.4m × 2.4m | ~1,000–1,200 cases | $3,500–$5,000 | $3.50–$5.00 |
| **40ft Standard** | 12m × 2.4m × 2.4m | ~2,000–2,400 cases | $5,500–$7,500 | $2.75–$3.75 |
| **40ft Reefer** | 12m × 2.4m × 2.4m | ~1,800–2,000 cases | $8,000–$12,000 | $4.50–$6.00 |

**Per-bottle breakdown (20ft container, ~1,100 cases):**
- Container cost: ~$4,000
- Per case: ~$3.64
- **Per bottle: ~$0.30**

**⚠️ But!** You rarely fill a whole container with one product. LCL (shared container) rates run $0.80–$1.50 per bottle. Use **$1.50/bottle as conservative estimate** for planning.

### Air Freight (Rush Orders, Perishables)

| Route | Rate per kg | Per Wine Bottle (~1.3kg) | Per Caviar Tin (0.2kg) |
|-------|-------------|--------------------------|----------------------|
| **Miami → Grand Cayman** | $2.50–$4.00/kg | $3.25–$5.20 | $0.50–$0.80 |
| **Europe → Grand Cayman** (via Miami) | $4.00–$7.00/kg | $5.20–$9.10 | $0.80–$1.40 |
| **Japan → Grand Cayman** (Wagyu) | $6.00–$10.00/kg | N/A | N/A |

**When to air freight:**
- Perishables (caviar, scallops, Wagyu) — always
- Rush restock of fast-selling items
- Low-weight/high-value items (chocolate, coffee samples)
- **Never** for bulk wine/spirits — sea freight only

### Consolidation via Miami
Most European and Asian goods should consolidate through a **Miami bonded warehouse** before final shipment to Grand Cayman. This is standard for Caribbean distribution.

- Miami consolidation fee: $50–$150 per pallet
- Allows combining European wine + US spirits + food items in one container
- **Key contact:** Research freight forwarders with Cayman Islands routes (Thompson Shipping, Tropical Shipping)

---

## 5. Markup Strategy by Category

### Wine (Core Business — 60% of Revenue Target)

| Tier | FOB Range | Wholesale Markup | Retail Markup | Strategy |
|------|-----------|-----------------|---------------|----------|
| **Entry Premium** | $8–$15 | 35% | 80% | Volume driver; restaurant house pours |
| **Mid-Premium** | $15–$30 | 30–35% | 70–80% | Core portfolio; somm selections |
| **Ultra-Premium** | $30–$80+ | 25–30% | 55–70% | Prestige; lower markup, higher $ margin |

**Wine advantage:** Per-litre specific duty means premium wines have the **best margin structure** of any category. A $50 Barolo pays the same ~$4.13 duty as a $10 Chianti.

### Spirits

| Tier | FOB Range | Wholesale Markup | Retail Markup | Strategy |
|------|-----------|-----------------|---------------|----------|
| **Craft/Standard** | $15–$30 | 30% | 60–65% | Fill Jacques Scott gaps |
| **Premium** | $30–$60 | 25–30% | 55–60% | Japanese whisky, craft gin |
| **Ultra-Premium** | $60+ | 20–25% | 45–55% | Allocated/rare; collector market |

**Spirits note:** Higher per-litre duty ($15.98/L) means tight margins on cheap spirits. Focus on $25+ FOB products where duty is <50% of cost.

### Food Categories (Charcuterie, Cheese, Oil, Coffee, Chocolate)

| Category | Wholesale Markup | Retail Markup | Key Insight |
|----------|-----------------|---------------|-------------|
| **Hard Cheese** | 40% | 100% | Shelf-stable anchor; Parmigiano is flagship |
| **Cured Meats** | 40% | 100% | Vacuum-sealed ships ambient |
| **Olive Oil** | 45–55% | 100–130% | No competition; highest margin food |
| **Coffee** | 25–40% | 75–90% | Wholesale foodservice = volume; retail = margin |
| **Chocolate** | 45–50% | 120% | Gift/seasonal; yacht provisioning |
| **Truffle/Pantry** | 50% | 120–200% | Gift boxes can be 200%+ markup |

### Perishables (Caviar, Wagyu, Scallops)

| Category | Wholesale Markup | Retail Markup | Key Insight |
|----------|-----------------|---------------|-------------|
| **Caviar** | 35–40% | 80–100% | Air freight + cold chain; target 40–60% gross |
| **Wagyu** | 25–30% | 50–60% | Restaurant-only; prestige product |
| **Scallops** | 35% | 65–70% | Frozen air freight; Nova Scotia story |

### Mixers & Non-Alcoholic

| Category | Wholesale Markup | Retail Markup | Key Insight |
|----------|-----------------|---------------|-------------|
| **Premium Mixers** | 45% | 100% | Upsell with every spirits sale |
| **NA Spirits** | 35% | 70% | Growing category; health-conscious market |

---

## 6. Competitor Pricing Context

### Jacques Scott (Main Competitor — ~540 Spirits SKUs)
**Average Cayman markup vs US retail: 1.8–1.9×**

| Product | US Retail | Jacques Scott (USD) | JS Markup |
|---------|-----------|-------------------|-----------|
| 1792 Small Batch | $30 | $58 | 1.93× |
| Foursquare 2010 | $60 | $101 | 1.68× |
| Diplomático Reserva | $35 | $66 | 1.89× |
| Woodford Reserve | $35 | $59 | 1.69× |
| Fernet-Branca | $25 | $82 | 3.28× |

**7 Cellars target: 1.5–1.7× US retail** → Undercuts Jacques Scott by 10–15% while maintaining healthy margins.

### Fever-Tree (Only Premium Mixer on Island)
- Jacques Scott: 7 SKUs at KYD $1.99/200ml
- **7 Cellars opportunity:** Carry full 20+ variety range, plus Q Mixers and East Imperial as alternatives

### Food/Specialty (No Real Competition)
- **Foster's Food Fair:** Parmigiano Reggiano at CI$30–40/kg (7 Cellars landed cost: ~CI$16/kg)
- **Olive Oil:** Only mass-market brands (Bertolli, Colavita) at grocery stores
- **Caviar:** No dedicated supplier
- **Italian Coffee:** Only retail tins at Foster's/Kirk at 3–4× proper wholesale pricing

---

## 7. Break-Even Analysis

### Monthly Fixed Costs (Estimated)
| Item | Monthly (KYD) |
|------|--------------|
| Warehouse/storage | $2,500 |
| Vehicle/delivery | $1,500 |
| Insurance (business) | $500 |
| Licenses/permits | $300 |
| Marketing | $1,000 |
| Admin/misc | $700 |
| **Total Fixed** | **$6,500** |

### Break-Even by Category

| Category | Avg Gross Margin (Blended) | Monthly Revenue to Cover Fixed | Monthly Units Needed |
|----------|--------------------------|-------------------------------|---------------------|
| Wine | 35% | $18,571 | ~540 bottles @ KYD$34 avg |
| Spirits | 30% | $21,667 | ~430 bottles @ KYD$50 avg |
| Charcuterie/Cheese | 40% | $16,250 | ~650 kg @ KYD$25 avg |
| Olive Oil | 45% | $14,444 | ~520 bottles @ KYD$28 avg |
| Coffee | 35% | $18,571 | ~530 kg @ KYD$35 avg |
| Caviar | 45% | $14,444 | ~340 tins @ KYD$42 avg |

**Note:** These are standalone break-evens. In reality, all categories share fixed costs, so the combined break-even is ~KYD$6,500 ÷ 36% blended margin = **~KYD$18,000/month** (~$22,000 USD).

### Path to $5M Revenue (3-Year Goal)

| Year | Monthly Revenue (KYD) | Annual (KYD) | Annual (USD) |
|------|----------------------|-------------|-------------|
| **Year 1** | $25,000–$35,000 | $300K–$420K | $366K–$512K |
| **Year 2** | $80,000–$120,000 | $960K–$1.44M | $1.17M–$1.76M |
| **Year 3** | $280,000–$350,000 | $3.4M–$4.2M | $4.1M–$5.1M |

**Key growth drivers:**
1. Hotel/restaurant account wins (Ritz, Kimpton, Marriott)
2. Yacht provisioning contracts
3. Expanding from wine/spirits into full food portfolio
4. Online ordering / delivery for HNW residents

---

## 8. Google Sheets Formulas

Import the CSV, then replace static values with these formulas. **Assumes columns A through Q.**

### Column Layout
| Col | Header | Type |
|-----|--------|------|
| A | Category | Text |
| B | Product/Brand | Text |
| C | Unit Size | Text |
| D | FOB Cost (USD) | **INPUT** |
| E | Shipping Cost/Unit (USD) | **INPUT** |
| F | Insurance (% of value) | **INPUT** (decimal, e.g., 0.015) |
| G | Import Duty Rate | **INPUT** (text for specific; decimal for %) |
| H | Import Duty Amount (USD) | **FORMULA** |
| I | Landed Cost (USD) | **FORMULA** |
| J | Landed Cost (KYD) | **FORMULA** |
| K | Wholesale Markup (%) | **INPUT** |
| L | Wholesale Price (KYD) | **FORMULA** |
| M | Retail Markup (%) | **INPUT** |
| N | Retail Price (KYD) | **FORMULA** |
| O | Gross Margin Wholesale (%) | **FORMULA** |
| P | Gross Margin Retail (%) | **FORMULA** |
| Q | Notes | Text |

### Formulas (Row 2 as example)

**H2 — Import Duty Amount:**
For ad valorem (22%) food items:
```
=(D2+E2)*(1+F2)*0.22
```
For specific-rate alcohol, enter the per-unit duty amount manually or use a lookup:
```
=IF(OR(A2="Wine",A2="Champagne/Sparkling",A2="Spirits"), [manual entry], (D2+E2)*(1+F2)*0.22)
```

**I2 — Landed Cost (USD):**
```
=D2+E2+(D2+E2)*F2+H2
```

**J2 — Landed Cost (KYD):**
```
=I2/1.22
```
*(USD to KYD: divide by 1.22, since 1 KYD = 1.22 USD)*

**L2 — Wholesale Price (KYD):**
```
=J2*(1+K2)
```

**N2 — Retail Price (KYD):**
```
=J2*(1+M2)
```

**O2 — Gross Margin Wholesale (%):**
```
=(L2-J2)/L2
```
*(This gives the margin as a %. Format cell as percentage.)*

**P2 — Gross Margin Retail (%):**
```
=(N2-J2)/N2
```

### Helper: KYD ↔ USD Conversion
Put the exchange rate in a named cell (e.g., `$R$1 = 1.22`) and reference it:
```
=I2/$R$1    (USD to KYD)
=J2*$R$1    (KYD to USD)
```

### Helper: Alcohol Duty Lookup
Create a reference table on a separate sheet:

| Type | Duty per Litre (CI$) |
|------|---------------------|
| Still Wine | 5.50 |
| Sparkling Wine | 9.50 |
| Spirits | 15.98 |
| Beer | 1.95 |
| Liqueurs | 10.00 |

Then use VLOOKUP to auto-calculate:
```
=VLOOKUP(A2, DutyRates!A:B, 2, FALSE) * [volume in litres]
```

---

## 9. Key Assumptions & Notes

### Exchange Rate
- **1 KYD = 1.22 USD** (pegged rate; Cayman dollar is pegged to USD)
- This rate is stable — no currency risk

### Duty Rates
- Alcohol duty rates are **specific (per litre)**, sourced from Cayman Islands Customs Tariff Act and caymanresident.com. Rates shown are approximate — **confirm with your customs broker for exact rates** before placing large orders.
- Food/non-alcoholic duty is **22% ad valorem** on CIF value (PwC Tax Summaries)
- Rates may change; check gov.ky/web/cbc for updates

### Shipping Estimates
- Based on typical Miami → Grand Cayman rates
- Actual quotes will vary by season, fuel surcharges, and volume
- Get quotes from: **Tropical Shipping, Thompson Shipping, Cayman Express**

### What's NOT Included
- **Customs broker fees:** ~$50–$150 per entry (budget monthly)
- **Warehouse handling:** Internal cost, covered in fixed overhead
- **Breakage allowance:** Budget 1–2% for wine/spirits
- **Payment terms cost:** If you prepay, consider opportunity cost of capital
- **Marketing/sampling:** Budget 5–10% of revenue for trade tastings and samples

### Temperature Considerations
- **Ambient shipping OK:** Wine, spirits, olive oil, coffee, chocolate (winter), cured meats, cheese, mixers
- **Reefer container needed:** Chocolate (summer), butter-based products
- **Air freight + cold chain required:** Caviar, Wagyu, scallops, fresh cheese

---

## Quick Reference: The 7 Cellars Advantage

| Factor | 7 Cellars | Jacques Scott |
|--------|-----------|--------------|
| **Spirits SKUs** | 40+ exclusive brands | ~540 (mostly mainstream) |
| **Food portfolio** | Full Italian specialty | None |
| **Pricing** | 1.5–1.7× US retail | 1.8–1.9× US retail |
| **Service** | Personal, sommelier-led | Retail store model |
| **Target** | HNW, luxury hotels, yachts | General market |

---

*This is a living document. Update duty rates annually, refresh competitor pricing quarterly, and adjust markups based on actual sales data.*

files.name: Private Event Wine Packages
files.content:
# Private Event Wine Packages — Full Playbook

## A Launch Guide for 7 Cellars, Grand Cayman

**Prepared by:** Reece (Research Agent)
**Date:** February 20, 2026
**For:** Dwayne Schofield, Roberto Logioia & Tallyn — 7 Cellars

---

## TL;DR

Private event wine packages represent a high-margin, relationship-driven revenue stream perfectly suited to 7 Cellars' positioning as Grand Cayman's premium wine importer. Three tiers — The Gathering ($250–400), The Celebration ($800–1,200), and The Grand Affair ($2,000+) — target villa guests, wedding parties, and corporate groups through referral partnerships with villa companies, event planners, and hotel concierges. With Roberto's sommelier expertise as the differentiator and a 10% referral commission for partners, conservative projections show $4,500/month within 6 months, scaling to $12,000+/month in peak season. Launch requires minimal capital — just sales materials, a tasting kit, and 4 weeks of relationship building.

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Package Design — Three Tiers](#1-package-design--three-tiers)
2. [Target Market — Grand Cayman](#2-target-market--grand-cayman)
3. [Revenue Model & Projections](#3-revenue-model--projections)
4. [Execution Playbook — Roberto & Tallyn](#4-execution-playbook--roberto--tallyn)
5. [Sales Materials — Draft Copy](#5-sales-materials--draft-copy)
6. [Sources](#6-sources)

---

## 1. Package Design — Three Tiers

### 1A. The Gathering — $250–$400

**The occasion:** Intimate dinner parties, villa nights, couples' evenings, small birthday dinners.

**Guests:** 4–8 people.

| Component | Details |
|---|---|
| **Wines Included** | 3–4 bottles: 1 sparkling (welcome pour), 1 white, 1–2 reds |
| **Wine Style** | Premium-tier selections ($25–$45 retail per bottle) |
| **Delivery** | Free delivery to villa/hotel, same-day if ordered by 2pm |
| **Setup** | Wines pre-chilled, delivered with tasting notes card |
| **Sommelier** | Not included (available as upsell, +$150/hr) |
| **Glassware** | Not included (available as upsell, +$50 for 8 stems) |
| **Ice & Cooler** | Included — insulated bag with ice |
| **Target Margin** | 55–65% gross margin |
| **COGS Estimate** | $90–$150 in wine + $10–15 delivery |

**Upsell opportunities:**
- Add a cheese/charcuterie board pairing guide (+$25)
- Upgrade to reserve-level wines (+$75–$150)
- Add Roberto's personal tasting notes video (pre-recorded, +$0 cost, premium feel)
- Glassware rental (+$50)
- Second delivery for "nightcap" course (+$100)

---

### 1B. The Celebration — $800–$1,200

**The occasion:** Milestone birthdays, anniversaries, engagement parties, corporate dinners, holiday gatherings.

**Guests:** 10–25 people.

| Component | Details |
|---|---|
| **Wines Included** | 8–14 bottles: 2 sparkling, 3–4 whites, 4–6 reds, 1 dessert wine |
| **Wine Style** | Mix of premium ($30–$50) and reserve ($50–$80) selections |
| **Delivery** | Free delivery with setup — wines arranged, chilled, and ready |
| **Setup** | Full table arrangement: wines staged by course, ice buckets provided |
| **Sommelier** | 2-hour Roberto appearance included (welcome pour + wine introductions) |
| **Glassware** | Included — up to 25 stems (delivery + pickup next day) |
| **Ice & Cooler** | Included — multiple ice buckets, cooler for whites/sparkling |
| **Printed Materials** | Custom menu card with wine descriptions and food pairing suggestions |
| **Target Margin** | 50–60% gross margin |
| **COGS Estimate** | $300–$500 in wine + $50 delivery/setup + $0 Roberto (salaried) |

**Upsell opportunities:**
- Extended sommelier presence (+$150/hr beyond included 2 hours)
- Premium/cult wine upgrade (+$200–$500)
- Wine & food pairing consultation with villa chef (+$200)
- Magnum bottles for centerpieces (+$80–$150 each)
- Post-event wine club signup — recurring deliveries to home address
- Caviar & wine pairing add-on (+$250–$500)

---

### 1C. The Grand Affair — $2,000+

**The occasion:** Destination weddings, rehearsal dinners, large corporate events, gala dinners, yacht parties.

**Guests:** 25–75+ people.

| Component | Details |
|---|---|
| **Wines Included** | 20–50+ bottles, custom-selected for event menu and theme |
| **Wine Style** | Full range: sparkling for toasts, whites for cocktail hour, reds for dinner, dessert wine or port for finale |
| **Delivery** | Full logistics: delivery, setup, breakdown, glassware pickup |
| **Setup** | Complete wine service station(s), bar setup, ice, coolers, decanting |
| **Sommelier** | Full-event Roberto presence included (4–6 hours) |
| **Glassware** | Included — up to 100 stems, multiple types (flute, white, red) |
| **Ice & Service** | Full ice service, multiple stations, wine buckets |
| **Printed Materials** | Branded wine menu cards, table tent descriptions, custom labels available |
| **Staffing** | Additional pour staff available (+$35/hr per person) |
| **Target Margin** | 45–55% gross margin |
| **COGS Estimate** | $800–$1,500+ in wine + $100–200 logistics + staffing |

**Upsell opportunities:**
- Custom-labeled wines for the event (wedding labels, corporate branding) (+$15/bottle)
- Pre-event tasting session for couple/host to select wines (+$300)
- Morning-after brunch wine package (+$400–$800)
- Craft spirits bar add-on (cocktail hour) (+$500–$1,500)
- Groomsmen/bridesmaid gift bottles — premium single bottles, gift-wrapped (+$75 each)
- Wine wall or wine display installation (+$250)

---

### Margin Summary

| Tier | Price Range | Target COGS | Target Gross Margin | Gross Profit |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| The Gathering | $250–$400 | $100–$165 | 55–65% | $138–$260 |
| The Celebration | $800–$1,200 | $350–$550 | 50–60% | $400–$720 |
| The Grand Affair | $2,000–$5,000+ | $900–$2,500 | 45–55% | $900–$2,750 |

**Key margin insight:** The Gathering has the highest percentage margin because it's wine-only with minimal service costs. The Grand Affair has the highest dollar margin but requires more labor. The Celebration is the sweet spot — high margin dollars with manageable logistics.

---

## 2. Target Market — Grand Cayman

### 2A. Luxury Villa Rental Companies

These are the **#1 priority** — villa guests are the perfect customer. They're on vacation, spending freely, hosting dinners, and have no easy way to source premium wine.

| Company | Website | Notes | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Grand Cayman Villas & Condos** | grandcaymanvillas.com | 100+ private oceanfront homes, largest villa manager on island | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Luxury Cayman Villas** | luxurycaymanvillas.com | Boutique collection, luxury positioning, concierge services | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Grand Cayman Luxury Villas** | grandcaymanluxuryvillas.com | Platinum-level service, luxury focus | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Nocturne Luxury Villas** | nocturneluxuryvillas.com | Curated experiences, milestone celebrations, trip planning | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Isle Blue** | isleblue.co | Caribbean-wide luxury villas, Cayman collection | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **The Meridian** | meridian.ky | Seven Mile Beach luxury villas | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Exceptional Villas** | exceptionalvillas.com | Global platform, Cayman listings | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Villas of Distinction** | villasofdistinction.com | Global luxury villa network | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **The Residences (Ritz-Carlton)** | theresidencesgrandcaymanrentals.com | Ritz-branded private residences with concierge | 🔴 HIGH |

**Contact approach:** Roberto visits in person with a complimentary tasting kit (3 half-bottles or splits). Ask to meet the concierge/guest services manager. Offer a free private tasting for their team. Leave a one-pager and commission structure sheet.

---

### 2B. Event & Wedding Planners

Wedding planners are gold — every destination wedding needs wine, and the planner influences the vendor choice.

| Company | Website | Specialty | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Celebrations Ltd.** | celebrationsltd.com | Full-service events & weddings, 30+ years, largest on island | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Direction Event Planning** | directionevents.com | Luxury destination weddings, modern/fresh aesthetic | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Five Star Events Cayman** | fivestareventscayman.com | Personalized weddings & events | 🔴 HIGH |
| **ETHOS Event Collective** | ethoseventcollective.com | Grand Cayman's largest DMC, corporate & large events | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Simply Weddings** | simplyweddings.ky | Cruise ship weddings, elopements, since 2008 | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Island Weddings & Events** | caymanislandsweddingsandevents.com | Cruise ship weddings, intimate ceremonies | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Isla Weddings** | islaweddings.ky | Weddings + corporate events | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Island Soul Cayman** | islandsoulcayman.com | Experience-based events, wellness & adventure | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Caribbean Culinary Concepts** | caribbeanculinaryconcepts.com | Culinary tours & intimate food events | 🟡 MEDIUM |

**Contact approach:** Email introduction (template in Section 5) → follow up with in-person visit → offer a complimentary tasting for their next planning meeting. Position as "your dedicated wine partner for events."

---

### 2C. Hotels & Resorts — Concierge Programs

Hotel concierges recommend services daily to high-spending guests. A 10% referral fee makes 7 Cellars an easy recommendation.

| Hotel | Location | Notes | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| **The Ritz-Carlton, Grand Cayman** | Seven Mile Beach | AAA Five Diamond, top luxury property, Club Lounge concierge | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Kimpton Seafire Resort + Spa** | Seven Mile Beach | Luxury boutique, strong F&B program | 🔴 HIGH |
| **The Westin Grand Cayman** | Seven Mile Beach | Large resort, events/weddings on-site | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Hotel Indigo Grand Cayman** | George Town area | Conference/event venue, corporate groups | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Wyndham Reef Resort** | East End | Corporate retreats up to 50 guests | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Grand Cayman Marriott Resort** | Seven Mile Beach | Large property, group bookings | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Comfort Suites** | Seven Mile Beach | Mid-tier, but high volume | 🟢 LOW |
| **Sunshine Suites** | Seven Mile Beach | Budget-friendly, smaller groups | 🟢 LOW |

**Contact approach:** Request meeting with concierge manager or guest experience director. Bring a tasting kit. Present the referral commission program. Offer to provide branded cards for concierge desks. Supply a WhatsApp number for instant ordering.

---

### 2D. Yacht Charter Companies

Yacht guests want premium wine on board. Currently, most charters handle their own provisioning — 7 Cellars can become the default supplier.

| Company | Website | Notes | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Cayman Yacht Charters** | caymanyachtcharters.com | Premier selection, multiple vessel types | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Cayman Luxury Charters** | caymanluxurycharters.com | Weddings, celebrations, sunset cruises, up to 32 guests | 🔴 HIGH |
| **Yachts Cayman** | yachtscayman.com | Weddings, receptions, parties | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Caribbean Luxury Charter** | caribbeanluxurycharter.com | Meticulously crafted experiences | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **No Drama Charters** | nodramacharters.com | Private yacht charters, family-friendly | 🟡 MEDIUM |
| **Cobalt Custom Charters** | cobaltcustomcharters.com | Private boat charters, luxury vessel | 🟡 MEDIUM |

**Contact approach:** Visit marina/dock offices. Offer to pre-stock wines for their charter calendar. Provide a simple order form (WhatsApp or text). Deliver directly to the dock, pre-chilled.

---

### 2E. Referral Commission Structure

**Standard: 10% commission on total package value, paid monthly.**

| Package | Price | Commission to Referrer |
|---|---|---|
| The Gathering | $250–$400 | $25–$40 per booking |
| The Celebration | $800–$1,200 | $80–$120 per booking |
| The Grand Affair | $2,000–$5,000 | $200–$500 per booking |

**Terms:**
- Commission paid on collected revenue (not on cancellations)
- Monthly payout via bank transfer or check
- No cap — the more referrals, the more they earn
- Tracking: referral partner name on every booking form
- Bonus: 15% commission after 10 referrals in a quarter

**Why this works:** A concierge referring 4 Celebration packages per month earns $320–$480/month passively. That's meaningful money for a recommendation they'd make anyway.

---

## 3. Revenue Model & Projections

### 3A. Assumptions

- **Gross margin on wine:** 45% average (40% on volume, 50% on premium)
- **Service margin:** 70% (sommelier time is salaried, glassware is reusable)
- **Blended gross margin per package:** ~50%
- **Peak season:** November–April (6 months)
- **Slow season:** May–October (6 months)
- **Referral commission:** 10% of revenue (paid out of gross margin)

---

### 3B. Three Scenarios

#### Conservative — "Slow Build"

| Metric | Peak Month | Slow Month | Annual |
|---|---|---|---|
| Gatherings/month | 6 | 2 | 48 |
| Celebrations/month | 2 | 1 | 18 |
| Grand Affairs/month | 0.5 | 0 | 3 |
| **Monthly Revenue** | **$4,500** | **$1,500** | **$36,000** |
| Gross Profit (50%) | $2,250 | $750 | $18,000 |
| Less: Commissions (10%) | -$450 | -$150 | -$3,600 |
| **Net Contribution** | **$1,800** | **$600** | **$14,400** |

#### Moderate — "Steady Growth"

| Metric | Peak Month | Slow Month | Annual |
|---|---|---|---|
| Gatherings/month | 12 | 4 | 96 |
| Celebrations/month | 4 | 2 | 36 |
| Grand Affairs/month | 1 | 0.5 | 9 |
| **Monthly Revenue** | **$9,800** | **$3,600** | **$80,400** |
| Gross Profit (50%) | $4,900 | $1,800 | $40,200 |
| Less: Commissions (10%) | -$980 | -$360 | -$8,040 |
| **Net Contribution** | **$3,920** | **$1,440** | **$32,160** |

#### Aggressive — "Full Pipeline"

| Metric | Peak Month | Slow Month | Annual |
|---|---|---|---|
| Gatherings/month | 20 | 8 | 168 |
| Celebrations/month | 8 | 3 | 66 |
| Grand Affairs/month | 2 | 1 | 18 |
| **Monthly Revenue** | **$19,600** | **$7,200** | **$160,800** |
| Gross Profit (50%) | $9,800 | $3,600 | $80,400 |
| Less: Commissions (10%) | -$1,960 | -$720 | -$16,080 |
| **Net Contribution** | **$7,840** | **$2,880** | **$64,320** |

---

### 3C. Break-Even Analysis

How many events per month to hit target contribution levels:

| Monthly Target | Gatherings Only | Celebrations Only | Mix (60/30/10) |
|---|---|---|---|
| **$3,000/month** | 19 events @ $325 avg | 5 events @ $1,000 avg | 8 Gatherings + 3 Celebrations |
| **$5,000/month** | 31 events | 8 events | 12 Gatherings + 4 Celebrations + 1 Grand Affair |
| **$8,000/month** | 50 events | 13 events | 18 Gatherings + 6 Celebrations + 1 Grand Affair |

**Key insight:** The Celebration tier is the efficiency driver. Each Celebration booking is worth ~4 Gatherings in revenue but only marginally more effort. Focus sales efforts on securing recurring Celebration-tier partnerships.

---

### 3D. Seasonality Pattern

| Month | Relative Demand | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| November | 🟡 Ramp-up | Season opens, early bookings |
| December | 🔴 Peak | Holiday parties, corporate year-end |
| January | 🔴 Peak | New Year, wedding season begins |
| February | 🔴 Peak | Valentine's, destination weddings |
| March | 🔴 Peak | Spring break, corporate retreats |
| April | 🟡 Moderate | Easter, shoulder season |
| May | 🟡 Moderate | Shoulder, weddings still active |
| June | 🟢 Slow | Low tourist season |
| July | 🟢 Slow | Local events only |
| August | 🟢 Slow | Hurricane season caution |
| September | 🟢 Slow | Lowest demand |
| October | 🟡 Ramp-up | Pirates Week, season prep |

---

## 4. Execution Playbook — Roberto & Tallyn

### 4A. Four-Week Launch Plan

#### Week 1 — Foundation

**Roberto:**
- [ ] Assemble tasting kit: 6 wines (2 sparkling, 2 white, 2 red) in half-bottles or splits
- [ ] Practice the 60-second pitch (see Section 4D)
- [ ] Identify 5 villa companies for first visits (start with Grand Cayman Villas & Condos, Luxury Cayman Villas, Nocturne, The Residences)
- [ ] Identify 3 event planners to email (Celebrations Ltd., Direction Events, ETHOS)

**Tallyn:**
- [ ] Create booking spreadsheet (see Section 4E for template)
- [ ] Print 30 copies of package one-pager (Section 5A)
- [ ] Print 20 copies of referral commission sheet (Section 5C)
- [ ] Set up dedicated WhatsApp Business number or line for event bookings
- [ ] Create simple invoice template in Cin7 or QuickBooks

#### Week 2 — First Contacts

**Roberto:**
- [ ] Visit 3 villa companies in person with tasting kit
- [ ] Send email outreach to 5 event planners (use template in Section 5B)
- [ ] Visit Ritz-Carlton concierge desk — request meeting with concierge manager
- [ ] Visit Kimpton Seafire — same approach

**Tallyn:**
- [ ] Follow up on any email opens/responses within 48 hours
- [ ] Track all contacts in booking spreadsheet (Leads tab)
- [ ] Prepare glassware inventory count — how many stems available?
- [ ] Source ice/cooler supplies — identify vendor for bulk ice

#### Week 3 — Tastings & Demos

**Roberto:**
- [ ] Host first complimentary tasting for a villa company team (30 min, their office or a villa)
- [ ] Follow up with all Week 2 contacts — offer tasting
- [ ] Visit 2 yacht charter companies at marina
- [ ] Visit Westin and Marriott concierge desks

**Tallyn:**
- [ ] Process first booking if any come in
- [ ] Send commission structure sheet to all confirmed referral partners
- [ ] Begin tracking referral sources

#### Week 4 — Optimize & Scale

**Roberto:**
- [ ] Host 2nd tasting for an event planner
- [ ] Follow up on all outstanding leads
- [ ] Debrief on what's working — which pitch resonates, which tier gets most interest?
- [ ] Adjust wine selections based on feedback

**Tallyn:**
- [ ] Month-end report: leads contacted, tastings completed, bookings closed
- [ ] Commission payouts if applicable
- [ ] Inventory reconciliation — event wine stock vs. regular stock

---

### 4B. Roberto's Role — Ongoing

| Activity | Frequency | Time |
|---|---|---|
| Villa/hotel visits (relationship maintenance) | 2–3 per week | 1 hour each |
| Event planner check-ins | 1–2 per week | 30 min each |
| On-site sommelier appearances (Celebration/Grand Affair) | 2–4 per month | 2–6 hours each |
| Free tastings for new partners | 1–2 per month | 45 min each |
| Wine selection for upcoming events | As needed | 30 min each |

**Roberto IS the product.** His presence, knowledge, and personality are what differentiates a 7 Cellars event package from "ordering wine from Jacques Scott." Every in-person touchpoint builds the brand.

---

### 4C. Tallyn's Role — Ongoing

| Activity | Frequency | Time |
|---|---|---|
| Process incoming bookings | As received | 15 min each |
| Confirm delivery logistics | Per booking | 10 min each |
| Invoicing & payment collection | Per booking | 10 min each |
| Referral commission tracking & payouts | Monthly | 1 hour |
| Inventory management — event wine stock | Weekly | 30 min |
| Lead follow-up emails/calls | 2–3 per week | 30 min total |
| Monthly performance report | Monthly | 1 hour |

---

### 4D. The Free Tasting Pitch — Roberto's Script

**Setting:** Roberto walks into a luxury villa company office, tasting kit in hand.

> "Hi, I'm Roberto from 7 Cellars — we're Grand Cayman's premium wine importer. I know your guests are always looking for special experiences, and we've just launched private event wine packages specifically designed for villa guests.
>
> I'd love to do a quick complimentary tasting for your team — takes about 20 minutes, I bring the wines. That way you can experience what we offer firsthand and feel confident recommending us.
>
> We also offer a referral commission — 10% on every booking your team sends our way. For a typical villa dinner package, that's $25–$120 per referral.
>
> Can I leave you this one-pager and schedule a tasting this week?"

**What Roberto brings to every first visit:**
- 3 wines (1 sparkling, 1 white, 1 red) — enough for 2–3 people to taste
- Package one-pager
- Referral commission sheet
- Business card
- A smile and zero pressure

---

### 4E. Booking & Tracking Spreadsheet

**Tab 1: Leads**

| Column | Description |
|---|---|
| Date Added | When lead was identified |
| Company/Contact | Name of villa company, planner, concierge |
| Type | Villa / Planner / Hotel / Yacht / Other |
| Status | New / Contacted / Tasting Scheduled / Active Partner / Inactive |
| Last Contact Date | Most recent touchpoint |
| Next Action | What to do next |
| Notes | Any details |

**Tab 2: Bookings**

| Column | Description |
|---|---|
| Booking # | Sequential (EVT-001, EVT-002, etc.) |
| Date | Event date |
| Client Name | End customer |
| Package Tier | Gathering / Celebration / Grand Affair |
| Revenue | Total billed |
| COGS | Wine cost + delivery + supplies |
| Referral Partner | Who referred this booking |
| Commission Due | 10% of revenue |
| Commission Paid | Date paid |
| Status | Confirmed / Delivered / Invoiced / Paid / Cancelled |

**Tab 3: Monthly Summary**

| Column | Description |
|---|---|
| Month | Calendar month |
| Total Bookings | Count |
| Total Revenue | Sum |
| Total COGS | Sum |
| Gross Profit | Revenue - COGS |
| Commissions Paid | Sum |
| Net Contribution | Gross Profit - Commissions |

---

### 4F. Follow-Up Cadence

| Touchpoint | Timing | Method |
|---|---|---|
| Initial outreach | Day 0 | In-person visit or email |
| Follow-up if no response | Day 3 | Email or WhatsApp |
| Second follow-up | Day 7 | Phone call or in-person |
| Tasting invitation | Day 10 | Direct ask |
| Post-tasting thank you | Day of tasting | WhatsApp + email |
| First booking check-in | 2 weeks after partnership starts | In-person |
| Ongoing relationship | Monthly | Quick visit or WhatsApp message |
| Quarterly review | Every 3 months | Review commission totals, see if they need anything |

---

## 5. Sales Materials — Draft Copy

### 5A. Package One-Pager

---

**7 CELLARS — PRIVATE EVENT WINE PACKAGES**

*Grand Cayman's Premium Wine Experience, Delivered to You*

---

**THE GATHERING — $250–$400**
Perfect for intimate dinner parties and villa evenings (4–8 guests)

✓ 3–4 hand-selected wines (sparkling, white, red)
✓ Delivered pre-chilled with tasting notes
✓ Same-day delivery available
✓ Ice and insulated service included



---
